DOC.HEAD: Minnesota Republicans Embrace Embattled Durenberger
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Dave Durenberger received a warm welcome home from Republicans meeting at a state convention Friday. He vowed to survive an ethics investigation into his financial dealings. ``I've got the best friends in all the world,'' Durenberger told a luncheon of the Independent Republicans, the state party. It was his first public appearance since the Senate Ethics Committee on Wednesday completed two days of hearings. Durenberger received a standing ovation from the 1,300 luncheon guests when he entered the banquet room, and another when he finished his 20-minute speech. Delegates gathered around the 12-year Senate veteran, and handshakes, hugs and kisses were exchanged. ``I'm learning so many lessons these days about how tough times bring out the best in you and the best in your friends,'' Durenberger said. Durengerger said he would not resign. ``I just stand on the election results of November 1988,'' he said. ``This is a six-year term.'' The Ethics Committee met for two days to investigate allegations that Durenberger tried to cirumvent Senate limits on speaking fees and tried to hide his ownership in a Minneapolis condominium to collect travel reinbursements. Durenberger did not refer specifically to the allegations, but apologized. ``I've made mistakes and I'm taking responsibility for every single one of them,'' he said, adding that he acted in good faith and did not violate the public trust. Durenberger focused his speech on the accomplishments of the Reagan and Bush administrations and on his work ahead in the Senate. Durenberger noted that he had been selected as one of seven Senate conferees to work out differences with the House on the Clean Air Act.

DOC.HEAD: Water Would Be Shipped by Tanker Under Proposal for Dry Coast Region
DOC.TEXT: Huge oil tankers steaming along the Pacific coast from Alaska could be joined next year by ships carrying water to drought-stricken Southern California, city officials said Friday. Water has become so scarce in Santa Barbara that it's a crime for a homeowner to hose down his lawn. The gives away low-flow shower heads and offers $80 each to people who switch from big-flush to small-flush toilets. The water tanker idea is one of three being considered by the city to ease the drought, said city spokesman Pete Ramsdell. The city is negotiating with three companies on a proposal to import thousands of gallons from Canada. Another idea is to construct a $50 million desalination plant that would turn sea water into drinking water, said Ramsdell. The city staff will recommend to the City Council on July 31 which idea is worth pursuing further, Ramsdell said. Santa Barbara is not connected to either Northern California or Colorado River supplies and must rely entirely on local sources for water. Thus it has been the Southern California city hardest hit by the region's 4-year-old drought. City officials made it clear earlier this year they would listen to just about anyone with an idea on how to get them more water. That's where the water tanker idea came in, Ramsdell said. Proposals rom two Canadian companies and a Santa Barbara firm are currently being studied. Officials of the local company, Sun Belt Water Inc., met with city officials Friday, said Richard Schuller, the company's president. The company has proposed using tankers to bring in 14,000 acre-feet of water per trip from British Columbia's Toba Inlet. Sun Belt's partner in the deal, British Columbia-based water bottler Snowcap Ltd., is one of several companies already licensed by the Canadian province to export fresh water. Ramsdell said the city, which used about 16,000 acre-feet of water a year before the drought, wants to import at least 5,000 acre-feet a year of water. Schuller, noting his company proposed bringing in far more than that, said the rest could be sold to other water users in Santa Barbara County. Schuller said his company made an initial bid of $2,700 per acre-foot. The costs would cover installing terminals in Canada and California for drawing and unloading the water, he said. ``We would own the facilities and operate the ships,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: What to Do About the Thousands of Spies in a Unified Germany?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Communist spies are coming in from the cold throughout Germany, and officials are trying to lure others from possible Soviet recruitment with suggestions of amnesty. For 40 years, East German agents using West Germany as their Western base stole vital defense and technological secrets, wrecked one West German government and turned the German states into the espionage battleground of the Cold War. With the collapse of the East German Communist government and the rapidly approaching merger of the two Germanys, officials say the former adversaries are cooperating. In addition, many former spooks are talking, some in hopes of bettering their fate in a unified Germany. ``As you can imagine, the information flows quite freely because we have former Stasi officials who come to us and speak very frankly and freely,'' said Lutz Stavenhagen, a security expert in Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government. Stasi in German is short for the old East German Ministry for State Security, which included domestic and foreign intelligence agents. West German espionage experts estimate there are up to 6,000 spies in West Germany, including East German agents and West German defectors, but they won't say how many are known to authorities. The treaty that outlines the conditions for the economic and social unification of the two German states does not address the espionage issue. What to do with the spies has become ``a very, very tricky matter,'' said one West German government official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. An amnesty has been suggested. ``They must think about it, because (otherwise) there would be too many people at risk to be punished on both sides of the former German border,'' said Hans-Gert Lange, spokesman for the Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution. Adding impetus to an amnesty proposal is the fear the Soviets are recruiting agents. ``We know that obviously the Soviet secret service, the KGB, is trying to get hold of the most efficient of these agents,'' Stavenhagen said in an interview Wednesday. He said officials have tried to counter that by urging them to turn themselves in to avoid persecution. A similar situation developed after World War II, as both the Soviets and Western allies scrambled to recruit the top agents who had worked in Hitler's secret service. Stavenhagen said the most likely outcome for agents in West Germany would be an ``amnesty for the normal spy _ looking into boxes and papers and that sort of thing,'' but the ``basic condition is that they turn themselves over.'' Top spies, ones the West Germans say ``have blood on their hands,'' would not qualify for an amnesty, he said. A different amnesty _ perhaps one without conditions _ would probably apply to the spies in East Germany who worked for the branch of Stasi that spied on the West. One West German government espionage expert, who spoke on condition of anonymity, estimated there were about 12,000 such spies. ``It's bad enough, but what can you do? At the time they did it, they didn't do something illegal according to GDR (East German) laws,'' Stavenhagen said. Two top targets in East Germany are Markus Wolf, former head of East German espionage, and former senior West German counterintelligence official Hans-Joachim Tiedge, who fled to the East with vital secrets. Stavenhagen said they probably would not qualify for amnesty. West German officials have alleged in the last several weeks that Wolf is helping the KGB set up a new spy network, a charge he denies. In an interview with Junge Welt, the East German youth newspaper, Wolf termed as ``absolute nonsense'' speculation that the KGB had taken over complete groups of former East German spies. However, in another interview with the Sueddeutsche Zeitung, he said he could not rule out the possibility that individual spies had gone over to Moscow of their own will. A decision on how to handle the spies is expected before formal German unification, which Stavenhagen estimated would be before year's end. One government official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said a decision could be ready in two weeks, but that because of the sensitivity of the issue, it probably would not be announced until a majority of the governing coalition was assured. In the meantime, the two German interior ministers ``are in very close cooperation,'' Stavenhagen said. ``From the eastern part of Germany, a substantial number (of spies) have come here ... and we have very valuable information from them, so those still hiding hoping that they wouldn't be detected, I think are doing the wrong thing.''

DOC.HEAD: Long-Neglected Miners Play New Role as Shock Troops
With PM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Miners, among the most outspoken critics of the former Communist rulers, have become the shock troops of President-elect Ion Iliescu during anti-government protests. Neglected during more than four decades of Communist rule, the miners have enjoyed the biggest rewards of the December revolution that toppled dictator Nicolae Ceausescu: higher salaries, more food and less work. Though their presence in the pits is vital to the country's growing energy needs, Iliescu and his ruling National Salvation Front have called miners to Bucharest three times since the revolution to act against government opponents. While Iliescu has pledged to move Romania toward a free-market pluralistic society, he has relied on the tactics of the former hard-line Communists rather than Western standards of democratic dialogue to deal with protest. ``Traditionally, when Communist bosses thought their political fate was in danger, they asked the workers to come and help them,'' said Stelian Tanase, editor of the anti-Communist weekly ``22.'' ``Now, the neo-Communists largely making up the Front are appealing to the miners, viewed as the workers' advance guard, who received everything they wanted from the government,'' Tanase said. In a controlled Communist society, the shows of support posed little danger, but relying on such tactics during a turbulent post-revolutionary period has proved bloody and destabilizing, observers said. ``Iliescu's game is a very dangerous one. Using the miners against other civilian groups, such as students and intellectuals, can lead to unforeseen consequences,''said Emil Hurezeanu, a Romanian exile and editor at Munich-based Radio Free Europe. ``Iliescu still thinks as a Communist. People like him, who have been trained as Communists since childhood, cannot discard the mold too easily,'' wrote Vladimir Tismaneanu, a professor of Romanian stock who lives in Philadelphia, in the independent newspaper Romania Libera. Until the December revolution that deposed and executed former Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, Romania's 70,000 miners worked more and received less pay and food than their Soviet bloc colleagues. Most work in mountainous western Transylvania, dominated the largest coal basin of the Jiu Valley, where 30,000 coal miners went on strike in 1977 demanding a five-day week, six-hour day, free hot meal and retirement at 50. Ceausescu, taken aback by the biggest work protest in Communist Romania, initially gave in, but later rescinded most concessions. The now disbanded secret police arrested hundreds of miners, and their leaders disappeared. The Front, a loose organization of ex-Communists, technocrats and industrial workers, set to improving the living standard of workers _ especially the vocal miners _ shortly after taking power in the revoution. In January, Iliescu, 60, a former Communist Party secretary, met miners' leaders and agreed to their demands, adding alpine chalets as a bonus. According to some Romanians, Iliescu's aim was primarily to appease miners, but they said that at the same time, he may have realized he could manipulate them to the Front's advantage. Days later, Iliescu made a televised appeal for their support to counter a major anti-government demonstration. Thousands of miners arrived in Bucharest and attacked an opposition party headquarters. Corneliu Coposu, president of the National Peasants Party, had to be rescued by an armored personnel carrier. On Feb. 19, a day after opposition demonstrators stormed and ransacked government headquarters, 5,000 miners came to Bucharest again to show support for the Front. They warned they would return in case of further trouble. Early Thursday, thousands of miners poured into Bucharest at the government's request after anti-government demonstrators stormed and set fire to police and Interior Ministry buildings. The violence started early Wednesday when club-wielding police routed anti-Communist demonstrators who had blocked University Square for 53 days. Operating as vigilantes or paramilitary groups, the helmeted miners, their faces smudged with coal dust, stopped cars, checked identities, made home searches, confiscated or destroyed property and clubbed anyone they wanted. ``It's clear that they had all the logistical support provided by the government,'' a Western analyst said on condition of anonymity. ``They came on buses or trains from as far away as Maramures, 300 miles northwest of Bucharest, and in the capital they were given food and milk from army trucks. The whole thing was well organized,'' the analyst said.

DOC.HEAD: Snow Surfer Dies in Accident in French Alps
DOC.TEXT: A snow surfer who made pioneering descents in the Himalayas and the Alps was killed while trying to conquer a steep slope on Mont Blanc, police said. Bruno Gouvy, 27, skidded on an ice patch shortly after being dropped by helicopter Friday on the top of the Green Needle, a 13,523-foot peak on Mont Blanc in the French Alps, police said. As those aboard the helicopter, including a film crew, looked on, Gouvy skidded more than 3,000 feet down a steep face before falling into a crevasse. Snow surfing, an increasingly popular sport, is a form of skiing on a single board, positioned like a surfer. Ski poles are not used. Gouvy reportedly held the altitude record for his sport with a 1989 descent on Mount Everest starting at 27,650 feet. Gouvy, who last year snow-surfed down the west face of the Eiger in the Swiss Alps, also was an experienced mountain climber and a devotee of free-fall parachuting.

DOC.HEAD: Hopes That Rose With Revolution Fade With Violence
With PM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Viorel Budulacu, beaten up during a crackdown on anti-government demonstrations, says he suffered more than cuts and bruises. He also lost his idealism. ``The only chance is to defect _ flee from Romania,'' said the 25-year-old student. Like many students who helped spearhead the December revolution that toppled Nicolae Ceausescu, Budulacu said he has lost faith in President-elect Ion Iliescu. Iliescu and his National Salvation Front won the May 20 elections but the protesters say they are continuing Ceausescu's repressive policies. Budulacu, a sophomore at Bucharest Polytechnic, was one of 367 people hurt since police broke up a 53-day-old peaceful anti-Communist protest at downtown University Square on Wednesday. That action touched off fierce street violence that claimed five lives when security forces opened fire on crowds attacking them. Iliescu called for help in quelling the anti-government demonstrations, and thousands of coal miners responded by pouring into the capital and brutally beating anyone they suspected of being an opponent of the government. Marius Dinu, 22, an architecture student and University Square protester, told reporters at the Emergency Hospital on Friday he has no hope left for Romania. ``I don't know what's awaiting me. I would like to leave the country for good ... and forget all about the hopes the revolution has given me,'' Dinu said. Dinu was hospitalized after being clubbed, punched and kicked by miners Thursday morning in the School of Architecture on the square. ``They threw us on top of each other into a moaning pile,'' he said. Emergency Hospital director Mihai Ciuta told a news conference Friday that 48 of the 236 injured people treated at his facility since Wednesday morning remained hospitalized, most with multiple injuries. Marian Munteanu, president of the Students' League and one of the leaders of the anti-government protest, has a fractured skull and broken left leg and arm, Dr. Horia Georgescu said. Munteaunu, speaking from the emergency ward, said he believed Iliescu's rule was doomed to fail. ``I wouldn't like to be in Iliescu's place. I believe in God and one day we will all have to answer God's questions for whatever we have done,'' he said. ``It's a long way to democracy,'' said Munteaunu, close to tears. ``You are now watching a growing dictator.'' Iliescu was shown on state television Friday night thanking the miners ``with all my heart'' for defending his government. Marius Dobrescu, beaten by paramilitary police when he and other demonstrators stormed the state television building, is now in intensive care. He said he also wants to leave Romania. ``I am sorry I survived Ceausescu's times and I find myself wanting to leave the country again,'' Dobrescu said.

DOC.HEAD: Rising Fears of Housing Shortage for Soviet Immigrants
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Israel is fast running out of housing for Soviet Jews, and the country could face a severe shortage by year's end. Government officials say more than 43,000 Soviet Jews have arrived this year, and the influx has pushed up rents in some areas, fueling protests by young Israelis that they are being priced out of the housing market. ``If something isn't done soon, we are going to have a social explosion,'' warned Jerusalem's deputy mayor, Avraham Kehila. The emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel has been running at record levels since Moscow relaxed exit policies in the spring of 1989, and the United States subsequently tightened its immigration rules. Nearly 13,000 Soviets came to Israel in 1989. The 1990 total is expected to exceed 150,000, Israeli officials say. Uri Shoshani, director of engineering and planning in the Housing Ministry, said Israel's estimated 20,000 vacant rental units will be filled in four months. Three months later, Israel will have exhausted it's supply of ``alternate'' housing, such as holiday flats, army camps and off-season hotel rooms, he said. He said the ministry has asked that 60,000 new units be built this year, or three times the rate of recent years. But so far, ground has been broken for only 7,000 new homes, Shoshani said. ``We're building as fast as we can but we're worried that there just won't be enough housing to go around,'' Shoshani said. The shortage already is apparent in the modest-priced units that Soviet immigrant families can afford on government housing subsidies of $237 monthly. A recent survey by the Hebrew daily Hadashot showed rental prices had risen significantly. In suburban Nazareth, monthly rents for two-bedroom units have risen from $80 to $200 in the past year, Hadashot said. In Rishon Lezion near Tel Aviv, rents have doubled to $600, and in Jerusalem they are up 150 percent to $450, the paper said. The increase has come about because landlords have raised rents on the cheapest apartments to match the Soviets' monthly subsidy. That drives up rents all down the line. In Israel, the average monthly after-tax income for a family of four is $1,160. Many young Israelis say they cannot compete with Soviets for housing and they have begun forming protest groups to seek government help. In Beersheva in the southern Negev desert, scores of university students, young couples and recently discharged soldiers staged a sit-down protest to demand affordable housing. They have formed a group called ``Young People Without Apartments'' to press their concerns. Rafi Luzan, a 36-year-old factory worker, from Carmiel near Haifa, went on a hunger strike earlier this month after his rent was raised to $300 from $150. He was forced to move out of his flat with his wife and their son. Luzan, who earns $650 a month, is encouraging people thrown out of their homes to live in tents outside Carmiel's municipal building until their plight is resolved. ``Rents have doubled all over town, and working people and young couples don't have the money to pay for it,'' Luzan told Israel radio. Hana Koval, spokeswoman for the Carmiel government, warned of ``a social catastrophe'' if emergency measures aren't taken soon. She said Carmiel officials wanted the Israeli government to buy up unsold houses and apartments and rent them at subsidized rates to Israelis. Town officials also have called for rent controls.

DOC.HEAD: Archaeologists Search for Clues from the Ill-Fated Donner Party
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: An archaeological team is sifting through a Sierra Nevada campsite for remnants from the final days of George and Jacob Donner, whose dreams of life in sunny California ended near here in icy disaster. The two brothers from Illinois and most of their party died 144 years ago when a raging October snowstorm halted their westward trek and sealed their fate. Donald Hardesty, an archaeologist at the University of Nevada, Reno, is leading a team of students and volunteers in an effort to pinpoint the exact whereabouts of the brothers' last camp at Alder Creek. ``This camp is not nearly as well known or understood through written accounts,'' he said Thursday. The Donner families stopped at Alder Creek when a wagon axle broke. The rest of the party continued to a lake about five miles away, now known as Donner Lake. Incessant snow trapped both groups for six months in 1846-1847. As starvation set in, they ate boiled hides for nourishment. When those were gone, they turned to the flesh of their comrades who died of weakness. Of the 87 people who became stranded, 39 survived. Nine of the 12 adults and nine children with the Donner families lived to see the spring. The Donner brothers did not. Hardesty said it is believed George Donner used tree limbs propped against a giant Ponderosa Pine that still towers over the site, and covered them with animal hides and quilts for a shelter. Jacob Donner created a similar lean-to for his family about 200 yards away. Hardesty hopes to uncover the location of a third camp believed to have been used by teamsters traveling with the families. Armed with buckets, brushes, trowels and sifters, 19 students and 10 volunteers sifted the soil near the two sites on Thursday in the joint venture of the university and the U.S. Forest Service. As the excavating team worked in the warm June sunshine, yellow and purple wildflowers bloomed in a nearby meadow and the sweet scent of sagebrush perfumed the air. But almost as a reminder of the task, gray clouds hugged the snowcapped peaks of the Sierra. Hardesty said the group hopes to find small items and fragments at Alder Creek. He said diaries were kept by those at the Donner Lake cabins, but no writings have been found near the Alder Creek site. Hardesty participated in a 1984 excavation of the Donner Lake site, where bone fragments, cloth remnants, chips of pottery and hardware were uncovered. The most significant find there, he said, was a bronze, Roman Catholic medallion.

DOC.HEAD: Murder Conviction Reversed for Juror Misconduct
DOC.TEXT: An appeals court reversed convictions for murder and manslaughter stemming from a 1987 slaying because jurors visited the crime site on their own to assess the evidence. ``Unauthorized visits to the crime scene are condemned,'' the 1st District Court of Appeal said in a ruling released Friday. The state court, in a 3-0 decision, said the observations by two jurors contradicted important defense testimony in the case. The court granted a new trial to Dana Deweese of Castro Valley and his sister, Deanna Joao. Joao's lawyer, Kyle Gee, said she already has served most of her four-year sentence for manslaughter. Deweese was sentenced to 17 years to life for second-degree murder. They were convicted of the August 1987 killing of Kenneth Tyrone Jackson after a brawl between the Deweeses and a neighbor family at a birthday party. Prosecution witnesses said Jackson was not holding a weapon or making threatening gestures when Deweese, standing 15 to 20 feet away, shot him with a gun his sister allegedly had given him. They said Deweese was standing between his brother Duane and Jackson. But Deweese testified that Jackson was pointing a knife at Duane, five or six feet away, and attempting to stab him when Deweese fired into the ground to scare Jackson. He said the gun accidentally went off a second time and hit Jackson, about 40 feet away. After the verdict, two jurors, Margaret Westberg and Daniel Freeman, told a defense investigator they had visited the site during the trial. Freeman said he had concluded that Deweese had been less than 25 feet from Jackson. Freeman's unauthorized observations contradicted Deweese's testimony, supported prosecution testimony that Deweese's brother was not in danger, and caused the juror to question Deweese's credibility, said the opinion by Presiding Justice Harry Low. ``By wrongly viewing the crime scene, the juror was improperly influenced against defendant's version of the shooting,'' Low said. Alameda County Superior Court Judge Stanley Golde ruled that the declarations did not require a new trial, but was overruled by the appeals court.

DOC.HEAD: Hole Swallows City's Water Supply
DOC.TEXT: Nearly a million people have been asked to conserve water after farmers failed to block a hole in a canal that supplies Bristol and surrounding communities. A culvert collapsed Thursday night beneath the Gloucester and Sharpness canal north of this city of about 375,000, located about 100 miles west of London. Farmers threw straw bales, barrels and an old farm gate wrapped in plastic into the whirlpool created by water rushing through the hole, but could not stem the leak. The collapse of the culvert allowed more than a million gallons of water to escape. ``It was like a bath without the plug in, but on an enormous scale,'' said Jeremy Williams, spokesman for the Bristol Water Company. The 18-mile canal carries more than 30 million gallons of water a day to serve an area around Bristol of more than 1,000 square miles. The leak reduced the water supply by two-thirds, Williams said. ``We do not yet know what caused the collapse, but the culvert is 170 years old and it might have just given up,'' Williams said, adding that repairs were expected to take a week. About a million customers were asked to conserve water while supplies from reservoirs in the Mendip hills were pumped in.

DOC.HEAD: Marriage, Soviet-Style: For Some, The Reason's Anything But Love
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Sveta and Oleg have signed up to marry. But they won't be around to hear the wedding bells _ they'll be too busy shopping. In an illustration of how desperate Soviets are for food and consumer goods, Sveta and Oleg have applied to marry just to get the right to shop in a special store for brides and grooms. When they applied, wedded bliss was the furthest thing from their minds, although the couple is in love and living together. Oleg's thoughts were on an imported man's suit, cuff links, gold or silver wedding rings and imported shoes; Sveta's were on her own ring, imported shoes, pantyhose and mascara. For both, it was a chance to shop in Gemini, part of a nationwide chain of stores that is an oasis in a desert of deficits. Here is how the scam works: a single or divorced Soviet finds a partner and applies to marry at a government registration office. They pay a 15-ruble ($24) fee. The couple is assigned a date for an official ceremony and is given a prized booklet of coupons for the Gemini store, as well as food shops meant to supply wedding parties. The couple can shop at the stores until the wedding day, when the coupons expire. They don't show up for the official wedding, and their marriage application is automatically voided. Then they can start all over again. And if their faces become too familiar at the registration office, they can just go to another. That's why Sveta and Oleg have no intention of getting married. The scam is so lucrative that Sveta has applied to marry three times since November _ once with Oleg, twice with his friends. Thousands are participating. One-third of all Soviets applying to marry do so only so they can shop in the special stores, state television's breakfast show ``120 Minutes'' reported in April. And that does not include other matches that are made merely so one partner can obtain a residence permit in a city where the other lives. Looking for loopholes, even in such a sacred institution as marriage, has become a survival technique in a system that has failed to offer Soviets the food and consumer goods they want. ``It's the situation in this state which leads people to such things, where you can't spend money on anything except low-quality food,'' said Viktor, a 31-year-old Muscovite. Like Oleg, Viktor applied to marry a friend of his girlfriend in May so they could obtain access to the special store. ``There's such a terrible deficit. You can't buy anything in the (regular) stores,'' said Sveta, a 28-year-old eye doctor. She declined to give her surname, fearing its publication would help authorities track her down. The fear was largely unfounded, because what she and the thousands of other Soviets are doing is not illegal. ``It's a moral, not a legal issue,'' said Valentina Borzhenkova, director of Moscow's Wedding Palace No. 1, where weddings are performed. ``It's everyone's right if all formalities are followed.'' ``If all the offices had computers, this couldn't happen, because they could check whether you have applied at more than one,'' Sveta said. But computers are as rare as efficient bureaucrats in the Soviet government, so couples can apply as often as they like. The bureaucrats admit they are powerless to end the practice. ``It will stop only when there are no deficits in the country,'' Mrs. Borzhenkova said. At the Gemini store, Sveta has bought American shoes _ virtually unavailable elsewhere in the Soviet Union _ and gold rings. She travels to a nearby socialist country and and resells the rings _ at a hefty profit. Other goods also have a handsome return. Imported women's shoes bought at Gemini for 55 rubles ($89) can be peddled on the black market for 150 rubles ($243), she said. The special stores, however, are not a completely reliable source. Perhaps because of the high number of fictitious marriages, even the special stores have sporadic supplies and long lines _ sometimes a six hour-wait. ``If you want everything, you must go every day and still there's no guarantee you'll get everything you want,'' Sveta said. One day this month, Gemini, where only customers holding a coupon booklet are admitted, was selling 400-ruble ($648) gold rings and 55-ruble ($89) women's shoes from Yugoslavia and Hungary. Aside from its treasure trove of goods, the store is set apart in other ways. It is well lit, clean and colorful, with decorations in a celestial theme. But there is an even better shop nearby, for couples celebrating their 25th and 50th anniversaries. Sveta would love to get into that one, but admits with a laugh, ``Unfortunately, grandmothers and grandfathers won't run back and forth to the registration offices.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Vetoes Easing of Rules on Federal Workers Politicking
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said he must ensure the ``integrity of the civil service'' as he vetoed a bill relaxing 51-year-old curbs on the off-duty political activity of government workers. Two days after the Senate upheld his 11th veto, an authorization bill for Amtrak, Bush cast the 12th veto of his presidency. No Bush veto has yet been overturned. ``The Hatch Act has upheld the integrity of the civil service by assuring that federal employees are hired and promoted based upon their qualifications and not their political loyalties,'' he said Friday in a veto message to Congress. Robert Tobias, president of the National Treasury Employees Union, representing federal employees in 16 agencies and departments, called the veto ``wrongheaded'' and urged the Senate to override it. Tobias urged lawmakers to ``hold fast to their commitment to federal workers.'' He said in a statement, ``Senators must maintain their courageous support of reform and not trade their collective conscience for White House cuff links or breakfast with Bush.'' Republican leaders have said they expect to be able to sustain the veto, even though the bill passed by more than the two-thirds majorities that would be needed to override. The Hatch Act revision would affect 3 million federal employees and postal workers, who are now prohibited from participating in any form of political activity beyond voting. Sent to Bush by a 334-87 House vote on Wednesday, the bill would allow government employees to work in political campaigns on their own time, hold office in a political party and attend political conventions. However, the measure would leave intact prohibitions against running for partisan political office and soliciting money from the public. Sponsors said the measure would extend some of the same fundamental freedoms now enjoyed by most Americans to federal and postal workers. But Bush said he was opposed to any tinkering with the Hatch Act, passed in 1939 to prevent Depression-era government workers from being pressured to work for President Franklin D. Roosevelt's re-election effort. Bush said the easing would ``inevitably lead to re-politicizing'' the government bureaucracy. ``It has been manifestly successful over the years in shielding civil servants and the programs they administer from political exploitation and abuse,'' Bush wrote. ``We cannot afford, in the final decade of this century, to embark on a retreat into the very worst aspects of public administration from the last century,'' he said. The Senate passed the same bill last month by a vote of 67-30. That would be just enough for a veto override. But GOP Senate leaders have expressed confidence they can persuade one or two of their colleagues to change votes. In sending the bill back to Congress with a veto, Bush told lawmakers: ``As one who has devoted much of his life to public service, I take great pride in the integrity of our federal work force.''

DOC.HEAD: Pet Products Show Makes Fido a Team Player
DOC.TEXT: The pet product industry's annual trade show is not a place dogs would find rough, rough, rough. It's a world where dogs strut in T-shirts and neon sun visors, fish live in designer aquariums and birds eat from National Football League helmet feeders. The 485 booths at the American Pet Products Manufacturers Association show have such standard fare as pet foods, Kitty Litter and bird cages, but also offbeat items. There is a full line of NFL-licensed items that identify pets with their favorite team _ or at least the team of their owner. ``It's important to get kids and adults to think about their pets and bring them into the family, not just look at them as disposable things,'' said Karen Long MacLeod, editor of the trade publication Pet Age. ``Those products are designed to keep pets healthy and to have fun.'' Anne McDowell, senior licensing manager for NFL Properties Inc., said the idea for the NFL pet products came from a dinner party attended by a league official in Pittsburgh, where the hosts had knit a Steelers sweater for their dog. When the NFL decided to sanction pet products bearing team logos, Ms. McDowell said, ``We decided, don't do it piecemeal. Go all the way. Let's do everything.'' Animal T-shirts, sweaters, dinner bowls, beds, collars and bird feeders all bear NFL insignias. There's a variety pack of rawhide chews in the shapes of helmets, footballs, jerseys and pennants. The three-day show was ending today.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Robert Polhill, who had to treat his own diabetes as a hostage in Lebanon, and former Surgeon General C. Everett Koop were honored by the American Diabetes Association. Polhill, an American University professor whom Shiite Moslem kidnappers held 39 months, was presented Friday with an American Diabetes Association Honor recognizing his perseverance and heroism. He was diagnosed with cancer of the larynx after being freed in April and had his vocal cords removed. He stood by as his wife, Ferial, read his remarks to the ADA's national convention. ``If there is any achievement to be honored ... most of the credit must go to that remarkable piece of equipment called the human body, which with a little help from the human spirit, can adjust to and overcome even the most burdensome adversities,'' he said. Koop said people should learn to depend more on themselves, preventing disease through diet and exercise. The ADA's Koop Medal will be presented each year for contributions to public health.

Entertainer Cher returned to the Las Vegas stage after an eight-year absence, giving a pop-metal review to a sold-out crowd at a Strip resort. ``This is going to be a very strange show for a lot of you,'' she said early in her hourlong performance in the 1,500-seat showroom at the new Mirage Hotel and Casino. Cher opened the show wearing slacks, a blouse and a vest. She promised the crowd it would be the most attire she would wear the rest of the evening, and made good on the promise when she returned later in a black lace body suit. She will perform eight shows during a six-night engagement that began Thursday. Cher and her former husband, Sonny Bono, first appeared in Las Vegas in 1969, polishing an act they would take on television in 1971. The two played Las Vegas, apart and together, through 1982.

Singer Miriam Makeba wants to sing before her native South African people but says there's a question about whether that would amount to the long-exiled performer breaking a boycott. She indicated some disagreement with the African National Congress and others who advocate the boycott. ``I believe as a South African the cultural boycott does not apply to me,'' she said Friday. ``It would be a shame for me to die tomorrow before I come back to sing before you, because that is something I look forward to the most, to come back and sing before the South African people, where I do not have to translate my songs,'' she said. She left South Africa in 1959 at age 27 to make a movie musical and appear on television in the United States, but received a one-year contract to sing at the Village Vanguard in New York. When her mother died in 1960, the year the African National Congress was outlawed, Ms. Makeba was denied permission to return home and attend the funeral. After landing in Johannesburg on a flight from her home in Brussels, Belgium, last Sunday, Ms. Makeba went immediately to her mother's grave in Soweto. ``I tried to make a prayer. I just choked, and all I did was weep,'' she said at a news conference.

The name was familiar, but seemingly out of place in the sports section: a World Cup soccer column in the Los Angeles Times under the byline of Henry Kissinger. Actually, it wasn't the first time the former secretary of state had undertaken such an endeavor, and it won't be the last _ Kissinger and Times senior correspondent Anthony Day are teaming up on five World Cup columns during this year's competition in Italy. Last Sunday's column previewed the competition. The next column will appear June 24 and three will follow on consecutive Sundays. ``Henry and I are going to meet up in Italy on June 26 and stay there for the rest of the World Cup,'' Day said Friday. Day, 57, admitted he knows a lot less about soccer than the 67-year-old Kissinger, who's the vice chairman of the World Cup '94 Organizing Committee. The 1994 World Cup will be hosted by the United States. ``He's been a soccer fan since he was a boy in Germany,'' Day said.

Bob Hope told high school graduates to clean up the environmental mess their elders are leaving them. ``The specific challenge of your generation is to work creatively with the consequences our generation has passed on to yours,'' Hope told 500 graduates and 3,500 others at Palm Springs High School. Hope got an honorary degree Thursday and in return gave a few one-liners. ``Palm Springs High is some school,'' he quipped. ``The dress code here is swimsuit and thongs. And that's for the teachers. ``I know how you all must feel,'' Hope, 87, told the graduates. ``I remember how proud I was when the principal handed me my diploma. I dropped it. It was printed on a stone tablet.''
