DOC.HEAD: Bush Now Supports International Fund to Phase Out CFCs
DOC.TEXT: President Bush no longer opposes an international fund to help poor nations phase out ozone-depleting chemicals and is joining other world leaders in calling for such action, the White House says. The Bush administration is willing to contribute $25 million to a fund expected to total about $100 million over three years, said one administration official who spoke on condition of anonymity. No figures were officially released in Friday's announcement that the administration will push for a fund. In the policy reversal, the White House announced it will propose establishing a fund to help Third World countries at an international meeting next week in London. U.S. opposition to the fund had threatened to disrupt the conference, where participating nations will consider changes to strengthen the 1987 so-called Montreal Protocol to phase out chlorofluorocarbons, or CFCs, by the turn of the century. U.S. officials recognized that failing to help the developing nations _ particularly heavy CFC producers such as China and India _ would alienate them and keep them from signing the pending update of the Montreal Protocol, said the administration source. The White House announcement brought praise from Capitol Hill. The ranking Republican on the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee, Sen. John Chafee of Rhode Island, said it was ``tremendously good news'' coming as it does ``on the eve of the London meeting.'' A Democratic critic of Bush's environmental policies, Sen. Al Gore of Tennessee, said the decision was ``predictable because the original policy was completely out of touch with the reality.'' He said the United States was ``the last holdout'' among nations. ``Instead of providing leadership they try to block any progress, then begrudgingly admit the obvious,'' he said. Before Friday's announcement, the administration had maintained that any assistance to Third World nations for phasing out CFCs should come from existing World Bank resources and not new funds. But World Bank officials said it could not afford such a program. White House spokesman Steve Hart said a key to the policy change was that the administration's plan calls for a new fund, but within the existing World Bank structure, rather than setting up a completely new organization to administer the fund. Earlier this week, Mustafa K. Tolba of Egypt, head of the U.N. Environment Program, said U.S. opposition to the financial aid fund suggested by a number of European countries last month threatened to unravel the Montreal Protocol. The treaty calls for reducing CFC production by 50 percent by the end of the century. The pending amendments would call for complete phase-out by that time. CFCs, used widely as refrigerants and as aerosol propellants, are depleting the ozone layer, which protects the Earth from harmful levels of ultraviolet rays, scientists say. Hart said internal discussion among administration officials, with input from other governments, led to the switch in policy. ``We have found that we're at a point ... where we feel such a fund is warranted,'' he said. One country pressuring the United States to change its stance was Britain, said an administration source. Specifics of the plan, such as how the aid would be disseminated, were to be worked out in the London negotiations. U.S. officials are expected to push for a system under which the largest contributors would have the most say in where the money goes. A World Bank official hailed the White House announcement as ``the beginning of a chance for real dialogue'' on the CFC question. The White House statement was put out under the name of Chief of Staff John Sununu, who has been criticized by environmentalists for blocking other environmental initiatives. Activists have criticized the administration for what they call foot-dragging on eliminating CFCs.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Attempts to Ease U.S.-Israeli Dialogue
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney is attempting to ease the strain in U.S.-Israeli relations by promising that America will continue to support its ally's military edge in the volatile Middle East. But Cheney also cautioned that U.S.-supplied weaponry won't ensure Israel's security unless ``successful negotiations'' with Palestinians and Arab states take place. Cheney, speaking Friday before the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith in New York City, stressed America's commitment to peace in the Mideast as well as its ``solid and unalterable'' ties to Israel. The secretary also made a point of congratulating the new government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, saying the administration looks forward ``to working with him to secure a comprehensive peace between Israel and the Palestinians and between Israel and all of its Arab neighbors.'' The secretary's remarks were monitored by reporters in the Pentagon. Cheney made no direct mention of the sharp remarks exchanged in recent days between Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Shamir over Israel's commitment to the peace process. But he did note that all is not well between the two allies. ``The important thing in a good relationship is to remember that disagreements are not all there is,'' he said. Cheney said that while both nations have ``had our differences of opinion'' about how best to pursue the peace process, ``there is not an ally in the world with whom we have not had an occasional disagreement.'' Strategic cooperation between the two nations has ``become closer than ever'' and Israel is in line to receive 35 percent of the administration's fiscal 1991 budget request for security assistance, Cheney said. Israel is to begin taking delivery on its third order of F-16 fighter jets next year, will be getting its first delivery of Apache attack helicopters and is getting funds to upgrade its navy, the secretary added. Israel has received around $3.1 billion a year in a combination of military and economic aid from the United States. Cheney advised, however, that such aid is not the path to peace in the volatile Mideast. ``Israel must remain strong to secure that peace, but weapons and technology alone are not sufficient,'' Cheney said. ``Real security can only come through successful negotiations with Palestinians and Arab states that leads to a durable peace.'' Cheney also put in a plug for his defense budget request, saying that the U.S. commitment to Israel's security ``depends on our ability to project American power.'' Even though budgets are shrinking, the United States must continue to fund a highly trained, mobile and lethal fighting force to protect its interests around the world, he argued. ``Some people who like to portray themselves as great friends of Israel are also in the forefront of those who want to cut the heart out of the defense budget,'' Cheney said. ``I believe those two positions are fundamentally incompatible. We in the United States must not let ourselves become just another regional power. If we do, we _ and our friends, such as Israel _ may well suffer the consequences.'' Baker, testifying before a Senate committee on Wednesday, urged Israel's new right-wing government to move to restart the stalled peace process. He sarcastically recited the telephone number of the White House switchboard and said: ``When you're serious about peace, call us.'' In return, Shamir blamed U.S. criticism of Israel for stirring up growing Arab hostility toward the Jewish state. ``Aggressive intentions ... begin to surface in the Arab world as soon as they see cracks or breaches in the wall of friendship between Israel and the United States,'' Shamir said in an interview published Friday in the Jerusalem Post.

DOC.HEAD: 12-Year-Old Boys Accused of Attempted Bank Robbery
DOC.TEXT: A pair of 12-year-old boys weren't playing cops and robbers when they allegedly tried to hold up a credit union office by pretending to have a gun, police said. The pre-teens entered the Marathon-Republic Credit Union office Thursday and one told manager Judy Boles that he had a gun under his shirt, police investigator Leo Rodriguez said. ``He said, `Lady, I ain't playing with you. I have a gun, this is a robbery,''' Ms. Boles said. The boys ran off when Ms. Boles said she doubted that he had a gun. Police arrested the two 12-year-olds and a 9-year-old boy about 30 minutes later. The younger boy allegedly acted as lookout. The 9-year-old was released because he is too young to prosecute. The other boys were being held in a juvenile detention center. ``Both said they were only pretending they were going to hold up the place,'' Rodriguez said. ``They were taken seriously and now they're in serious trouble.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Administration to Withhold Aid to Romania
With PM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States will hold back any economic aid to Romania, where miners backing the government beat up journalists and raided the offices of opposition parties. The State Department, in a statement read by spokesman Richard Boucher, also said an envoy would go to Bucharest to express American concern to the Romanian government. The statement urged Romanian President-elect Ion Iliescu to ``clear all worker vigilantes from the streets and publicly pledge that they will not be encouraged or allowed to re-enter.'' ``The actions authorized by President Iliescu and his government in the past few days strike at the very heart of Romanian democracy,'' Boucher said. Miners poured into the Romanian capital on Thursday after Iliescu called for their help to put down what he called fascist forces demonstrating against his government. The miners beat pedestrians and journalists and raided the offices of opposition parties. The U.S. ambassador to Romania, Alan Green Jr., will be sent to Bucharest to ``convey to the Romanian leadership the seriousness of our concern,'' Boucher said. Green has been in Washington for consultations. Boucher said the United States would go ahead with $80 million in food aid and $1 million in medical aid that had already been announced. But Washington ``has decided to withhold all non-humanitarian support assistance that Romania might be eligible for,'' he said. The department said earlier that such assistance, of an unspecified nature, was under consideration. Such aid often takes the form of export credits and government loans. The spokesman said the aid would be withheld ``until the democratic process is restored'' in Romania. Iliescu ``should provide public guarantees of safety for leaders and members of all political parties and those who exercise their legitimate right of dissent and should reopen independent newspapers and magazines that were attacked on Thursday,'' Boucher said. ``We urge President Iliescu and his government to engage opposition parties and other groups in dialogue to repair the damage to Romanian democracy caused by events of the past few days,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Courtroom Ready to Show Videotape of Barry Sting
DOC.TEXT: Television monitors for viewing the videotaped sting operation against Marion Barry are ready to go and a defense lawyer says opening testimony in the mayor's cocaine and perjury trial will unfold as scheduled. R. Kenneth Mundy, Barry's attorney, discouraged suggestions Friday that plea bargaining talks might be rekindled. The jury will be seated Monday and ``there is nothing, absolutely nothing, that indicates otherwise,'' Mundy said. ``All next week the trial will proceed; bet on it, believe it and don't question it,'' Mundy added. Opening statements are scheduled for Tuesday. Brought into the courtroom during the noon hour Friday were television monitors and headphones so jurors may see and hear the results of the FBI's undercover sting at a downtown Washington hotel last Jan. 18. Barry was videotaped smoking crack cocaine, and the tape is the centerpiece of the prosecution's case. If the trial proceeds to a conclusion without any plea bargain, it is expected to last about a month. The U.S. attorney's office has not said when it plans to show the videotape. In regard to possible talks with the government, ``there is nothing going on, there is nothing planned to go on, there is nothing being considered, there is nothing being talked about,'' Mundy told reporters. ``Nobody is sitting by the phone waiting for a call,'' he said. ``Nobody is waiting to make a call to somebody else. All that is going to happen is the trial.'' Eighty-one people have been sent into a pool of prospective jurors in the last two weeks. Among the three people qualified Friday was Aurelia Corbett-King, who recently defended Barry's right to remain on the city Democratic Party's ballot. Party officials had encouraged Barry to take himself out of the race. She belongs to the local Democratic committee and her husband is a chauffeur to Walter Fauntroy, the non-voting D.C. delegate to Congress who is one of the candidates to succeed Barry as mayor. Barry announced Wednesday night he would not seek re-election. Barry has pleaded innocent to three felony counts of perjury, 10 misdemeanor counts of drug possession and one misdemeanor count of conspiracy. Preliminary plea bargain talks broke down over prosecutors' insistence that Barry plead guilty to a felony, while Barry insisted he would plead guilty only to a misdemeanor, sources close to the situation said.

DOC.HEAD: Adventure Tourism Booming from Himalayas to the Amazon
DOC.TEXT: Americans are vacationing from the Amazon to the Himalayas, fueling a phenomenon called ``adventure tourism'' that has unleashed protests over the footprints left behind. Adventure tourism accounts for 10 percent of the U.S. travel industry, or $1.3 billion a year, and no one knows how big it will grow. The debate is heating up over the impact of tourist intrusion on some of the most remote and ecologically fragile regions left in the world, including Antarctica and the Galapagos Islands. The expeditions are growing in popularity, particularly among older Americans with money to burn and a burning desire to visit the last frontier lands seen only by a lucky few in their youth. Proponents say the trips promote ``ambassadors for the Earth.'' Critics complain of litter, contact with remote tribes and disruption of breeding among protected wildlife. ``There's clearly a trend toward these type of expeditionary visits to remote places in the world,'' said Bruce Manheim, an environmentalist seeking tourist controls of one of the hottest travel destinations _ Antarctica. Travel agents and tour operators are targeting affluent and well-traveled Americans with an urgent message: ``Go now before environmental destruction of Earth's final frontiers is complete.'' ``If you don't go now you are going to miss it,'' said New York travel agent Chip Snyder, who specializes in customized tours. He urges tourists to visit such places as Brazil, Papua New Guinea and Indonesia. James Barnes, an environmentalist for Friends of the Earth, a Washington-based lobbying group, said adventure tourism has positive and negative consequences. ``On the one hand, it's always useful to have intelligent and outwardly looking people to look at places in need of protection and it helps to provide a constituency for protection,'' he said. ``But the scale of these activities is growing at such a pace that it does provide cause for concern to a lot of environmental groups.'' He pointed to the Galapagos, an equatorial island chain in the Pacific 620 miles off South America. Scientists warn of unchecked tourism endangering the ecosystem there. The desolate archipelago is invaded each year by thousands of tourists, and the scientists say some are disobeying rules, littering and disrupting wildlife. Ecuador, which annexed the islands in 1832, has considered stemming the influx by imposing stiff tariffs on foreign visitors. About 800 tourists visited the frozen continent of Antarctica in 1988 and nearly 3,000 in 1989, with more than 4,000 tourists expected in the upcoming December-to-February season. ``This may be just the tip of the iceberg,'' said Manheim, who has called for strict regulation of tourist activities near wildlife breeding sites and coordination of cruise ship visits to protected areas. Travel to the Himalayas also has risen. Sir Edmund Hillary, the 70-year-old New Zealand adventurer who pioneered the route up Mount Everest in 1953, complained last March of tourist development destroying the pristine innocence of the majestic mountains. ``The living standards are increasing, but the beautiful tracks and valleys have been littered,'' he said. In Brazil, tourism poses a different problem: encroachment on the jungle-dwelling tribes, Barnes said. But Richard Brill, general manager of Amazon Explorers in Parlin, N.J., said not all visitors to that region are insensitive. Brill has been leading travelers to the Amazon for three decades and said visitors come back committed to saving the rain forests. He said tours show tourists its destruction firsthand. ``I can show you scores of letters from people who have taken my voyages, who have become involved right away with the Earth,'' Brill said. ``You should see the letters to the governments to protect the jungles and to protect the Indians.''

DOC.HEAD: Group Wants Investigation of Minivans
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. says it has no reason to investigate complaints of sudden acceleration of its Aerostar minivans despite an accident that killed two people in Illinois. The Center for Auto Safety, a consumer watchdog group, demanded a government probe Friday in a letter to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. A spokesman said the request was being studied. The center has received nine reports that Aerostars accelerate suddenly after the gear is shifted from the ``park'' position, vehicle safety staffer Douglas Nelson said in the letter. A 57-year-old woman and a 17-month-old child died last Sunday after being hit by a 1990 Aerostar at a church picnic in Nokomis, Ill., Nelson said. Witnesses said the minivan's engine began racing as soon as it was started. The driver shifted to reverse but the vehicle lurched forward out of control, Nelson said. ``Ford has persistently claimed that events such as the one that occurred in Nokomis are impossible,'' he said, adding that the government ``hasn't pressed for the hard answers.'' Nelson said the traffic agency should send a team of investigators to examine the van and should open a probe of all 1986-90 Aerostars ``rather than sweep these tragic sudden acceleration deaths under the rug as it has done so many times in the past.'' Ford spokeswoman Anne Doyle-Farrell said the government had concluded a study last year that found no evidence of a mechanical defect causing sudden acceleration in Aerostars. The company does not believe another probe is justified, she said. ``We had a team of engineers in Nokomis yesterday cooperating with local authorities on inspecting the vehicle,'' she said. ``The vehicle passed just fine. There was no mechanical problem at all with the vehicle that was related to the accident.'' Ford has no explanation for the cause of the tragedy, Ms. Doyle-Farrell said. ``We certainly feel very sorry about what happened,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Estrogen Replacement Also Seems to Protect Heart, Committee Says
DOC.TEXT: An estrogen replacement drug taken by women who have had hysterectomies may also protect against heart disease, a government committee says. There is enough evidence to conclude the drug Premarin lowered the risk of heart disease in post-menopausal women who have had their uteri and ovaries removed, the Food and Drug Administration's Fertility and Maternal Health Drugs Advisory Committee said Friday. But representatives of the National Women's Health Network opposed the finding and issued a statement saying that greater use of Premarin would be ``alarming'' until more is known about the long-term effects of the drug, something the committee said should be studied. The FDA considers recommendations by advisory committees in establishing the approved uses for a drug. Once the agency has established any approved use, physicians are free to prescribe the drug for any other use. Premarin, manufactured by Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories, is an artificial form of estrogen. It is now approved for treatment of menopause symptoms and to help in the prevention of osteoporosis, a thinning of bones that often occurs among women after menopause. Nine members of the panel voted for the conclusion and a tenth member abstained, according to FDA spokeswoman Susan Cruzan. The studies evaluated by the advisory committee suggested that the drug also reduces the risk of coronary heart disease by as much as 50 percent among post-menopausal women or among women who have had hysterectomies. Estrogen is one of the hormones that regulate development of the secondary sex characteristics. The body produces it naturally during a woman's childbearing years. Cruzan said the committee also concluded that the studies showed that the health benefits from the estrogen replacement drug outweigh the risk from side effects, providing women taking the drug don't have other indications for caution such as smoking, a family history of breast cancer, or a personal history of gall bladder disease or a blood clotting disorder. ``It is alarming to think that millions of women may be given this drug before either its dangers or benefits are understood,'' said David Birnbaum of the National Women's Health Network. Premarin is designed to restore the hormone after age, surgery or disease ends its natural production.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Donates 25,000 Tons of Corn to Honduras
DOC.TEXT: Honduras is getting 25,000 metric tons of surplus corn from the United States as part of an expanded food-aid package. F. Paul Dickerson, general sales manager of the Agriculture Department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said Friday the corn's value is $2.2 million. The grain will be sold by the Honduran government to the private sector to help meet food and industrial needs. What the government earns from the sales then is supposed to be used to get food to needy families and to help farmers in projects to increase production and marketing. The corn donation boosts Honduran food aid to $3.4 million from an initial $1.2 million announced on March 9, Dickerson said.

For the third time this month, Oliver North has been called before a federal grand jury investigating the Iran-Contra scandal. The former White House aide spent several hours before the panel, leaving the grand jury room several times to confer with attorneys. At the end he declined to comment to reporters. The grand jury is looking into Iran-contra as part of the 4{-year-old criminal investigation by independent counsel Lawrence Walsh. Iran-Contra prosecutor Craig Gillen was seen entering the room where the grand jury is meeting at the U.S. Courthouse. As part of the latest phase in its investigation, Walsh's office is trying to determine the precise roles that President Reagan, then-Vice President George Bush and other administration figures played in the affair. Mary Belcher, a spokeswoman for Walsh's office, declined all comment.
DOC.HEAD: Kansas Firm Wins Permit for Iowa Tests
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department has cleared the way for the first field trials in the United States of genetically engineered corn. The permit clears the way for BioTechnica Agriculture Inc. of Overland Park, Kan., to begin its tests this month in Lisbon, Iowa, the department said Friday. James W. Glosser, administrator of the department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, said the tests will continue through the summer. He said the company's procedures were designed carefully so as not to disturb the environment. The corn being tested differs from standard seed only in that it contains genetic marker genes. These will allow scientists to map more exactly the locations on chromosomes of genes that determine the corn's characteristics, including yield and resistance to diseases. Once the genes are located, researchers can manipulate and eventually introduce them into new corn varieties and other crops as well. Biotechnica scientists already have examined the experimental corn plants in the greenhouse and want to repeat the studies under field conditions, Glosser said. The corn project follows announcement earlier this week of similar field trials for soybeans and rice.

DOC.HEAD: Germanys Agree On Settling of Property Disputes
DOC.TEXT: Under an agreement between the two Germanys, East Germany has agreed to return property confiscated by the former Communist government or pay compensation to the original owners. The property issue has been one of the most contentious as the two Germanys move toward merging their economies. Former owners of property in the East who fled to the West immediately after the war _ or after Communist East Germany was founded in 1949 _ have been returning to stake claim on property they contend is still theirs. Also Friday, West Germany's unification committee, comprised of representatives of all parties in Parliament, agreed on a treaty that paves the way for economic unity July 2. Parliamentary ratification of the agreement was expected late next week. The property agreement was the result of weeks of negotiations between the German governments. It was outlined in a four-page statement read at a news conference by Rudolf Seiters, chief of staff for Chancellor Helmut Kohl. The agreement was part of overall accord on upcoming monetary and economic unification. Representatives from the West and East had been meeting to iron out that and other issues. The statement said the rights of East German renters living in disputed apartments or on disputed property would be protected, according to East German law. For East Germans who bought appropriated land, or who own buildings which were erected on confiscated property, a ``socially acceptable compensation'' was to be worked out either through exchange of property of similar value or other unspecified compensation, it said. The accord, however, does not apply to property confiscated during the 1945-1949 Soviet postwar administration of the territory that later became East Germany, Seiters said. He said the Soviets and East Germans balked at that idea. It was not immediately clear how much of the property in question was taken during the four years after the war, and officials could not be reached for comment Friday night. Seiters said it would be up to a future joint German Parliament to make a final decision on any governmental compensation for property seized in the four years after the war. The agreement for the return of private assets confiscated by the East German government applies to Germans who fled East Germany from 1949 on and will also extend to nationalized companies. The statement said either the entire company would be returned to the original owner or some form of compensation would be made. Seiters said the East German government was working on a program to outline the time frame in which applications for return of property or compensation could be submitted, and that experts from both countries would continue working out the details of the compensation program. The East German government will establish a separate fund to take care of compensation payments, he said. West German Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann said the Staatsvertrag, or state treaty, that won final committee approval late Friday holds some some economic risks for East Germany, but there was no reason for ``exaggerated pessimism.'' ``Naturally, after 40 years of planned economy, there will be painful cuts. Of course, some companies will have to close down,'' Haussmann said. Some experts have said up to 2 million East Germans could lose their jobs as antiquated factories go bust, and there is speculation that public unrest in East Germany could follow.

DOC.HEAD: Coal Miners Threaten Nationwide Strike If Ryzhkov Does Not Resign
DOC.TEXT: In a stern rejection of the Communist Party leadership, coal miners from across the country have threatened a strike next month if the government of Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov does not resign. The miners, closing a five-day congress Friday, also demanded that the party relinquish control over the government and state enterprises, and give up its vast inventory of property. The miners earlier announced plans to create a new labor union independent of the party and the government. The actions marked the first time a national organization with such massive support has challenged Communist Party authority so decisively. Bulat Mukazhanov, chairman of the First Congress of Soviet Miners and a representative of miners from Karaganda in Kazakhstan, said it was not clear how many of the nation's 1 million coal miners would heed the strike call, set for July 11. ``It would be a political strike,'' Mukazhanov said. The moves at the congress intensified the political crisis facing Soviet President and Communist Party leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who is already dealing with secessionist republics, ethnic violence and a crumbling economy. Gorbachev could be the first Soviet leader since Vladimir Lenin to face an independent, nationally organized labor union. The miners did not directly challenge Gorbachev, and their position left him a way to steer the party toward more radical reform and force the resignation of Ryzhkov, who has been left to bear responsibility for unpopular economic policies. The miners' resolution called for the resignation of the ``government,'' a reference to Ryzhkov and his Cabinet. Gorbachev is at the beginning of a five-year term, but the prime minister can be replaced by parliament at any time. Political strikes were outlawed last year, but the Soviet government has been unable to enforce the ban. Economic strikes are legal only after a period of negotiations. Last summer, about 500,000 miners walked out in the Soviet Union's first nationwide strike, paralyzing heavy industry and raising fears of whole cities freezing. But the winter was warm. Angered by the government's failure to fulfill promises it made to end that strike, the miners formed a committee to draft bylaws for a new union independent of the Communist Party and the government. The union is to be founded at a second meeting, scheduled for Aug. 15-16 in Moscow. The current congress, which included delegates from all 712 coal mines in the country, suggested nationalizing the Communist Party's huge holdings, which include buildings, publishing houses and newspapers, automobiles and bank accounts. ``The Communist Party of the Soviet Union claims that it is the party of the working class, its vanguard. We are workers, but we do not regard the party in its present form as our party,'' read a resolution. The resolution was passed by a vote of 308-116 at the conclusion of the congress in Donetsk, the center of the largest Soviet coal region. ``We demand that the Communist Party be deprived immediately of its privileged position in our enterprises,'' it said. The miners said in a separate resolution that they supported a more rapid transition to a market economy than proposed by Ryzhkov, even though it might mean that some unprofitable mines would be closed and miners thrown out of work. Ryzhkov's plan, presented to the Supreme Soviet legislature last month and defended by Gorbachev on national television, called for the price of bread to triple on July 1, and the price of most other food to double at the beginning of next year. The legislature has delayed the unpopular bread increase for at least two months. It has told the government to come back in the fall with more detailed plans for economic reform.

DOC.HEAD: Tailgating Truck Driver Attacked by Couple with Swords
DOC.TEXT: Ride somebody's tail on the highway in some states and they might take a pot shot at you. In Massachusetts they might draw swords. A couple who apparently thought a big-rig truck was following too closely stopped the car and assaulted the truck driver with antique swords, state Trooper Stephen Earle said Friday. ``Never a dull moment,'' said Earle of the Wednesday altercation on Route 3 in Duxbury. ``I've seen fistfights, and of course you always hear about people pulling guns, but this is the first time I've ever had anyone pull a sword.'' No one was injured. The truck driver used a long metal hook to defend himself, Earle said. ``I tell you he was a little astounded,'' Earle said. Robert M. Nightingale, 29, of Quincy, and Edith Kigsbury, 24, of Marshfield, pleaded innocent Thursday in Plymouth District Court to charges including assault and battery with a dangerous weapon. Nightingale apparently kept one sword in the car's back seat and one in the trunk, Earle said. Massachusetts law forbids Nightingale from carrying a firearm because he is a convicted felon, Earle said. ``This may have been his remedy to that situation,'' Earle said. Nightingale posted bail, which was set at $2,500. The woman was released without bail. A pre-trial hearing was scheduled for June 20.

DOC.HEAD: Supertanker Fire Extinguished, Bacteria Unleashed on Spill
LaserPhotos HT1, HT2, XGAL1
DOC.TEXT: The blaze aboard the leaking Mega Borg has been extinguished and firefighters doused the sizzling supertanker today to avoid a flare-up. The fire was put out Friday, but Coast Guard and state officials warned that the Norwegian ship crippled in an explosion June 8 still posed a threat. ``There are no flames. However it's still real hot and if we walk away from it right now, it may reflash. It's not yet dead,'' Coast Guard Chief Petty Officer Todd Nelson said. The accident left 4.3 million gallons of light African crude in the Gulf of Mexico _ the fifth worst spill in U.S. history. Tar balls from a 10-mile long slick were expected Sunday on the Bolivar Peninsula, about 40 miles east of Galveston. Tar balls from the spill had been expected to hit shore Friday, but Jerry Galt of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration in Houston said changing currents and atmospheric conditions delayed their arrival. Scientists on Friday unleashed experimental oil-eating bacteria on a patch of the slick and awaited results of the procedure, called bioremediation. Salvage crews today hoped to transfer oil remaining in a ruptured 5.5 million tank to an undamaged tank to stop a continuing leak and to balance the 886-foot ship. The supertanker was loaded with 38 million gallons of oil. An official from Det Norske Veritas, Norway's equivalent to the American Bureau of Shipping, was expected to board the Mega Borg to inspect damage over the weekend. The ship, with its rear section awash and seared by fiery explosions, was clear of smoke for the first time Friday. ``I feel like I am face to face with my enemy,'' said Texas Water Commission Chairman B.J. ``Buck'' Wynne, looking at the listing hulk from a Coast Guard boat about 100 yards away. ``For the first time since this thing began, I'm beginning to believe we can beat it. But I know there is going to be a next time,'' Wynne said. More than two dozen boats were expected to continue skimming spilled oil today. Salvage crews said they have collected 146,389 gallons of oil. The Coast Guard said Friday most of the light crude that spilled either evaporated or burned and less than 22,000 gallons remained in the water. Carl Oppenheimer, a scientist who developed bioremediation and was eager to see it tested for the first time on oil in open seas, joined officials unleashing trillions of oil-eating microbes on the rust-colored slick. They sprayed the bacteria mixture on an acre of oil about three miles southeast of the Mega Borg. The bacteria will break the oil down into harmless fatty acids that will be consumed by marine life, said Oppenheimer, a University of Texas microbiologist who has been working on the process for 15 years. Oppenheimer predicted the acre would be clear of oil in one or two days. ``This is breakthrough technology,'' Texas Land Commissioner Garry Mauro said. Investigators have not determined the cause of the fire that killed two of the ship's 41 crew members, injured 17 and left two missing and presumed dead. A panel convened by Norwegian consul general Erik Leikvang concluded a three-day hearing Friday. At the hearing, officials asked third mate Jaipal Singh Mahlawat to elaborate on a fuel leak discovered in the ship's pump room six hours before the explosion. ``I saw the pump man, he was screwing a coupling back to stop the oil from leaking,'' Mahlawat said. ``No oil was leaking. He had already wiped it out.'' The pump man, Putham Mahamood, testified Thursday through a translator that he performed ``no measurable repair work'' the day of the explosion. The Mega Borg's chief engineer told the panel Thursday one of the vessel's pumps was leaking fuel about six hours before the explosion, and a Norwegian shipping inspector said some other pumps were overdue for an inspection. Coast Guard investigator Ruben Arredondo, who sat in on testimony but was not a member of the panel, said the oil leak may have provided the fuel source for a fire sparked by something such as a bad light fixture. The panel will send its report to the Norwegian maritime investigative bureau, which will determine if the ship is seaworthy and if there is any criminal liability.

DOC.HEAD: List of Worst U.S. Oil Spills
With PM-Tanker Blast, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of 10 of the worst oil spills in U.S. history:

1. March 24, 1989, Exxon Valdez, Prince William Sound, Alaska, 10.92 million gallons of crude spilled when the ship ran aground. 2. Nov. 1, 1979, Burmah Agate tanker, Galveston Bay, Texas, up to 10.7 million gallons of oil burned or spilled when two ships collided. 3. Dec. 15, 1976, Argo Merchant tanker, Massachusetts' southeastern coast, 7.6 million gallons of crude spilled when the ship ran aground. 4. Nov. 6, 1985, exploratory well, Ranger, Texas, 6.3 million gallons of oil spilled after a blowout. 5. June 8, 1990, Norwegian supertanker Mega Borg, 4.3 million gallons of light crude spilled in the Gulf of Mexico after an explosion. 6. Jan. 2, 1988, Ashland Oil Co., above-ground storage tank, Jefferson Borough, Pa., 3.8 million gallons of oil spilled when a tank ruptured. 7. July 30, 1984, Alvenus tanker, Cameron, La., 2.8 million gallons of oil spilled after a ship ran aground. 8. Oct. 31, 1984, Puerto Rican tanker, San Francisco, 2 million gallons of oil spilled when a ship caught fire following an explosion. 9. Aug. 18, 1984, Triangle Oil Corp., above-ground storage tank, Jacksonville, Fla., 2.5 million gallons of oil burned after lightning sparked a fire. 10. Nov. 22, 1980, Georgia tanker, Pilottown, La., 1.3 million gallons of oil spilled after an anchor chain caused a ship to leak.

DOC.HEAD: Facts on Bacteria Microbes to Be Used on Oil Slick
With PM-Tanker Blast, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are the key facts about bioremediation, an experimental plan to dump oil-eating bacteria on the Mega Borg oil slick in the Gulf of Mexico off Galveston, Texas: DESCRIPTION: Bioremediation uses naturally occurring bacteria microbes, which have a sandlike consistency, to reduce oil to an emulsion of fatty acids. The emulsion sinks and is consumed by marine life. Microbes die when they cannot find any more oil to eat. USES: The microbes have been used for years to clean up hazardous waste sites, treat sewage and wastewaters, and extract oil from tight geologic formations. They were used to clean some rocks on shore after the Exxon Valdez accident last year in Alaska. Their use off Texas was the first time bioremediation has been used in the water to clean up an oil spill. PLAN: State officials mixed the bacteria in 100-gallon tanks of salt water and shot it through hoses from a Coast Guard cutter. AMOUNT: Officials planned to use 100 pounds of the bacteria each day for three to four days on freshly spilled oil near the vessel. COST: The test will cost the state about $50,000.

DOC.HEAD: Knighthoods for Peter Ustinov and Kingsley Amis
DOC.TEXT: Actor-author Peter Ustinov and writer Kingsley Amis became the newest knights of the realm today in the birthday honors list of Queen Elizabeth II. Ustinov, the 69-year-old actor, author, dramatist, film director, newspaper columnist and raconteur, was named a Knight Bachelor. So was Amis, 67, author of ``The Old Devils,'' ``Lucky Jim'' and most recently, ``The Folks That Live on The Hill.'' Ustinov, who was made a CBE, or Companion of British Empire in 1975, was asked how he felt about being knighted. ``I cannot see it making any difference. I shall go on working. It's like another flag on Everest,'' Ustinov said. ``My reaction is one of unqualified delight,'' Amis said. ``It is wonderful news.'' The honors, and others to writer Anita Brookner, historian Martin Gilbert and fashion designer Bruce Oldfield, were actually chosen by the government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. The government rewards the loyalty and service of hundreds of people twice each year _ at the New Year and in June, in honor of the monarch's official birthday. Queen Elizabeth was born April 21, 1926, but her official birthday is marked on a day in June when there is a marginally better chance of sunny weather for parades and celebrations. The honors list showered medals and awards on hundreds of other Britons, some of whom made their mark in obscure professions. The Most Rev. Robert Runcie receives a peerage that will enable him to sit in the House of Lords as Baron Runcie following his retirement as Anglican archbishop of Canterbury next year. Dame Lydia Dunn, a senior Hong Kong legislator who has become a well-known figure in the preparations for China's takeover of the British colony in 1997, becomes a baroness. Ms. Brookner, who won the prestigious Booker Prize in 1984 for her novel, ``Hotel du Lac,'' was made a CBE. The same honor went to actress Eileen Atkins, an actress and co-creator of the television series ``Upstairs, Downstairs.'' Oldfield, 39, reared in a Yorkshire children's home, became a favorite fashion designer of the Princess of Wales. He was made an OBE, or Officer of the Order of British Empire. Tracy Edwards, 27, whose all-woman crew placed second in their class in the Whitbread around-the-word yacht race, became an MBE, or Member of the Order of British Empire. Tucked away in the shadow of these luminaries, among the head librarians, tax inspectors and civil service secretaries, are professions less glamorous than drama and fashion. British Empire Medals went to Herbert Plenty, cheese-grader for the Milk Marketing Board, and Florence Clary, the keykeeper of Mistley Towers, Essex. The honors bear nothing except a medal and the right to put letters such as OBE and MBE after a name, but they are a matter of great pride to recipients.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Claims Responsibility for Bombings
DOC.TEXT: The Irish Republican Army has claimed responsibility for two bombings that did extensive damage this week to the mansion of a Conservative Party official and an army training center in West Germany. No one was hurt in either blast. The explosion at the army diving school in Hamelin Thursday ripped apart the building, which was empty at the time but is used regularly by British, Dutch and West German troops. The bombing of the 18th century mansion, West Green House, in the southern English village of Hartley Wintney, blew out windows and part of the front of the red brick home on Tuesday. The house had been occupied until three weeks ago by Lord McAlpine, a former deputy chairman and treasurer of the Conservative Party. The explosion tore a three-foot hole in the front of the restored mansion, demolished part of a garden wall and left a crater in the gravel drive. The British news agency Press Association said the IRA claimed the bombings in a statement issued in Dublin. The outlawed IRA, in a new and bloody offensive aimed mainly at British targets outside Northern Ireland, has killed seven people in the past few weeks and mounted half a dozen attacks in England. The mainly Roman Catholic organization is waging a violent campaign to end British rule in the predominantly Protestant province of Northern Ireland and unite it with the republic of Ireland.

DOC.HEAD: Homes Swept Away, Muddy Streams Remain After Flash Flood
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Gilg is cq in 16th graf, `At least ...'.
DOC.TEXT: Cement blocks were all that remained of homes, fallen branches stood where trees used to be and muddy streams meandered through the outskirts of this Ohio River town after a furious flash flood. Residents donned shorts and hip-waders Friday to begin putting their lives back together after 5{ inches of rain fell in 3{ hours late Thursday, churning floodwaters that left at least 11 people dead and 51 others missing early today. The shock had not worn off, said police officer Bruce Fink, whose bristly face bore signs of more than 20 hours on duty, including work at a temporary morgue set up at a funeral home. ``We have counselors back there now, but we've lost whole families. It's just been devastating,'' he said Friday night. Fink said he feared there wouldn't be enough funeral homes to handle the dead in this eastern Ohio town of 4,300 people. Allan Hans called the flooding ``the devil's work.'' ``I lost everything but my car and the clothes I'm wearing,'' he said. Hans said he was sitting in his trailer when he heard a branch crack and went to check out the noise. He saw rushing water, ran to tell neighbors and moved his car. The trailer was swept away by the time he returned home. John and Sue Wright, whose home rests on the banks of Pipe Creek, estimated they lost about $20,000 worth of property. ``I was one of the lucky ones. What I lost, I can replace,'' Wright said. Although it was the center of rescue operations, downtown Shadyside suffered no apparent flood damage. But it was a different story on the outskirts of town, in the heart of Ohio's richest coal fields. Cars were mired roof-deep in mud, and guardrails and chunks of concrete were torn from roads. A 20-foot, 18-inch thick beam that held a sign leading to 3K's Bar near Pipe Creek was twisted like a pretzel by the force of what witnesses described as a wall of water. People moved rubble and made makeshift repairs to bridges that span McMann Creek, which links homes to Ohio Route 147. Many bridges were washed away. Small tractors and four-wheel-drive vehicles were the only means of transportation in much of the stricken area. At least 170 members of the Ohio National Guard were called in to patrol and to help rebuild flood-swept roads, said Stacie Gilg, a spokeswoman for the Ohio Emergency Management Agency. Disasters always bring out the curious, and this was no exception. By Friday night, traffic jammed Ohio Route 7, which skirts the Ohio River and is the main north-south road through town. Belmont County Sheriff Tom McCort said he suspected many of the vehicles belonged to sightseers. McCort said there were no serious attempts at looting. He said he was pleased with the assistance of young people. One young man turned in a strongbox filled with valuable coins lost in the flood, the sheriff said. ``The kid ... handed me this box and it was unlocked,'' McCort said. ``It really made me feel good.''

DOC.HEAD: `Dick Tracy' Gets Positive Reviews
DOC.TEXT: ``Dick Tracy,'' facing stiff competition this weekend at the box office, got mostly rave reviews from critics. The Walt Disney Co. production could generate box-office receipts of $30 million from its debut on about 2,200 screens nationwide this weekend. An entertainment industry analyst, Jeffrey Logsdon of Crowell Weedon & Co., said the film might bring in up to $7 million more from special early screenings starting at midnight Thursday. On Friday, Disney stocks were up $2.75 to $131.75 in trading on the New York Stock Exchange as doubts about the success of the $35 million production faded. ``There were some concerns that `Dick Tracy' would be a flop ... but it's a commercially viable product,'' Logsdon said. He said the stock's rise was due to the realization that Disney continues to surprise its doubters. Critic Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times on Friday that the film directed by and starring Warren Beatty, ``is a great uninterrupted grin ... a movie that finds funniness in the most unexpected places and characters.'' Sheila Benson of the Los Angeles Times called it ``a film of enormous style, with a sure sense of itself.'' Associated Press critic Bob Thomas said the film ``is distinguished by its originality.'' Two of the few negative reviews of the film appeared in The Wall Street Journal and the trade newspaper Daily Variety. The film also stars Madonna, Al Pacino and Dustin Hoffman. The film's immediate competition will be ``Gremlins 2: The New Batch,'' Arnold Schwarzenegger's ``Total Recall'' and Eddie Murphy's ``Another 48 HRS.'' The original ``Gremlins,'' released in 1984, produced worldwide revenues of $200 million. Almost a year ago, Warner Bros. opened ``Batman'' to record business of $40.5 million in one weekend. ``Batman'' went on to gross more than $250 million domestically. ``There's a big question as to how (this weekend) is going to come out,'' said John Krier, president of Exhibitor Relations Co., which studies box-office figures. ``It's going to be an interesting contest.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Agrees to Help Film Industry
DOC.TEXT: The government has decided to inject $8.5 million into Britain's foundering film industry in an effort to turn around seven years of hard times. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told a meeting of film industry representatives Friday that the money will be used over the next three years to help British filmmakers seeking co-productions elsewhere in Europe. Theater attendance soared last year in Britain, but British film production reached its lowest level since 1981. Britain made only 25 films last year, Mrs. Thatcher said. Some production companies have gone bust. The best known is Goldcrest films, which helped bring ``Chariots of Fire,'' ``Gandhi'' and ``The Killing Fields'' to the screen. The independent company's work between 1977 and 1986 received dozens of awards, including 19 Oscars, but it collapsed after a series of flops. The lag followed a boom in the early 1980s, when the industry seemed reborn. When ``Chariots'' scriptwriter Colin Welland accepted the 1982 Academy Award for best film, he declared triumphantly, ``The British are coming!'' British films have not benefited from the government support given the industry in countries like Australia and France. ``The British film industry has a proud record of excellence. But film production in this country has been on the decline,'' Mrs. Thatcher said. ``This is an industry in which Britain cannot just compete _ we can excel.'' The meeting was attended by Sir Richard Attenborough, the director of ``Gandhi,'' and David Puttnam, who produced ``Chariots of Fire.'' ``I am hugely encouraged,'' Puttnam said. ``All we have asked for over a long period of time is a hearing, and that is what we have had.'' He called the $8.5 million ``a goodwill gesture.'' ``What is more important over the long term is the formation of the working parties,'' he said. The committees are to look into setting up government incentives to attract private money. Mrs. Thatcher also said the industry will study taxes on film production and report back to the government. In addition, the government will provide an additional $263,500 to support the 1990 European Film Awards in Glasgow, Scotland. The film industry representatives said their main concern was the lack of British investment in its own film industry. They said money was available from the United States, but any profits go right back across the Atlantic.

DOC.HEAD: Draft EPA Report Says Second-Hand Smoke Kills 32,000 Americans
DOC.TEXT: The Tobacco Institute and a congressman are pressing the Environmental Protection Agency to withdraw or revise a draft report that incorporates the finding that second-hand tobacco smoke causes 32,000 heart disease deaths among non-smokers. The finding has been incorporated into an EPA ``technical compendium'' of the latest research on passive smoking, sometimes referred to as ``environmental tobacco smoke,'' or ETS. The report has not yet been released. Documents with information on its contents were obtained by The Associated Press from the Tobacco Institute and from the office of Rep. Thomas Bliley of Richmond, Va. ``It would ... in my judgment be most inappropriate to include this paper in its present form in the EPA ETS Compendium of Technical Information,'' wrote W. Gary Flamm, a Tobacco Institue consultant, in summarizing the six-inch high stack of comments that the Tobacco Institute sent to the EPA. The chapter was written by Stanton Glantz and William Parmley, both professors in the department of medicine at the University of California, San Francisco. Parmley is a past president of the American College of Cardiology. Elissa Feldman in the EPA's indoor air division said the technical compendium is still undergoing revision, and that it probably would not be released until later this summer. Glantz presented many of the chapter's findings on May 21 at a scientific conference in Boston, but he did not disclose that they were included in the EPA's passive smoking report. Robert Axelrad, director of the EPA's indoor air division, said Glantz had been given permission to discuss his findings as long as he did not mention his connection with the EPA. He noted that the technical compendium was not a determination by the EPA of the risks associated with passive smoking, but a collection of state-of-the-art summaries of research on passive smoking. ``It will contain disclaimers that the views of the individual authors do not represent the views of the EPA,'' he said. The link between the EPA document and Glantz's presentation in Boston came in a June 6 letter to EPA Administrator William Reilly, in which Bliley said that Glantz's presentation in Boston was based on the EPA report. Bliley has had a long interest in tobacco issues. Philip Morris is the largest private employer in his congressional district. The chapter concludes that passive smoking causes 32,000 heart disease deaths each year and a total of 50,000 deaths each year, when heart disease and cancers are combined. That makes passive smoking the third leading cause of preventable death, behind smoking and alcohol, the report concludes. The study, based on a review of existing scientific studies, also concludes that passive smoking increases a non-smoker's chance of dying from heart disease by 20 percent to 30 percent. Glantz said he could not discuss the details of the criticisms from the Tobacco Institute and Bliley until the EPA report is released. He did make several general comments, however. ``All of the people who have reviewed this material, both within the EPA and as it was submitted to the scientific peer review process, have been favorable _ except the Tobacco Institute,'' he said. The comments from the Tobacco Institute and Bliley's letter both include a strongly worded personal attack on Glantz, using similar language. They accused him of being an anti-smoking advocate whose political activity compromises the integrity of his scientific work. ``The fact that they're conducting an ad-hominem attack on me shows that they can't find anything wrong with our work,'' Glantz said.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Awards Nearly $7.6 Million to Widow of Prison Author's Victim
DOC.TEXT: Jack Henry Abbott, whose prison writings became a best-selling book, lost a nearly $7.6 million court judgment to the widow of an aspiring actor he killed. A jury awarded the money Friday to Ricci Adan, whose 22-year-old husband, Richard, was stabbed in the heart outside a Manhattan restaurant where he worked as a waiter in 1981. Abbott, whose writings were brought to public attention by Norman Mailer, is serving a 15-year-to-life sentence for first-degree manslaughter in the slaying. Mrs. Adan, 32, and her family sat quietly as the court clerk polled the jury at Abbott's request. Leaving the courtroom, they whooped, shouted and hugged in celebration of the verdict after a two-week civil trial on Mrs. Adan's wrongful death lawsuit against Abbott. Abbott, who acted as his own attorney, said to the judge, ``This is a little excessive, your honor, wouldn't you say?'' The judge, Carol Arber, advised Abbott he could appeal, but he did not say whether he would. ``It's been a nightmare,'' said Mrs. Adan, who had to be cross-examined by her husband's killer. She said of her slain husband: ``He's not just a speck of dust anymore. He's not just a victim, or a piece of paper; he's a human being. And he can rest now.'' Adan died July 18, 1981, just six weeks after Abbott paroled on earlier convictions. Naomi Zack, the State University of New York philosophy instructor Abbott married last September while in prison, was not in court for the verdict. She had been present almost every day at the trial and was the only witness Abbott called. Abbott tried to convince the jury that Adan endured no pain and suffering because the single knife thrust through the heart killed him instantly. ``I'm no savage,'' Abbott said. In a savage and ``atrocious'' murder, the killer tries to inflict maximum damage on his victim, Abbott said. Mrs. Adan was in tears at Abbott's descriptions of the killing. Abbott, 46, sneered at a Pace University economist's projections that Adan might have earned $17 million as a successful actor by the time he was 65. Abbott said the calculation assumed Adan ``would have been a movie star of the caliber of Paul Newman.' Abbott gained fame from writing ``In the Belly of the Beast,'' a best-seller composed of letters he wrote to Mailer from prison between 1978 and 1981. During those years, Abbott was behind bars first for bank robbery and then for fatally stabbing another inmate. Mailer later supported Abbott's parole, largely because of his writing talent. Mailer, who attended Abbott's criminal trial, was absent from the latest one. Mailer has been unavailable for comment on Abbott's latest court drama. Mrs. Adan's lawyers estimate that Abbott has a little more than $100,000 in escrow held by the Manhattan sheriff in case of a civil judgment in Mrs. Adan's favor. Practically all of that money comes from ``In the Belly of the Beast.'' Abbott also has $15,000, also earned from his writings, held by the state Crime Victims Board. The jury awarded Mrs. Adan $5.575 million in compensatory damages for lost income and $2 million for her husband's pain and suffering before his death.

DOC.HEAD: Japan and U.S. Must Put in Strong Efforts for Trade Agreement, Baker Says
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III met with his Japanese counterpart and said afterward it will take a ``strong effort'' from both countries to reach a final trade agreement by the end of the month. The United States and Japan are rushing to draw up a final agreement aimed at correcting a trade imbalance between the countries in time for next month's seven-nation economic summit in Houston. ``Our two nations, the two largest economies in the world, have an obligation to offer constructive international leadership,'' Baker said in a statement after the 3{-hour meeting at the Fairmont Hotel. ``We believe we can do so as global partners.'' Foreign Minister Tara Nakayama told Baker that Japan was ``making efforts'' to correct the trade imbalance between the nations, a Japanese government spokesman told reporters. Less than two weeks remain before Japan and the United States are scheduled to wrap up trade talks and draw up a formal list of economic reforms. Friday's discussion reportedly was called so the officials could attempt to revive the talks, which have become stalled in recent months. Nakayama ``made it clear that the Japanese government is making efforts to reduce its current trade surplus,'' Makoto Yamanaka, a spokesman for the Japanese foreign minister, told reporters. Yamanaka stopped short of saying that Friday's discussion had revived the stalled talks, known as the Structural Impediment Initiative, saying only that progress was ``important'' to both governments. The spokesman declined to discuss the specifics of the meeting of Baker and Nakayama, but he said the two talked about Eastern Europe, China and Mongolia as well as the trade imbalance. Baker said it would take a ``good strong effort on both sides'' to come up with a final agreement. One point of contention is that the Bush administration has called for Japan to spend at least 9 percent of its gross national product on government construction projects. Yamanaka said the foreign minister still had some resistance to a specific spending requirement. The United States' trade deficit with Japan is $49 billion a year. In April, the two countries tentatively outlined a series of economic reforms. Japan agreed to open its retailing system, increase spending on public works projects, strengthen antitrust legislation and loosen restrictions on foreign investment. The United States pledged to cut its federal budget deficit and take measures to increase savings and investment. The SII talks, begun last year, have been bogged down lately with Japan indicating its made all the concessions it can. Meanwhile, the United States is characterizing the April accord as a ``way station'' with more concrete language needed to carry out the promises. Congressional critics have said the Bush Administration's decision to remove Japan from a tough section of trade law called Super 301, which threatens economic sanctions, has allowed Japan to refuse further concessions. Negotiators are supposed to conclude the talks June 25-26 in Tokyo.

DOC.HEAD: Brandeis President Evelyn Handler To Resign
DOC.TEXT: Brandeis University President Evelyn E. Handler plans to resign to pursue other interests at the end of the next school year. ``I have been privileged to have served Brandeis since 1983, and I have accomplished most of what I set out to do,'' said Handler, the school's fifth president. ``I am ready for new challenges and Brandeis, too, is ready for change, change that will prepare it for the new millennium,'' Handler said Friday. Handler, a former president of the University of New Hampshire, said her last year will be spent outlining priorities for the university's future. She also was a faculty member and academic dean at Hunter College in New York City. Handler is the third Boston-area president to step down this year. The others were Harvard University president Derek Bok and Massachusetts Institute of Technology president Paul Gray.

DOC.HEAD: Sheriff Picks Deputy Through Luck of Draw
DOC.TEXT: A county sheriff used the luck of the draw to determine which of two laid-off deputy sheriffs to rehire. R.C. Godsey won the draw on Friday and returns to work July 1, Fayette County Sheriff Bill Laird said. A secretary shook up a box containing the names of Godsey and Garland Burke. Laird said he drew Godsey's name. ``I don't particularly like this approach to decision making,'' Laird said. But the two deputies' seniority was the equal, and state law provided no other guidance on how to decide. Burke had no comment, The Register-Herald in Beckley said. Godsey and Burke were laid off Jan. 1, 1989, because of budget cuts. ``I just wish that both of us could have come back,'' Godsey said.

DOC.HEAD: You Too Can Resemble The Jut-Jawed Detective
DOC.TEXT: Crimestoppers Tip No. 134: If you're paying $345 for a yellow overcoat, you're being robbed. But nobody held a gun on the shoppers who turned out at Manhattan stores Friday and kicked off the Dick Tracy paraphernalia onslaught by laying out cash for yellow fedoras ($30), Tracy towels ($20) and Tracy T-shirts ($14). Want the great detective's jutting jaw on your face? $50 for a mask. How about a denim jacket with his likeness across the back? $115. A leather bomber jacket with the omnipresent Tracy logo? $195. Or his trademark yellow trenchcoat? $345. Believe it, sweetheart. And stores were giving customers the hard sell on these goods, which were generated by the superhyped Warren Beatty flick which opened at 12:01 a.m. Friday. The second floor at Bloomingdale's featured a stack of eight televisions running the movie's trailer nonstop. In another section of The Dick Tracy Shop there, co-star Madonna belted out ``Vogue'' and songs from the film soundtrack over and over and over ... ``This is all for that movie?'' asked one woman as she handed over $28 for a pair of T-shirts. The Tracy togs were so prevalent that they displaced Bart Simpson and family from the top of the T-shirt racks. ``It's great. My wife says they're quite well made, not trashy,'' said Roger Dutton, a Melbourne, Australia, resident who was clutching a pair of towels. ``You pay premium for the premium goods, I guess.'' The trashy stuff was in another section of the store. Lacy bustiers, flapper dresses and other skin-flashing selections worn by Breathless Mahoney (Madonna) drew plenty of interest, but not as many buyers. ``If I could get away with this stuff in Kokomo, I'd wear it,'' said Linda Dechert, who was visiting from Indiana. ``I think this stuff will catch on with the younger crowd. Madonna's so popular.'' The Breathless outfits actually aren't as daring as the ones that cling to Madonna in the movie. ``Some of her gowns were slit down to the navel. We didn't go quite that far,'' said Elaine Johnson of L.A. Glo, which is handling the clothes. At Macy's flagship store, the eighth floor was covered in Tracy yellow, with painted black silhouettes of Tracy and his nemeses Big Boy and Flattop. ``Calling All Crimestoppers to Herald Square'' read a Macy's newspaper ad, and more people than that responded. Although store policy is not to release sales figures, things were going well on Day One of the Tracy explosion. ``Our shop is well-traveled, quite popular,'' said Barbara Lewinski, spokeswoman for the store. ``And once the film opens this weekend, it should get bigger.''

DOC.HEAD: Deadly Detroit Celebration Doesn't Surprise Mayor
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Coleman Young said the violence that killed seven people during the Detroit Pistons' basketball championship celebration disappointed but didn't surprise him. ``There are always some, who under cover of celebration, will break the law. Always. And that's what happened last night,'' Young said Friday, addressing a group of visiting journalists at a city-sponsored media day. ``But there sure wasn't any wild explosion of killings,'' Young added. Seven people were killed, six of them hit by cars, and hundreds were injured by gunfire, stabbings and fighting, police said. Looting and raucous behavior led to dozens of arrests after fans jammed streets to mark Detroit's 92-90 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers for the National Basketball Association title. Four people were killed and one person was injured when a car plowed into a group of pedestrians celebrating on the city's east side at 1:15 a.m. Friday. Police arrested a 41-year-old man and confiscated his car 10 hours later. The accident killed a 9-year-old boy, a 10-year-old boy, a 15-year-old girl and a 21-year-old man, said Police Sgt. Christopher Buck. A man with a broken leg was hospitalized, Buck said. In River Rouge, a southern suburb, a 4-year-old boy was struck and killed by a car during a street celebration. A man whose name and age weren't released died after he was hit by a car outside a party store in Detroit, police said. The seventh victim was a 21-year-old man who fell from the roof of an apartment building during a celebration party, said Diane Cuper, a spokeswoman for Detroit Receiving Hospital. Detroit's victory brought fans rushing from their homes to dance in the streets and on car roofs. They waved fists and shirts, dribbling and tossing basketballs in their excitement. Gunshots were fired by armed partiers. Police said there were 31 incidents of malicious destruction of property in Detroit neighborhoods. Thirty-five people were arrested or detained for disorderly conduct in Detroit, and River Rouge police arrested 28 revelers, most on disorderly conduct charges. Mike Toma said he plans to sell his Monte Carlo Foods store, which was looted of beer, wine, meats, a television, a shotgun and a money order machine. He had stayed open late, watching the NBA finals on television, he said. ``I was excited. I went out to go home and everybody was excited. Then excitement turned to disaster,'' he said. ``They tied something round the window bars and dragged them out with a truck. ``I'm going to put this store up for sale _ for any price. I'm fed up.'' On Detroit's west side, a merchant was questioned and released after two people were shot while trying to break into his store, police said. ``It was like hundreds of them with bats and bricks and it scared him,'' Maggie Varner, manager of the Beebe Party Store, said of the owner. ``He panicked,'' she said. ``They started breaking the door. When I came in this morning, we washed the blood off the sidewalk.'' A 17-year-old was shot in the head and listed in critical condition at Mount Carmel Hospital, spokeswoman Rose Dale said. The other man, age 21, was being treated for a gunshot wound to the leg. Varner said owner Jack Beebe, 60, was resting at home after the incident. The mob violence was reminiscent of 1984, when the Detroit Tigers won the World Series. More than 100,000 people poured into the streets, overturning cars, looting and causing widespread damage. One person died. Last year, carloads of boisterous fans also jammed streets after the Pistons, the ``Bad Boys'' of basketball, swept the Los Angeles Lakers in four games for their first NBA crown. But that celebration was free of violence.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Israel must remain strong to secure that peace, but weapons and technology alone are not sufficient. ... Real security can only come through successful negotiations with Palestinians and Arab states that leads to a durable peace.'' _ Defense Secretary Dick Cheney before the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith in New York City.

``Federal policy towards our cities and towards economic opportunity today is as bankrupt as the corrupt savings and loans which are robbing our young people's future. ... While we waited at Washington's back door for a few crumbs for urban America, these bandits heisted over $300 billion from our nation's treasury.'' _ Boston Mayor Raymond Flynn, complaining about reduced federal spending on urban problems.

``This is a little excessive, your honor, wouldn't you say?'' _ Jack Henry Abbott, whose prison writings became a best-selling book, on losing a nearly $7.6 million court judgment to the widow of an aspiring actor he killed.

DOC.HEAD: Talks Fail to Resolve Differences Over Cambodia
DOC.TEXT: A senior Chinese official says two days of talks in Hanoi failed to narrow differences between China and Vietnam over how to end the 11-year-old Cambodian war. Deputy Foreign Minister Xu Dunxin headed the first high-level Chinese delegation to visit Vietnam since the two countries fought a border war in 1979. The conflict came a few weeks after Vietnam invaded Cambodia and ousted the Khmer Rouge from power. Xu and Vietnamese Deputy Foreign Minister Tran Quang Co held discussions in Hanoi on Tuesday and Wednesday. Xu spoke Friday in Bangkok. His comments were reported by the official Chinese news agency Xinhua. He was quoted as saying the two countries remain divided over two key points: the status of Cambodia's government during the transition period before a new administration, and the status of its army during that period. China is the principal backer of three Cambodian guerrilla factions _ including the Khmer Rouge _ fighting the Vietnamese-installed government in Phnom Penh. There have been proposals that the United Nations become involved in adminstering the country to prepare the way for elections once the warring factions have agreed to a cease-fire. But Xinhua quoted Xu as saying: ``We came to know through the exchange of views that Vietnam does not agree to bringing into full play the role of the United Nations.'' He said the Vietnamese did not agree to an interim U.N. trusteeship for Cambodia or even to stationing a U.N. peacekeeping force there. Xu said there are no plans for further talks. The Hanoi discussions were the fourth round of Sino-Vietnamese talks over the past year and a half. Vietnam has sought to improve ties with China as the Soviet Union cuts back its economic and political support for Hanoi and Eastern European countries drift toward the West. Official Radio Hanoi on Thursday gave only a brief and vague report on the talks, indicating little progress was made. The latest efforts to end the fighting in Cambodia were set back earlier this month when the Khmer Rouge, the strongest guerrilla faction, refused to sign a cease-fire pact in Tokyo, saying it was denied equal representation in the negotiations. China also refused to support the agreement.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Roam Plains, Midwest; Rain in West.
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms roamed the central Plains and the western Midwest early today and rain fell in parts of the West. Rain-threatening clouds dissipated and left clear skies along the Eastern seaboard. Drizzle fell on central North Dakota, southwest South Dakota and eastern Minnesota and in San Fransico, Seattle, Salt Lake City and central Wyoming. Intense thunderstorms struck eastern Nebraska early today. Hot and muggy weather was forecast today from the Plains to the East Coast. Tropical air from Mexico riding ahead of a cold front was expected to unleash thunderstorms from west Texas to the Midwest. Tornadoes downed farms, trees and power lines Friday in southwest Nebraska, but caused no deaths or injuries, authorities said. Cattle and horses were killed by twisters cutting a 25-mile path in Hitchcock County, authorities said. Violent thunderstorms swept Kansas on Friday, damaging windows in about 100 homes and several rooftops in Topeka. A car dealership there reported 80 or 90 cars had their windshields blown out. The high Friday in the Lower 48 states was 105 degrees in Laredo, Texas. DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUB 1st item to CORRECT spelling of Connar, sted Donnar, in 2nd graf.
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Richard G. Connar Sr., a surgeon who helped establish the University of South Florida medical college and was chairman of its surgery department, died at his home Thursday of cancer. He was 70. Connar, a World War II flight surgeon who taught surgery at Duke University before moving to Tampa in the 1950s, performed the first open-heart and closed-heart operations in Tampa, both at Tampa General Hospital. The medical college was chartered in 1965 and opened its doors in 1971. Dr. Connar joined USF surgery faculty in 1968 and was chairman of surgery from 1982 until his death. He also served as USF's deputy vice president and vice president for medical affairs.

DOC.HEAD: Peace Promoters Killed in Plane Crash
DOC.TEXT: A small-plane crash killed a retired air force colonel and a college professor about to wrap up a 48-state peace tour. Retired Air Force Col. Frank Martineau, 69, of Bethesda, Md., and Marjorie Zeuch, 67, of Warwick, R.I., died Friday when their single-engine plane crashed short of an airport runway, said Maj. Robert Wolfe of the Air National Guard in Charleston. The two also were trying to set a speed record for flying a single-engine plane to all capitals in the contiguous 48 states. Charleston was their next-to-last stop before winding up the trip later Friday at Washington National Airport in Virginia. ``He had fuel on board and the landing gear was down,'' said Frank Gurish, a Federal Aviation Administration investigator at the scene. ``It would appear he was of the notion he was on a normal landing pattern. It was on course. It was just lower than he should have been.'' The four-seat plane clipped a tree in a park about one-half mile short of the Yeager Airport runway, Wolfe said. The plane spun around and landed on its nose, with the right wing torn off in several pieces, said Sgt. Vic Gazitano of the Kanawha County Sheriff's Department. Despite light rain, visibility was 1 mile and ``the weather was good enough to permit landings,'' said Jack Depew, manager of the airport control tower. Zeuch was an English professor at Rhode Island Community College. Martineau had been a pilot in the Royal Canadian Air Force and the U.S. Army Air Force during World War II. The 4,000-mile trip, dubbed ``Operation Appleseed,'' was taken to promote Zeuch's World Friendship Association, said Chuck Davenport, managing editor of Association Trends, a national weekly newspaper founded by Martineau. The association, a 2-year-old charitable organization, was ``dedicated to bringing ordinary people of the world closer together for permanent peace,'' Davenport said. Edward Cornish, whose son is married to Martineau's daughter, helped answer telephones at the newspaper's Bethesda, Md., office Friday. ``(Zeuch) had this mission of spreading friendship, and Frank thought this would be a good project for the association to be involved with,'' Cornish said. ``Obviously everybody's in shock,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Jewelry Store Loses $500,000 In Heist
DOC.TEXT: A man posing as a building inspector bound and gagged two clerks at a jewelry store and made off with more than $500,000 worth of goods, police said. The robber entered the Gold Connection early Friday and said he was there to inspect something in the basement, police Detective Sgt. Dennis Gerstmeyer said. The two women led him into a back room where a safe was located without asking for identification, Gerstmeyer said. He said the two thought the man had a gun, although they didn't see one. The man emptied the safe of mostly gold jewelry and some diamonds after tying the wrists of the women and taping their mouths, Gerstmeyer said. The safe was already open to stock store shelves. The robber stuffed the jewelry into two shopping bags and slipped into a crowd outside, Gerstmeyer said.

DOC.HEAD: TV Station Reports American Kidnapped by Former Colleague
LaserPhoto NY13
DOC.TEXT: A kidnapped American whose family raised $60,000 ransom in a public appeal was seized in South America after his boss at a gold mine refused to pay blackmail to a former employee, a television station reported. Citing legal documents filed in a court in Quito, Ecuador, WHOI-TV in Peoria reported Friday that Scott Heimdal's kidnapping apparently was not a random terrorist act as previously thought. In the documents, Heimdal's boss, Jeffrey Fino, general manager of IMINCO gold mine in Quito, said a former employee had tried to blackmail him and orchestrated Heimdal's kidnapping. Fino claimed the worker was running guns to Colombian terrorists as well, WHOI reported. The former employee allegedly contacted Fino in February to tell him a terrorist group wanted to kidnap and kill him, but Fino ignored the warning, the station reported. WHOI also said the former employee made several attempts through blackmail to get Fino to pay $40,000, which Fino rejected. Heimdal, 27, formerly of Peoria, was kidnapped April 28 when a band of armed men attacked a canoe he was aboard, killed the pilot and took Heimdal and an Ecuadoran hostage. The attackers, earlier believed to be Colombian guerrillas, freed the Ecuadoran and sent him to Quito with the ransom demand.
