It was something that was beyond what I've seen from tornadoes and floods previously. One can only imagine what it was like,'' Gov. Richard Celeste said this morning after making his second flight over the area. ``The shock of the wall of water as it roared through a very confined area literally flattened everything.'' Flood-ravaged areas were sealed off today so police dog teams from as far away as Maryland and Kentucky and members of the Ohio National Guard could search for the missing. The body of a 5-year-old girl was pulled late this morning from from McMahon Creek, northwest of the primary search area, said Chuck Vogt, Belmont County coroner's investigator. ``They have sealed off the area around Wegee and Pipe creeks to everybody but emergency personnel until the search is over to help the dogs pick up the scent,'' said Stacie Gilg, a spokeswoman for the Ohio Emergency Management Agency. Adjutant Gen. Richard Alexander, commander of the Ohio National Guard, said 341 Guard personnel, including 130 engineers, were assisting in search and rescue and rebuilding efforts. Officials from West Virginia and the U.S. Coast Guard were also taking part. The Highway Patrol reported at least 60 people unaccounted-for, Ms. Gilg said. The Belmont County Sheriff's Department reported 51 people missing. Houses and businesses were washed away, roads were damaged and families were scattered in the flash flood, which caught the National Weather Service off guard. Alexander said at least 60 homes were destroyed and at least 50 others were damaged. ``It's hard to explain,'' Gregg Warren, trustee in nearby Mead Township, said Friday. ``It's unbelievable. A creek you could walk across with water up to your ankles in some places rose 15 to 25 feet.'' A 9-year-old girl, Amber Colvin, survived for seven hours on the Ohio River by clinging to logs and doing the dog paddle _ the only swimming stroke she knows _ after she was washed out of her home by floodwater. The girl, found seven miles from home, was hospitalized in fair condition with minor scrapes and bruises. She said she was swept from a bathtub when the house began to fill with water. A 12-year-old friend of Amber's remained missing. ``We got in the bathtub, and the water was over our heads and then the house collapsed,'' Amber said Friday. The Federal Emergency Management Agency on Friday declared as disaster areas Belmont County, where Shadyside is located, and nearby Jefferson County. Franklin County in central Ohio also was included in the disaster declaration because of flooding there. The declaration makes residents eligible for federal aid. Celeste, who flew over the area Friday and again this morning, said he had not seen so much damage since a tornado ripped through Xenia in western Ohio in 1974, killing 37 people. ``A wall of water wiped a path through the area,'' Celeste said. Ohio's two U.S. senators, John Glenn and Howard Metzenbaum, also toured the area Friday. ``When children and adults perish in such a disaster as this, it's very hard to know how to react,'' Metzenbaum said. Glenn called the flood-damaged portions of the city of 4,300 people a ``war zone.'' Chuck Vogt, an investigator for the Belmont County coroner's office, said all of the dead were from either Shadyside or Mead Township, where the two creeks run south of Shadyside. Shadyside is about 10 miles south of Wheeling, W.Va. At least five houses along the Wegee Creek were washed away and two cars floated Friday in water in one of the basements. Jim Leonard of the American Red Cross said relief teams set up a shelter at an elementary school. About 200 people came and went during the day Friday. Most sought news of friends or relatives. Doctors and ministers at the school counseled people who lost relatives and friends. The National Weather Service did not warn residents because a thunderstorm in the area appeared on radar to be less severe than it was, said Al Wheeler, deputy meteorologist in Cleveland. The weather service issued a flood watch, indicating that floods along small streams and low-lying areas was possible, but it did not issue a flood warning, which alerts residents to take shelter.

DOC.HEAD: Western Republican To Leads Mayors; Boston's Flynn Climbs To No. 2
DOC.TEXT: Colorado Springs Mayor Robert Isaac was in the middle of a long list of complaints about the federal government when he paused with a reminder. ``Just because you're a Republican doesn't mean you have to agree with everything that a Republican administration does,'' Isaac said. Such an attitude should prove handy to Isaac in his new position as president of the U.S. Conference of Mayors, an organization dominated by big-city Democratic mayors who blame many festering urban problems on sharp cuts in federal aid to cities. Isaac, whose city has a population of 280,000, leads the mayors' group at a time when many of its Democratic members are sharpening their attacks on President Bush. They accuse him of ignoring the needs of cities in housing, education, anti-drug and other programs, and demand a considerable share of any federal budget savings realized through planned defense cuts. When Isaac takes over Wednesday _ the final day of the mayors' annual summer meeting _ moving into his current slot as vice president will be perhaps the organization's most vocal Bush critic, Boston Mayor Raymond Flynn. Isaac realizes he'll face partisan pressure to tone down the organization's criticisms of the Bush administration. The White House and political party officials routinely lobby mayors. ``I'm elected to do a job and you can be sure that's what I'm going to do,'' Isaac said in an interview. ``I may not always agree with my colleagues but after the votes are taken and the positions adopted, I'm going to be carrying out those policies as best I can.'' Isaac already shares many of the concerns of his big-city Democratic colleagues. He is highly critical of sending federal anti-drug aid to states and forcing cities to compete for assistance and wait longer for aid. He supports tough law enforcement in the drug war but says cities also need much more money to reduce demand through by treating users. And Isaac says the mayors need to put more pressure on the administration and Congress to spend more of the billions of dollars piling up in highway and aviation trust funds _ money the White House and many in Congress are reluctant to spend because the balances of those accounts help hide the true size of the federal deficit. ``This money ought to be spent as it was designed to be spent,'' he said. Isaac's greatest complaint is that mayors _ ``those of us who make decisions at the lowest level of government and provide the most services'' _ are not consulted enough when the federal government placed new demands on governments. ``We have considerable mandates and requirements placed on us by the federal government but less and less money to carry them out,'' Isaac said. ``I have always rejected the approach that funding of the cities was a handout. There are certain functions of the cities that certainly the federal government ought to be involved in paying for.'' Isaac succeeds Houston Mayor Kathryn Whitmire, a Democrat, as conference president. Flynn will be in line to succeed Isaac next year. Many Democratic mayors were disappointed that Ms. Whitmire was not more vocal in her criticism of Bush, who has adopted her city as his hometown and who had her as a guest at the White House during a January meeting of the mayors in Washington. Her only outspoken criticism of the administration has focused on spending of federal anti-drug money. Flynn won the No. 3 conference leadership post last year in an unusual partisan floor fight in which Ms. Whitmire sided with Republican mayors. He offered strong praise of Isaac and said having a Republican leader of the conference could help the mayors as they lobby for more federal aid. ``What we do now can't be interpreted as partisan,'' Flynn said in an interview. ``Bob is a Republican, somewhat conservative, from the West, and here I am from the East, a Democrat, moderate to liberal. It's hard to ignore that unique combination of concern about what is happening to America's cities.''

DOC.HEAD: Rallies Held in South Africa on `Soweto Day'
LaserPhoto JOH3
DOC.TEXT: Blacks staged dozens of peaceful rallies nationwide on Saturday to commemorate the 1976 Soweto student uprisings that shaped an entire generation of anti-apartheid activists. About 20,000 blacks, most of them young, packed a Soweto stadium to observe June 16, 1976, or Soweto Day, when police opened fire on black students protesting the education policies of the white-led government. ``The youth of Soweto is now a great symbol of resistance and defiance throughout the world,'' African National Congress leader Walter Sisulu told the crowd. Soweto, 10 miles outside Johannesburg, is the country's largest black township with 2.5 million residents. The 1976 police shootings in Soweto touched off an unprecedented wave of unrest that spread throughout the country and lasted several months. Some 500 to 700 blacks died and thousands fled the country to join the ANC. Many blacks point to the 1976 riots as the time when they became active opponents of the white-led government and its apartheid policies of racial segregation. ``Fourteen years ago we mourned and complained, but today we are counting our victories,'' ANC spokesman Popo Molefe told tens of thousands of blacks at a rally outside the southern city of Port Elizabeth. The ANC, the country's largest black opposition group, was legalized in February after being banned for 30 years. ANC leader Nelson Mandela, the country's best known anti-apartheid figure, was released Feb. 11 after 27 years in prison and is on a highly publicized tour of Europe, North America and Africa, urging other nations to maintain economic sanctions on South Africa. Dozens of peaceful Soweto Day events were held Saturday around South Africa, most of them staged by the ANC or the rival Pan Africanist Congress. Since coming to power last year, President F.W. de Klerk has allowed peaceful protests that have official permission. Saturday marked the first time since the 1976 riots that widespread demonstrations have taken place on Soweto Day without major police intervention. In one incident in downtown Johannesburg, police fired tear gas to disperse a few dozen black demonstrators, saying they did not have permission for the protest. A black journalist was taken into custody, according to witnesses. Police also used tear gas to disperse rallies in Natal Province, the one region where a 4-year-old state of emergency remains in effect. De Klerk lifted the emergency in the rest of the country June 9. In the central town of Welkom, about 250 members of the white supremacist Afrikaner Resistance Movement marched to protest the detention without charge of two whites. Members dressed in khaki uniforms gave stiff-armed, Nazi-style salutes and chanted, ``Hang (Nelson) Mandela.'' They then marched to a nearby police station and handed in a petition protesting the detentions. The two men are being held in connection with separate bomb attacks in Pretoria and Welkom, but no one has been charged in either case. The 1976 protests were triggered by a government policy to teach classes in Afrikaans rather than English. Afrikaans is the language of the Dutch-descended Afrikaners who dominate the government and many blacks consider it the ``language of the oppressor.'' Every year since 1976 blacks have observed June 16 as an unofficial holiday. Most blacks stay home from school and work. The ANC said that the inferior black education system that caused the 1976 unrest still exists. Black teachers are holding strikes and protests throughout the country, and some black schools in urban areas have been closed for much of the year. Last year, only 42 percent of black high school seniors passed their final examinations required to receive a diploma. The government's per pupil expenditure on whites is about five times more than on blacks.

DOC.HEAD: Illinois Man Decapitated In Guatemala
DOC.TEXT: The bound and decapitated body of an Illinois man who worked as a travel guide has been found in a remote area of northern Guatemala, a police officer in the region said. The body of Michael Vernon Devine, 49, of Belleville, Ill., was discovered June 9, the officer said in a telephone interview. The officer, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Devine's money and watch were missing but that he did not know if robbery was the only motive for the killing. The body was found about two miles from the town of Poptun, 240 miles northeast of Guatemala City in the province of Peten, the officer of the provincial capital of Flores said. The tied-up body was found in a clump of bushes, the policeman said. He did not say who found the body. The disappearance of Devine, a tourist guide who owned the Xobel de Poptun inn, was reported by his wife, Carole A. Moore, the officer said. Devine also transported merchandise between ranches in the Poptun region near the Guatemalan border with Belize, the officer said. The victim was transporting goods when he disappeared, the officer said. He did not identify the goods or say whether Devine's vehicle was taken. Officials at the U.S. Consulate in Guatemala City said it did not have any information on the case.

DOC.HEAD: American Gets Belated Hero's Honors from Village He Helped Liberate
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Army Capt. Robert Hamsley returned Saturday for a hero's welcome to this Breton village he helped liberate nearly 46 years ago from Nazi German occupiers. Children waving American and French flags greeted Hamsley as he was paraded through the village in a World War II vintage command jeep. Nearly all of Plelo's 2,300 residents turned out to applaud. A detachment of U.S. Marines and French soldiers stood by as Hamsley, 71, was given the Chevalier of the Legion of Honor, one of the nation's most distinguished awards. The village sports stadium was renamed in his honor. Hamsley, of Lawrenceburg, Tenn., and Orlando, Fla., appeared a bit taken aback by the acclaim. ``I love you, Plelo,'' he said in a toast. At a ceremony at the village's monument to the dead of World War II, Plelo Mayor Yves Le Coqu hailed Hamsley as the village's ``American savior.'' In August 1944, Plelo was occupied by the Nazis, who were preparing to carry out a series of executions when Hamsley entered the village at the head of a five-tank platoon. His men wiped out a contingent of the heavily armed Germans. But two days later, German anti-tank guns knocked out four of the five tanks and damaged Hamsley's own M-4. However, Hamsley and his crew managed to destroy the guns and killed or drove off about 100 Gemans. Hamsley received a Bronze Star for his action and was promoted from lieutenant to captain. But his action was not even reported in the official diaries of the 15th Cavalry Regiment of Gen. George Patton's Third Army. The belated recognition was prompted in part by the efforts of a history buff who also served in the 15th Cavalry, Robert Dwan, of Tuscon, Ariz. Dwan, along with amateur French historians, pinpointed Hamsley as the hero of Plelo. Last year, the Plelo village council named Hamsley an honorary citizen ``in testimony of our gratitude for your courageous action of Aug. 6, 1944, which led to (the village's) liberation.'' The mayor then invited Hamsley to Saturday's ceremony in his honor.

DOC.HEAD: First College Reopened In West Bank Seen As Test Case
DOC.TEXT: The Israeli authorities on Saturday reopened the first of six colleges in the occupied lands that have been closed for 30 months due to the Palestinian uprising. The reopening of Ramallah College of Paramedical Sciences is seen as a test case. If it goes well, the other Arab universities in the occupied territories could be allowed to open again, too. The schools have a total of 18,000 students. The Palestinian institutions of higher learning were closed by the Israeli military shortly after the uprising erupted in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip in December 1987. The military contended the schools were hotbeds of unrest. The shutdown drew sharp criticism from the United States and Western Europe, which said it amounted to collective punishment. The European Parliament at one point recommended that scientific cooperation with Israel be frozen until the universities and colleges in the occupied lands were reopened. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir ordered the gradual reopening of the schools on May 14. But the order was suspended for a month following the May 20 massacre of seven Gaza laborers by an Israeli gunman near Tel Aviv and the subsequent wave of riots in the occupied territories. There were virtually no classes at the Ramallah school on Saturday because many students failed to appear. On the nearby Jerusalem-Ramallah road, long lines of cars were seen at army roadblocks, and some students said it was hard to pass through. The college director, Farsin Arabikian, that while the school was closed, some students got married, others went abroad and some were jailed. Only 15 of the former 38 nursing students had re-registered, she said. ``The fate of the college is unpredictable and students are affected by what is going on outside the college,'' she said. Arabikian expected about 150 students to pursue studies this year in the college's three departments _ nursing, X-ray and medical technology. On Saturday, about a dozen students standing outside the college, a branch of Jerusalem University, said they hoped their studies could continue. ``There is a decision by the uprising leadership not to use the academic institutions as centers for demonstrations and other activities,'' said Halil Mustafa Sarahne, 23, from Hebron in the West Bank. While the school was closed, Sarahne spent 10 months in detention at the Ketziot prison camp in the southern Negev desert for uprising-related activities he declined to specify. Now this medical technology student carries a special identity card that prohibits him from passing through Jerusalem on his way to the college. ``If police stop me in Jerusalem I will automatically be served with six months in administrative detention'' without trial, Sarahne said. Underground leaders of the rebellion have said in recent leaflets that resumption of studies was a top priority, and that students must not give the army an excuse to close schools. Yasser Obeid, head of the Ramallah college's Board of Trustees, said Israel's coordinator of activities in the occupied territories, Shmuel Goren, warned him the school would be closed again if students start rioting. Goren told The Associated Press in May that schools would be closed immediately if violence recurred. ``I'm not sure they can control their students. But at least they promised that they can do it,'' he said then. Obeid said he believed the college's 233 students just want to study. ``They are very eager to continue their education,'' he said. The other Palestinian universities that remain closed are Bethlehem University, Islamic University, Hebron University, An-Najah University and Bir Zeit University. During the shutdown, instruction has continued in the makeshift ``underground classes'' but attendance was sporadic and the education far below the normal standards.

DOC.HEAD: Government, Rebels Announce Cease-Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 2-3 pvs, `Last year...' to ADD no overall official count, sourcing on massacre. Pickup 4th pvs, `Saturday's cease-fire...'
DOC.TEXT: The government and Tamil rebels declared a cease-fire Saturday in another attempt to end a 7-year-old separatist campaign that has claimed more than 11,000 lives. Last year, the government gambled it could achieve peace by appeasing the rebel Tamil Tigers. That gamble failed last week when government and military officials said more than 130 unarmed policemen were massacred by the rebels and hundreds more were missing. After the Tigers broke an earlier truce on Monday, at least 376 people were killed in northern and eastern Sri Lanka, according to reports compiled by witnesses, military sources and rebel officials. The government has not given a comprehensive death toll. Saturday's cease-fire came after two days of negotiations. Military officials in Colombo and a Tiger spokesman in the northern rebel stronghold of Jaffna said it took effect throughout the north and east as scheduled at 6 p.m. Residents in the eastern town of Batticaloa, where the trouble started when the Tigers captured the police station Monday, confirmed the shooting had stopped. The Tigers were patrolling Batticaloa, according to the residents who were contacted by telephone from Colombo, 135 miles to the southwest. They declined to give further details and spoke on condition of anonymity out of fear for their safety. For the past 13 months, President Ranasinghe Premadasa's government and Tiger leaders had been negotiating on a power-sharing arrangment designed to draw the guerrillas away from the separatist campaign they launched in 1983 and into politics. The government let the rebels assume many military and civil powers. But its trust was shattered by the Tigers' methodical attacks in the past week in the north and east. The Tigers overran at least 20 police stations staffed by officers whose orders were to surrender, not shoot, and shot and killed some of their captives. A few hours before the cease-fire was announced, Premadasa referred to the Tigers as ``terrorists'' _ a sharp departure from his previous conciliatory efforts. He warned that unless the attacks stopped ``they will have to face the consequences and face the same fate'' as Sinhalese extremists whose leaders were decimated by the government last winter. Even before the attacks, there had been signs of trouble. The Tigers, consisting largely of teen-age guerrillas, had grown increasingly bold in the last few months, extracting ``taxes'' from local businesses and telling the army and police where they could and could not go. Tamils, who make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, claim the Sinhalese majority discriminate against them in jobs and education. After the massacres of the policemen, the army and the Tigers battled for five days for control of key towns in the north and along the eastern sea coast. When the Tigers captured the police station in Batticaloa, they allowed its 300 men to take refuge at an air force base or with Roman Catholic priests. The government, perhaps reassured by that, told police to surrender rather than fight if their stations were attacked. That was what police did at Kalmunai, 22 miles south of Batticaloa. Of the 115 policeman on duty Monday night, only one lived to tell what had happened. The sole known survivor, a 23-year-old officer named Piyeratna Ranaweera, said all 115 were blindfolded, loaded into three buses, taken into the jungle, forced to lie face-down on the ground and sprayed with bullets from T-56 assault rifles. Then shots were fired at close range into their heads, Ranaweera said in an interview at Kandy General Hospital. His left arm broken by rifle fire and his left ear grazed by a bullet, he said he crawled out of the heap of bodies after the Tigers left. After a 12-hour, 14-mile walk during which he fainted at least twice, he reached government lines and was flown to Kandy, in the center of the island. Altogether, about 800 policemen surrendered to the Tigers, according to the Defense Ministry. The government says it has no firm information on their fates. ``We still do not have orders to shoot,'' said an officer at Ampara, 13 miles southwest of Kalmunai. ``We don't care about orders. If we come under fire, we'll shoot.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: The South Carolina judge overseeing singer James Brown's work-release program was asked to please, please, please let the Godfather of Soul testify at the Rev. Al Sharpton's fraud trial. ``Mr. Brown's testimony ... is relevant, material and necessary to the case,'' attorney C. Vernon Mason wrote last week to Circuit Court Judge Rodney A. Peeples. The judge would have to approve Brown's trip to New York. Sharpton, a flamboyant civil-rights activist who recently lead protests in the racially torn Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, is on trial in state Supreme Court in Manhattan on charges he stole $250,000 from the non-profit National Youth Movement. He once worked as Brown's hairdresser. Brown was released to a halfway house for the work program earlier this year after serving 15 months of a six-year sentence for aggravated assault. The defense in Sharpton's case begins on Tuesday, but there was no word on whether Peeples would allow Brown to take the stand.

Jimmy Vaughan is leaving the Fabulous Thunderbirds after 15 years, but he's not going away mad, the rock band's manager says. ``Jimmie's not leaving the band on a bad note,'' said manager Mark Proct. ``He's real happy. Obviously no one in the band wanted to see him leave. But it's a decision Jimmie made on the basis of his personal life and his family.'' Vaughan, who helped found the group and shaped its sound with his bluesy guitar licks, will be replaced by two guitarists _ Duke Robillard, founder of Roomful of Blues, and Doug ``Kid'' Bangham, formerly of the East Coast band Sugar Ray and the Blue Tones. Vaughan is working with brother Stevie Ray Vaughan on a project scheduled for release in September. The two brothers are considered to be among rock music's leading guitarists.

A collection of speeches delivered by Nelson Mandela since his release from prison has arrived in the United States just days before the deputy president of the African National Congress gets here himself. ``Intensify the Struggle to Abolish Apartheid'' is a salute by Pathfinder publishers to Mandela's ``historic tour of North America,'' editorial director Steve Clark said Saturday. Mandela arrives Wednesday in New York to begin a 10-day visit. Included in the 74-page collection of 1990 speeches is Mandela's 1989 letter from prison to South Africa's state president; his post-prison speeches to mass rallies in South Africa; his speech to 80,000 anti-apartheid activists in London and his May 23 talk to South African business executives. The book also contains the ANC's historic Freedom Charter, photos, maps and historical information.

On Music Row, he is known as a ladies' man, but country music star Lee Greenwood says he's also quite a family man. In fact, the 47-year-old Greenwood is a proud grandfather _ three times over. But he wasn't always thrilled with his ``grandpa'' status. ``It was a negative to me until I saw an ad some years ago with Tom Jones carrying his grandchild. I said, `Man, he looks cool with that little baby.''' Greenwood, who has been married four times and is considering marrying Miss Tennessee Kim Payne, says he does try to stay out of his offsprings' lives. ``My mother and father were divorced when I was quite young and there was a big battle between my mother and grandmother to raise me. ``Too much input from grandparents, I think, is not good. I don't want to overshadow my children's lives.'' Greenwood is known for his Grammy-award winning 1983 hit ``I.O.U'' and his chest-pounding 1984 anthem ``God Bless the U.S.A.''

DOC.HEAD: Fort Worth, Texas, Museum Buys 19th Century Masterpiece To Keep It In City
DOC.TEXT: A 19th-century masterpiece was bought from one museum by another for $10 million to keep ``The Swimming Hole'' in the city. After a two-month debate over the possibility of a New York auction for the painting by Thomas Eakins, it was purchased by the Amon Carter Museum. The sale will be concluded this week, Jan Keene Muhlert, director of the Carter museum, said Friday. The Fort Worth Art Association, governing body of the Modern Art Museum of Fort Worth, purchased ``The Swimming Hole'' in 1925 for $700. But officials recently decided to sell the painting because it was unsuited to the Modern's collection of post-1920 European art and post-1940 American art. The painting, which had been on loan to the Carter museum for more than two years, was shipped to New York, then back to the Modern, while the debate raged about keeping it in the city. It will be moved back to the Carter on Tuesday, Muhlert said. Eakins, who lived from 1844 to 1916, was known for his portraits and for such works as ``The Clinic of Professor Agnew.''

DOC.HEAD: Vet Treats Pets with Acupuncture
DOC.TEXT: Is Fido feeling feeble? Morris miserable? Conventional cures can't correct it? Take your suffering pet to the acupuncture vet. After spending 120 hours in Florida learning the ancient Chinese art of acupuncture, Ellen Paul has brought her skills back to Urbana to improve the health of ailing dogs and cats. Take Divot, for example _ a dog with more than the usual canine aversion to cats. She's allergic to them, and when her skin itches, she tugs at it with her teeth, leaving scabs behind. For the cure, Divot stood atop a table, her paws sliding on stainless steel while Paul stucke needles in the dog's coat and spinned them. ``This is the worst part,'' said Paul. ``Once the needles are in, they get bored and want to leave.'' Divot, who started treatments early this month, was calmer when she returned for her second round of treatments last week, said her owner, Bob Heister. ``She doesn't seem to be biting herself as much,'' Heister said. ``It seems to work.'' Acupuncture is not a cure-all, Paul said. ``But it does a good job for the things it is indicated for and is better than some medication,'' she said. The aim is to treat specified pressure points. These known nerve pathways in humans have analogs in other animals, Paul said, which share many health problems with humans. The 3,000-year-old art seems to boost the immune system and ease tension, said Paul, who is doing the work without charge while she perfects her techniques.

DOC.HEAD: International Ballet Competition Takes Stage in Mississippi
DOC.TEXT: Ballet dancers from 23 countries begin battling toe-to-toe Sunday, testing their grace, power and precision at the International Ballet Competition. ``It is the Olympics of the dance world,'' said event spokesman Tracy Harbour. ``Some of the greatest dancers in the world are here. It's a way for many of them to get money, to get credentials, to get recognition, to gain status in the industry,'' he said. ``Historically, this competition is known for launching the careers of many dance greats.'' Big-name former medalists include Soviet-born dancers Mikhail Baryshnikov and Alexander Godunov. It is the fourth time the competition has been held in the Mississippi capital and the debut of entrants have come from Cuba, Spain and Guatemala. About 100 men and women dancers, most members of recognized ballet companies recommended by their directors, were scheduled to compete. The competition is held in Jackson every four years. In other years, it's held in Varna, Bulgaria; Helsinki, Finland; and Moscow. The event came to Mississippi mainly because of efforts by Thalia Mara, former artistic director of the Jackson Ballet. In 1982, Congress passed a resolution making Jackson the permanent U.S. home of the IBC. After state support ended in 1985, the non-profit Mississippi Ballet International Inc. was forced to raise all needed funds. This year, the event was paid for mostly with $1 million donated by corporate and private sponsors, including a local rugby club. The Jackson area is likely to get more than that back. The state Department of Tourism estimated visitors would pump about $2.5 million back into the area's economy, said Mimi Dinsmore, a spokeswoman for the competition. Running through July 1, the competition involves three rounds. In the first, entrants will perform a choice from the classical ballet repertoire. In the second, competitors must perform a comtemporary work, something choreographed no earlier than 1950. In the finals, dancers must perform in both categories. Winners in the Olympics-style event will receive gold, silver and bronze medals and cash awards from $500 to $10,000. But the limelight carries more weight than the medals and cash. ``It's a springboard. It's a rare opportunity for the audience to see, you know, the future Baryshnikov,'' Ms. Dinsmore said. ``And it's a rare opportunity for the dancers to get exposure to their international peers.''

DOC.HEAD: Mayors Split Over Whether to Seek Constitutional Amendment on Federal Aid
With AM-Mayors-Leadership
DOC.TEXT: The nation's mayors took time out Saturday from bashing Washington to fight among themselves over whether the Constitution should be amended to guarantee cities a set percentage of federal revenues. The debate came as more than 200 mayors got down to business at their annual summer conference, taking committee action on dozens of proposed policy statements on issues ranging from taxes and transportation to housing and AIDS research. The U.S. Conference of Mayors human development committee endorsed a resoltion calling on Congress to pass legislation mandating that a ``fair'' percentage of federal revenues be channeled directly to cities. If Congress refused to pass such a law, the resolution would put the mayors on record in favor of a constitutional amendment requiring the revenue sharing. Philadelphia Mayor W. Wilson Goode led the support of the measure, saying the mayors needed to make a forceful statement to win attention for their concerns in Washington. But a separate committee, the mayors' panel on urban economic policy, voted unanimously to oppose the provision calling for a constitutional amendment. The proposals endorsed Saturday need to clear another committee Sunday in order to be presented to the full gathering next week. ``The Constitution should not be part of the budget process,'' Fort Wayne, Ind., Mayor Paul Helmke said. That dispute was the only diversion from a day spent largely following up Friday's opening session attack on Congress and the Bush administration for not sending more aid to cities. The mayors are virtually unanimous in saying that aid cutbacks in the 1980s exacerbated urban housing and education problems and left cities too poor to provide drug treatment and other services to the needy. ``Solutions hinge on the federal government making the urban areas and people a top priority,'' host Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago said at a morning news conference. ``We basically need an administration willing to have some courage and strong leadership.'' But many of the proposals popular with the mayors are viewed with trepidation in Washington _ among them the mayors' position that the federal government needs to raise taxes and give some of the money raised to cities. Also high on the mayors' agenda but controversial in Washington are proposals to spend more of the billions in aviation and highway trust funds for airport and road improvements. The huge balances in those accounts hide the true size of the federal budget deficit. The mayors rarely fight among themselves or criticize each other, but there were a few objections to the attacks on the Reagan and Bush adminstrations led by big-city Democratic mayors. GOP Mayor Jimmy Kemp of Meridian, Miss., who was first elected as a Democrat but switched parties, complained that most of the resolutions being debated blamed urban problems on Republican presidents. ``That's a bunch of bull,'' he said during the meeting of the urban economic policy committee. In an interview afterward, Kemp said such attacks divert the mayors from more fruitful discussions. ``That's not what we're here for,'' he said. ``It makes real progress more difficult to achieve.'' Before the Saturday meetings, dozens of the mayors joined Daley in the city's third annual ``Say No to Drugs'' parade.

DOC.HEAD: Cheering Crowds Greet Mandela in Netherlands
DOC.TEXT: A crowd of 10,000 people on Saturday gave a joyous welcome to African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela, who thanked them for staunch Dutch support of the anti-apartheid movement. ``You made it possible for me to be released from prison and to be able to stand before you today,'' Mandela told the crowd that jammed a square in central Amsterdam. The 71-year-old black nationalist leader was freed in February after spending 27 years in South African jails. The crowd waved ANC flags and banners that said ``Welcome Mandela.'' Some people climbed lampposts to catch a glimpse of him. Later Saturday, Mandela flew on to Britain for an overnight stopover. The ANC's office in London said Mandela would consult briefly with ANC president Oliver Tambo in Britain, but would not make any public appearances. The British Foreign Office said it could not confirm Mandela's arrival since it was an unofficial visit, but the British news agency Press Association quoted government sources as saying he had arrived safely. He was to fly to Canada on Sunday. Mandela said it was of ``special significance'' that his Dutch stop coincided with commemorations of the June 16, 1976, uprising in the black township of Soweto, which left hundreds dead. ``That is the day on which the South African government decided to shoot down our children,'' Mandela said. ``If you ignore that it is the masses of the people who put pressure on their governments, we cannot win liberation for our country.'' Earlier Saturday, Mandela met with Dutch Premier Ruud Lubbers and Foreign Minister Hans van den Broek. Mandela also was granted an audience with Queen Beatrix, a rare honor for non-governmental visitors. Mandela's Dutch stop was announced only last week as a last-minute addition to the six-week tour that is taking him to 14 countries in Africa, Europe and North America. The trip is to thank the world for pressuring the South African government to remove the ban on the ANC and free him and his colleagues. Mandela is also urging that economic, cultural, diplomatic and sports sanctions be maintained against South Africa until apartheid is completely abolished. Mandela is to arrive in New York on Wednesday and begin his 10-day U.S. visit with a ticker-tape parade in Manhattan. President Bush and Congress will receive Mandela in Washington during his eight-city visit, which also will include a speech at the United Nations. The other cities on his itinerary are Boston, Atlanta, Miami, Detroit, Los Angeles and Oakland, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Farmer Protest Suspended After Walesa Intervenes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with protest suspended. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity leader Lech Walesa persuaded farmers Saturday to suspend a protest over low milk prices that had blocked roads and shut down dairies in northern Poland. It was the second such success for Walesa in three weeks. On May 28, he got railroad workers to end a strike that was paralyzing Poland's Baltic ports. The announcement that the protest in the Mlawa region, 80 miles north of Warsaw, was suspended until July 3 came after three hours of talks between Walesa and disgruntled farmers. In both disputes, the protesters demanded government intervention to protect them from the harsh effects of the government's shock treatment to transform Poland's socialist economy into a free-market system. The government, however, has stuck to its vow not to make special concessions. The farmers complained that their local dairy, deeply in debt, has not yet been paid for milk delivered in May and that the price it paid for their milk was cut to 2 cents a quart in June, compared to 5 to 6 cents in April. The farmers began blocking the main Warsaw-Gdansk highway on Tuesday, along with local roads and the Mlawa area dairy plants themselves. Rejecting demands for an immediate rise in milk prices, the Solidarity-led government Friday night sent out scores of police equipped with tear gas, truncheons and water cannons to Wisniewo, outside Mlawa, to open the E-7 highway blocked by tractors and hundreds of protesters. When the more than 50 police vehicles rolled into town under the government's get-tough policy, the farmers reluctantly lifted the blockade of the highway. However, local roads and dairy plants remained blocked until Walesa arrived Saturday. Arriving in Warsaw from Switzerland, where he addressed a meeting of the International Labor Organization on Friday, Walesa drove straight to Mlawa to try to solve the dispute. After the talk, the farmers' protest committee, ``taking into account the higher good,'' agreed to suspend the strike at least until July 3, according to a communique given the Polish PAP news agency. Meanwhile, the farmers' union Rural Solidarity was to enter into negotiations with the government seeking ``profitable conditions for producing milk in Ciechanow province and in the country.'' Waldemar Kuczynski, a senior adviser to Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, defended the decision to threaten the farmers with force in order to reopen the highway. ``A decision to use the forces of order is not an easy decision and it is not taken with joy,'' he said on the evening TV news show Saturday. ``The government decided to undertake the decision because blocking roads violates the law and threatens to paralyze important fields of the country's life and strikes out at all people.''

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Pledges to Maintain Democratic Struggle Despite Crackdown
LaserPhoto XBUC1
DOC.TEXT: Two opposition parties on Saturday pledged to resurrect their pro-democracy movements, which were targeted in a two-day rampage by coal miners backing President-elect Ion Iliescu. Iliescu said he was contemplating creation of a national guard to protect the government. He said it would be composed ``of clean, loyal, honest people who can act resolutely at exceptional times.'' ``We know that we can rely on you,'' Iliescu told the miners Friday before sending them home. His comments were carried on Romanian radio and monitored by the BBC. The center of the city was quiet Saturday. Helmeted police with automatic weapons guarded government buildings and University Square, the site of a 53-day anti-government rally that riot police ended Wednesday by firing on demonstrators. The state news agency Rompres said six people were killed and 502 injured in violence from Wednesday through Friday, the worst in Romania since the uprising that toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu in December. At least 110 people were still hospitalized, seven of them with very serious injuries, Rompres quoted Health Ministry officials as saying. Security officials detained 1,021 suspects in the anti-government rioting, the government said Saturday. The miners had been asked to restore order on the square. Protesters gathered there had demanded ex-Communists like Iliescu be banned from politics. The miners, swinging iron bars and clubs, swarmed Bucharest on Thursday and Friday, attacking anyone they suspected of being against the government. Among their targets was the headquarters of the National Peasants Party. Standing there Saturday among shards of broken glass, smashed typewriters and furniture, party secretary-general Liviu Petrina said the struggle for democracy would continue. ``Emotionally we are ready to start today,'' he told a reporter. ``Logistically, it could take weeks.'' The Liberal Party headquarters also were trashed by the miners. Calin Tarceanu, a Liberal Party official, said leaders ``are afraid for our lives, because nobody is protecting us.'' Dinu Patriciu, another party official, said the Liberals would ``continue to function as a free political party'' despite the intimidation. The miners injured or threatened other government critics and student leaders who contended Iliescu and other key figures of the government sought to revive totalitarian rule. They also threatened to close down four opposition publications. One, the Romania Libera daily, said Saturday it had not resumed printing because its workers feared a threat by the miners to return and destroy the paper's offices even if the government allowed it to reappear. Iliescu blamed the anti-government riots on right-wing extremists, whom he charged were aided from abroad. ``We are dealing here with a broader scenario of European proportions,'' Iliescu said. ``There was a joint action of right-wing forces, which started from the presumption that right-wing forces in all East European countries could come to power.'' Radu Campeanu, leader of the opposition Liberal Party, told reporters Iliescu's accusations were childish and ``part of an old Communist pattern.'' Although Iliescu and his National Salvation Front government overwhelmingly won free elections last month, his critics demanded he and other former Communist Party leaders be banned from politics for 10 years. The Front's dominant role since Ceausescu's overthrow has left other political voices little room to express their views except on the street. There was still no word Saturday on why miners were summoned instead of relying on police or soldiers to re-establish order. Speculation about tensions between the interior and defense ministries intensified after the state Rompres news agency published an open letter, apparently from the army, disavowing responsibility for the clashes with anti-government demonstrators. Western governments condemned the violence. U.S. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Friday that all but humanitarian aid would be withheld, and the European Community postponed a trade and economic agreement with Romania. The miners, among Ceausescu's most outspoken critics, have strongly backed Iliescu, who gave them pay rises and improved their working conditions soon after taking power.

DOC.HEAD: Quiet Observance of Anniversary of Anti-Communist Leader's Funeral
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of Hungary's new democracy on Saturday paid homage to Imre Nagy, the leader of the 1956 anti-Communist uprising, on the 32nd anniversary of his execution. The quiet laying of flowers at his graveside contrasted sharply with the ceremonial reburial of Nagy's remains last year, attended by hundreds of thousands of Hungarians in a show of support for democratization. This year, government officials joined relatives of Nagy and his associates who were executed in 1958 but posthumously rehabilitated last year. The officials in attendance included Premier Jozsef Antall and Interim President Arpad Goencz, who himself was sentenced to life in prison for his role in the 1956 uprising after it was put down by Soviet troops. Hundreds of Hungarians also laid flowers at the graves. The new government was sworn in last month after March elections that relegated the reformed Communists to a minor role. The first law passed by the new parliament, elected in the first free elections in 43 years, made Oct. 23 _ the day the 1956 uprising began _ a national holiday. The new government has also gone on record as saying it wants to quit the Warsaw Pact. The Nagy government had also said Hungary would withdraw from the Pact.

DOC.HEAD: Appalachian Tour Part Of Search For Reality
DOC.TEXT: Betty Ellis, a 64-year-old Minneapolis housewife, says ``intellectual curiosity'' drew her to join nine others Sunday on a 10-day journey billed as ``Appalachia: Third World in the United States.'' Global Exchange, a non-profit research, education and action center in San Francisco that arranged the ``reality tour,'' hopes it will lead Mrs. Ellis and her fellow travelers on a path to political activism. Political awareness tours cater to a different breed from the adventure or educational trips promoted by many travel agencies, and might be considered the opposite of Club Med's ``antidote to civilization.'' Tour members give up luxury hotels, museums, monuments and romantic dinners to take the opportunity to reshape their views of the world. The $500 per person Appalachian tour, for example, will go to Tennessee, Kentucky and Virginia to visit a child care center, agricultural, food and housing projects, the Mountain Women's Exchange and the Highlander Center in New Market, Tenn., which has fought poverty, racism, sexism and environmental destruction since the 1930s. There won't be any whiskey-sipping with ``toothless old men in overalls whittling cedar sticks at a country store,'' as a Tennessee columnist wrote in conjuring up stereotypes the tourists might be looking for. Global Exchange's tours, in fact, are supposed to break down stereotypes, inspire people to get involved in community organizations, and build ties between people in developed and developing areas _ the so-called First and Third Worlds. Poverty can be found in every state _ Global Exchange is planning other U.S. trips that may include the San Francisco Bay area _ but the group chose Appalachia because of ``its inspiring example and rich history of organizing.'' ``We felt it was very important to highlight community organizing in the United States as well as the Third World,'' said Laurie Adams, tour coordinator for Global Exchange. ``We don't feel you have to go all the way to the Third World to see some of the problems that are facing communities there.'' Grassroots organizing is a key aspect of the new activism of the 1990s _ an outgrowth of the citizen diplomacy efforts of the past decade and a step beyond the protest movements of the '60s and '70s. Participants span a wide range of ages and professions. ``We encourage people on the tours to get involved afterward, but in whatever ways that are comfortable for them,'' said Adams, 24. ``We've had grandmothers come and get articles published in local papers. It's encouraging to see that. It takes some courage and wanting to have a challenge to go on these trips. But you can have a lot of fun, too.'' Global Exchange claims 5,000 members nationwide but has a staff of only five working in a modest office in an ethnically diverse part of San Francisco. Two other staff members run a store in the city that sells arts and crafts from the Third World, and two staffers work in Haiti and Honduras. The group, founded 1{ years ago, has published books and promoted speakers on U.S. policy, Third World issues and grassroots organizing. In the past year it also has run trips to Haiti, India, Honduras, El Salvador, Nicaragua, Brazil, Mozambique and Zimbabwe. Among the people who have gone on the trips are community workers and those seeking alternatives to typical vacations, ranging in age from 18 to 75 and including doctors, nurses, city officials, nuns, business people, lawyers and housewives. Rachel Chapman, a health worker in Los Angeles, went to Mozambique and Zimbabwe and said she met people in high levels in the government and families in the countryside. ``The personal interaction stimulates and helps each of us become more capable as leaders,'' she said. The trip to Appalachia initially set off a storm of adverse publicity, and in May, West Virgina was dropped from the tour. ``Of course, not all of Appalachia resembles the Third World,'' Adams said, ``just as in Brazil there are wealthy parts and poor parts. But some of the characteristics are the same. ``The resources, such as coal, are extracted for the benefit of rich outsiders while local workers live in poverty and face dangerous working conditions. A lot of the control is in the hands of distant politicians and corporate boards, not in the hands of local people. Environmental destruction is wrought by things such as the coal mining industry. And health care, education and transportation systems aren't fairly distributed.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Military Instructor Killed in Robbery in Venezuela
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to CORRECT last name of victim; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. civilian instructor at a Venezuelan air base was killed by robbers who broke into his house and slit his throat when he failed to understand their demands, officials said Saturday. The U.S. Embassy identified the victim as Mark Ward, 42. His hometown was not available. Authorities earlier identified Ward by an incorrect last name. He died Thursday evening when two armed men broke into his house in Maracay, 68 miles west of Caracas, police said. The police and the U.S. Embassy said Ward was an F-16 maintenance specialist at the Palo Negro air force base, on the outskirts of Maracay. His 28-year-old fiancee, Betzabet Herrera, was beaten up by the robbers. She told police what had happened and provided a description of the assailants. The police said Ward, whose Spanish was not good, apparently did not understand the orders the robbers shouted at him. One of them slashed his throat. The robbers got away with about $640 in cash, as well as jewelry, and television and stereo equipment, according to police. Ward was taken to the hospital by neighbors who heard Herrera's cries for help. The U.S. Embassy said Ward died of a heart attack caused by shock and loss of blood. An embassy spokesman said Ward, who had two children in the United States, is to be buried in Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Go On Rampage After Crowded Social Club is Closed
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of people angered by the closing of a crowded Hispanic social club pelted police with rocks and bottles early Saturday during a window-smashing rampage that took three hours to quell. Police asked owners of the members-only Quisquellano Lounge to clear out an estimated 250 patrons about midnight after an officer saw a window break, Lt. Joseph Rowe said. ``It was unsafe and overcrowded,'' Rowe said, adding there was no official occupancy limit. ``After several requests were made both in English and in Spanish directing everyone to leave the area, people refused to leave ... and a kind of mob psychology took over.'' Reinforcements were called in to help control the crowd that swelled to about 500 and flooded the streets surrounding the Boston suburb's central square. ``They eventually blocked the entire street. When the first arrest was made, the crowd turned on the officers and pelted them with bottles and stones,'' he said, adding that fights broke out in alleys and store windows were smashed. Fifteen people were arrested, most for investigation of disorderly conduct or failure to disperse. All face arraignment Tuesday. Rowe said no injuries were reported and the disturbance stopped short of becoming a riot because police ``showed restraint ... did not attack the crowd.'' Manuel Ortiz, secretary at the club where owners have applied for a nightclub license, said it has no liquor license and serves only soft drinks. ``We've never had any trouble here in 15 years,'' he said in a telephone interview from the club. Rowe said he did not know whether alcohol was being served at Quisquellano, but ``certainly people were under the influence.''

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Minister Suffers Heart Attack
DOC.TEXT: Israel's new foreign minister, David Levy, has apparently suffered a slight heart attack, doctors reported Saturday. Levy, a 52-year-old Likud bloc member who is seen as a possible successor to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, arrived at Haemek Hospital in the northern Israeli town of Afula from his home in nearby Beit Shean on Thursday night. He was hospitalized in a cardiac intensive care unit for chest pains, and his condition was described Saturday as good. Dr. Udi Cantor said Levy would stay at the hospital for at least a week for observation. Shamir and Levy took their posts last week in the country's new right-wing government.

DOC.HEAD: Dozens Arrested at Union March
DOC.TEXT: About 50 police officers clashed with union members trying to organize janitors during a protest march. At least 16 people were injured and 42 arrested during the melee Friday night in an affluent office complex in Century City. Alex MacPhail, a representative of the Service Employees International Union, said police waded into a crowd of 400 demonstrators swinging clubs. ``I've never seen anything like it,'' MacPhail said. ``I saw superior officers lose control of their own men.'' Sgt. William de la Torre said police were restrained and defended officers' use of force. Janitors demanding the right to unionize struck May 30 against International Service Systems, a firm hired to clean about a dozen buildings in the complex. The cleaning company has said until the janitors vote the union in, it will not negotiate with the janitors' union.

DOC.BYLINE: Cities Vie for Father's Day Creation Honors ^By RAY FORMANEK Jr.
DOC.TEXT: A Washington woman may have helped establish a national day for dad, but folks in this coal-mining town claim they laid the groundwork. ``I'd like to describe it as a good-natured rivalry,'' said Harold Goff, historian for the Central United Methodist Church, which claims to have held the first Father's Day observance on July 5, 1908. ``We've established it using several well-documented books and people who participated,'' Goff said. ``Even the greeting card companies have been receptive. About the only outfit we've gotten short shrift from is the national Father's Day Council.'' Ted Kaufman, executive director of the non-profit council based in New York, said he doesn't dispute that the town held the church service honoring fathers. ``But as far as we're concerned, the first Father's Day observance was in Spokane, Wash., by Sonora Smart Dodd in 1910,'' Kaufman said in a telephone interview. ``All we know is the movement for a national Father's Day started from that event.'' No matter who gets the credit, Hallmark Cards Inc. spokeswoman Barbara Miller said sons and daughters nationwide will mail or hand-deliver about 90 million Father's Day greeting cards this year. The holiday is the fifth-largest for greeting card manufacturers behind Christmas, Valentine's Day, Easter, and Mother's Day, the spokeswoman said from company headquarters in Kansas City, Mo. Road signs declaring Fairmont the home of Father's Day and a plaque marking the site of the first observance have been in place in since 1984, when the town first began publicizing its claim. ``We've held Father's Day services continually since 1908, but any attempt to get wider attention has kind of languished,'' Goff said. ``We're not saying we're responsible for the national holiday, just the first observance.'' Mike Archer, a spokesman for the Spokane Chamber of Commerce, said Woodrow Wilson first proclaimed Father's Day in 1916, based on Mrs. Dodd's efforts. ``I guess we'll go with that to back up our claim,'' Archer said in a telephone interview. ``We use it in our brochures about the city.'' Fairmont's claim centers on Mrs. Charles Clayton, who lobbied the congregation of the Williams Memorial combined Methodist and Episcopal Church to honor fathers after Mother's Day was celebrated in nearby Grafton two months earlier. Now a dying railroad town of about 3,000, Grafton still receives national publicity once a year as the site of the first Mother's Day service. Mrs. Dodd's father was a Civil War veteran who raised her and her five brothers alone after the death of his wife. She decided fathers should be recognized, too, after hearing a sermon about Mother's Day. Spokane celebrated Father's Day on June 19, 1910, Archer said. Kaufman said it was through Mrs. Dodd's continuing efforts that Congress in 1972 _ 57 years after official commemoration of Mother's Day _ declared the third Sunday in June to be Father's Day. There had been six previous one-shot official observances, including Wilson's first proclamation.

DOC.HEAD: Death Toll Rises to 100 at Collapsed School in Nigeria
DOC.TEXT: Workers dug Saturday to rescue children crying out for help in the rubble of a private school that collapsed in an eastern city, state-run radio said. At least 100 people were reported killed. The school in the oil city of Port Harcourt collapsed Friday when almost 200 students were attending a debate on the uncompleted third floor. The News Agency of Nigeria said Saturday at least 100 people were killed. Survivors said workmen were pounding on the walls with tools when the building began to collapse. Police sources said the owner of the building did not have a construction permit and had been arrested.

DOC.HEAD: Two Djibouti Diplomats Asking Political Asylum
DOC.TEXT: Two diplomats said Saturday they are seeking Canadian political asylum after walking out of the Republic of Djibouti's embassy here in support of dissident movements in their African homeland. ``I believe that this embassy is not the true representative of the people of my country and I cease to work for and to cooperate with this embassy as of today,'' said former counsellor Ali Dahan in a statement. He was joined in the protest by Abdulkarim Ali Amarkak, the former financial attache of the embassy. They expressed support for the Union of Democratic Movements, which they described as a Paris-based organization that unites dissident groups in opposition to the government of Hassan Gouled Aptidon, president of Djibouti since it achieved independence from France in 1977. The East African moslem country of fewer than 500,000 inhabitants, formerly French Somaliland, has long been plagued by friction between minority Afars, most of whom live in Ethiopia, and the majority Issa people, whose lands spill over into Ethiopia and Somalia. Djbouti maintains a small army but its independence is guaranteed by the presence of French forces including Foreign Legion troops. The embassy was closed Saturday, but The Washington Post in Saturday editions quoted acting Ambassador Idriss Ahmed Chirwa as saying Dahan has been suspended and ordered to return to Djibouti to face charges that he did not specify.

DOC.HEAD: Iowa Flooded While Nebraska Gets Hail
DOC.TEXT: The Raccoon River, swollen with recent rains, rose to record levels and flooded parts of Iowa and Illinois, while Nebraska was hit with hail the size of golf balls Saturday. Six inches of rain overnight brought the Raccoon River out of its banks. The crest was expected to reach Van Meter in central Iowa Sunday, nine feet above flood stage and slightly higher than the record set in 1958. The river was expected to crest at Des Moines, Iowa, near its 1947 record. Flooding closed a large number of roads and washed out bridges in northeast and east-central Iowa and northwest Illinois. And nearly 6 inches of rain left roads and basements flooded in southwestern Minnesota. The Mississippi River was more than four feet over flood stage at Red River Landing, La., and slightly higher than flood stage at Donaldsonville, La. A tornado touched down during the morning west of Monroe, La., and thunderstorm wind gusts caused damage south of Ottumwa, Iowa. Golf-ball size hail fell south of Chadron, Neb. Rainshowers and thunderstorms continued into the afternoon from upper Michigan across Wisconsin, southeastern Minnesota, northern Illinois, much of Iowa, northwest Missouri, northeast Kansas and southeast Nebraska. There were showers and storms from western Oklahoma across northwest and west-central Texas, and over southern Louisiana, Mississippi, southwest Georgia and the northern portion of the Florida peninsula. Rainshowers and some thunderstorms extended from west-central Maine into east-central New York, and over northeast Nebraska, southern South Dakota and Wyoming into north-central Utah and over northeast Oregon. Heavier rainfall during the six hours ending at 2 p.m. EDT included 3 inches at Cedar Rapids, Iowa, 2{ inches at Des Moines, Iowa, an inch at Meridian, Miss., and almost an inch at Eau Claire, Wis., and Moline, Ill. The morning low temperature of 65 degrees at Hollywood, Fla., tied its low temperature record for the date set in 1972. The nation's low Saturday morning was 29 degrees at Truckee, Calif. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 41 degrees at Yellowstone, Wyo., to 99 at the Air Force Base near San Antonio, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: With King of Quotes,Bjt
A Few Tidbits from Norman Ornstein
DOC.TEXT:
Here are some quotes from political scientist Norman Ornstein:
On passage of the congressional pay raise: ``It's a zero issue, it's gone. For all of Ralph Nader's challenges and for all of the radio talk shows, the public is not paying attention to this issue.''
On a proposal by Sen. Daniel Moynihan, D-N.Y., to cut payroll taxes: ``I don't think Moynihan proposed (it) with the expectation that it would actually happen. Maybe I'm wrong, but I think he proposed it for the shock value.''
On special interest groups paying for travel by members of Congress: ``You're going to have much more luck slamming a guy for doing it on public expense than at the expense of private interests. The public reaction is `We don't give a damn if it's taken out of special interests, but don't take it out of our pockets.'''

DOC.HEAD: ACLU Releases Report on AIDS Discrimination
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6:30 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: Fear of the AIDS virus is so prevalent in the United States that one-third of the people who reported AIDS-related discrimination do not even have the disease, an American Civil Liberties Union report said Saturday. ``This study shows how extraordinarily persistent discrimination remains in this country, even after science has proven there is no risk of casual transmission,'' said Nan D. Hunter, principal author of the study. The ACLU study, ``Epidemic of Fear,'' will be presented at the Sixth Annual Conference on AIDS in San Francisco this week. The study was compiled from information provided to the ACLU by 260 legal and advocacy groups across the country. Discrimination hurts the fight to control AIDS because many who have the disease refuse to be tested out of fear they will become victims of intolerance, experts say. About 13,000 complaints of AIDS or HIV-related discrimination came into the 260 agencies between 1983 and 1988. HIV is the virus that causes AIDS. Discrimination reports increased by 50 percent during 1988, following an 88 percent increase in 1987, the report said. The study found that AIDS-related discrimination occurs nationwide, cutting across lines of race, gender, ethnicity and sexual orientation. Even people who do not have the disease but associate with people who do are frequent targets of discrimination, the report said. Most discrimination cases were based on fears of catching the disease, racial prejudice, or anti-homosexual prejudice, according to the study. Thirty percent of the people who reported discrimination were not HIV positive, the study said. Twenty-one percent of the discrimination complaints were from victims who thought they were targeted due to their risk of becoming HIV positive through a job, lifestyle or other factors. Nine percent felt they were the victims of discrimination merely because of their proximity to someone who was HIV positive. That closeness might be through a family relationship or by providing care or some type of services to an infected person, the report said. ``HIV discrimination is the No. 1 obstacle to controlling the epidemic in this country because people are afraid to come forward and be tested,'' said Carisa Cunningham, a spokeswoman for the Gay Men's Health Crisis in New York. ``We are not able to reach people'' because discrimination makes them afraid to come forward. Recommendations for fighting HIV-related discrimination include upgrading enforcement of anti-discrimination laws, training lawyers in HIV-related issues and tightening the regulation of insurance practices. Consistent anti-discrimination laws are needed around the country because some states have strict laws while others have no laws, the study said. Enforcement of The Americans with Disabilities Act, which takes effect in 1992, must become a top priority in the next decade, Ms. Hunter said. The act bans discrimination against people with disabilities, including people who are HIV positive, and will make it possible to file discrimination charges in federal court. The report was hailed by Dr. Mervyn Silverman, American Foundation for AIDS Research president, who said it points out how much still needs to be done in the area of AIDS education. ``Polls show that a significant percentage of Americans know AIDS is spread through sex and drugs,'' Silverman said. ``But at least 25 percent still believe it could be spread casually and when asked, they said the best way to avoid getting the disease is to not be associated with anyone who has the disease.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Counter-Spy Chief Calls for KGB to be Disbanded
DOC.TEXT: A self-described former KGB intelligence chief said Saturday that the spy agency _ still feared despite Soviet reforms _ has too much power and should be closed down. Up until now, no former KGB official here has publicly proposed that the agency be dismantled. As a rule, KGB officials who break with the agency flee abroad or disappear. ``The KGB has too much political power, and this way will remain a threat to democracy because it may be manipulated,'' said Oleg D. Kalugin, who identified himself as a onetime major general in charge of foreign counterintelligence. ``I would abolish the KGB as such,'' said Kalugin, 55, who spoke with reporters after a speech to the Democratic Platform, Communist Party members who are considering breaking with the party. He displayed what he said were his KGB credentials, but no one could be reached at the agency Saturday to comment on Kalugin's remarks or verify his former title. However, CIA spokesman Mark Mansfield in Washington confirmed a man named Oleg Danilovich Kalugin was at one time a KGB major general in charge of foreign counterintelligence. ``We find it encouraging that an increasing number of Soviet officials are speaking so candidly,'' Mansfield said. ``We think there is some merit in this suggestion'' of disbanding the KGB, he said. The urbane, well-dressed Kalugin, who said he spent 12 years as an operative in the United States, said the KGB supports Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev. But the former official _ who said he was drummed out of the KGB this spring _ warned that criticism of the Soviet president is increasing and that KGB chief Vladimir A. Kryuchkov ``will turn with the tide.'' Kryuchkov, appointed by Gorbachev less than two years ago, has been more open than any of his predecessors. He and his top deputies have granted interviews to Soviet and foreign media, and a documentary film about the agency has been released. The KGB has long been thought to be one of the organizations that brought Gorbachev to power five years ago. The KGB, or Committee on State Security, once terrorized Soviet citizens and harassed foreigners. It has said it is re-orienting itself toward the struggle against organized crime and drug trafficking in cooperation with other foreign intelligence agencies. Foreign residents of Moscow notice much less surveillance than in the past. Kalugin revealed no secrets during his appearance and did not discuss specific KGB cases. But he said he still feared repercussions. ``For the time being, it is only publicity that can curb the KGB,'' he told reporters. The Supreme Soviet legislature formally oversees the agency but has done nothing to rein it in, he said. Kalugin said KGB agents are still spreading disinformation about leaders of the political reform movement, still tapping telephones, still playing dirty tricks. Kalugin said legitimate domestic KGB operations should be placed under the Interior Ministry, which is responsible for uniformed police. Intelligence services should be placed directly under the president, and KGB border guards should be transferred to control of the customs service, he said. Boris N. Yeltsin, the radical reformer and new president of the Russian Federation, has made a similar proposal _ to merge the KGB into a single investigations agency. Kalugin, who speaks English well, said he worked from 1958-1970 as a KGB agent in the United States, first as a Radio Moscow correspondent and then as a first secretary in the Soviet Embassy in Washington. He said he was certain during his tour in the United States that the CIA had identified him as a spy, but no action was taken against him.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Accused Of Child Abuse For Drinking Gives Birth To Healthy Baby
DOC.TEXT: A woman who was cleared of child-abuse charges that alleged she drank too much while pregnant has given birth to an apparently healthy boy, a doctor said. Diane Pfannenstiel had her baby Thursday evening, said Dr. Katherine Kohler, an obstetrician here. ``He's a beautiful, healthy 7-pound boy,'' Kohler said. ``As far as anyone can identify, he seems to have no problems. The mother is also doing well. We are all very pleased.'' Pfannenstiel, 29, was about four months pregnant when she was arrested Jan. 4, two months after another judge ordered her to remain alcohol-free. A test revealed she had a blood alcohol level of just over 0.1 percent, the level at which a person is considered intoxicated under state law. Albany County Attorney Cal Rerucha said he filed the child-abuse charge to protect Pfannenstiel's unborn children from suffering an ailment such as fetal alcohol syndrome. But Judge Robert Denhardt dismissed the complaint, saying the state did not produce probable cause that her fetus had been injured. The defense never presented witnesses, winning the dismissal after the state closed its case. Pfannenstiel's attorney, Mary Elizabeth Galvan, said the birth in effect vindicates her client. ``If prosecutors had their way, she'd (have) had this baby in jail,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Feds Try Rescue of Sea Turtles as Slick Moves Towards Shore
With AM-Dirty Coast, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Loggerhead sea turtles were threatened by crude oil creeping closer to shore from the crippled supertanker Mega Borg, which spewed more goo into the Gulf of Mexico on Saturday. Divers were planning a rescue mission to pluck about five loggerhead turtles from waters near the slick's leading edge, said Edward Klima of the National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration. Loggerhead turtles are a threatened species that can grow up to 4 feet long and weigh up to 200 pounds, he said. He said if the turtles eat floating tar balls, mistaking them for food, they could die. No other marine life appeared to be threatened, he said. About 4.6 million gallons of oil have spilled from the Norwegian tanker since it was rocked by an explosion June 8, Coast Guard Lt. Cmdr. Frank Whipple said Saturday. The figure makes the Mega Borg spill the fifth-worst in U.S. history. Coast Guard officials believe most of that oil _ all but 12,000 to 40,000 gallons _ evaporated or burned in the inferno following the explosion. The remaining slick is ``almost hanging out there,'' Whipple said. The 45-mile-long slick of Angolan crude oil was about 20 miles from Galveston. Coastal authorities braced for an onslaught of oil that could reach Texas beaches as early as Sunday, but might not reach shore for several days, said Sharon Christopherson of NOAA. Where the oil slick might wash ashore was uncertain, but the latest estimate identified an area between the west end of Galveston Island and High Island as the most likely landfall. About 1,200 volunteers were being trained on how to clean up any oil reaching shore. Tony Redding, spokesman for Smit America Salvage Inc., said the fire aboard the 886-foot tanker was declared extinguished Saturday morning. Crews continued to douse the hull of the ship throughout the day to cool the buckled Mega Borg so workers could begin removing its cargo. A small, undetermined amount of oil leaked from the ship Saturday, Whipple said. Geert Koffeman, project manager for Smit America, said the possibility of the vessel sinking was ``next to nil.'' Skimmers and booms were used on concentrated oil spots, but most of the slick was too thin to skim. Texas General Land Office representatives, meanwhile, said they were pleased with an experiment started Friday when oil-eating bacteria were dumped on a square acre of the slick. ``Visually, the results of the microbes are very promising, but we have no hard science. I'm very optimistic,'' said Blanton Moore of the Land Office. He said it was difficult to tell from the air if the oil had been eaten by the bacteria or dissipated some other way, adding that more microbes will likely be used later.

DOC.HEAD: Cyprus Orders Transfusion for Toddler
DOC.TEXT: A 2-year-old girl suffering from leukemia was given a blood transfusion Saturday by government order, despite the religious objections of her parents. The girl's parents, Titos and Eleni Charalambous, are Jehovah's Witnesses, a fundamentalist Christian sect that forbids blood transfusions. They had snatched their daughter from a British hospital, where she was being treated, to avoid a blood transfusion and later defied a Cypriot court's order to agree to a transfusion. In an unprecedented move, the government Friday declare the child, Stephanie, a ward of the state, making the transfusion possible without the family's approval. ``We had to rescue the child from death,'' said Helen Soteriou, a British-born leukemia expert at Nicosia's Evangelistria Clinic. She conducted the transfusion. ``It was obvious we couldn't change their minds. Their convictions are too strong. But we had a child's life at stake,'' she added. George Marcoulis, a cancer specialist at the private clinic, told reporters ``there is a great improvement in the girl's condition'' after an initial transfusion of one pint of blood. ``Her chances of survival are definitely in the range of 60-80 percent,'' Marcoulis said. Leukemia is an often fatal cancer of the blood. Health Minister Panikos Papageorgiou, himself a physician, told Cyprus Television on Saturday, ``The improvement in Stephanie's condition justifies the action we took yesterday in making her a ward of the social welfare department.'' He said the government would bear the costs of all further treatment for the child. But Stephanie's father said: ``I didn't see any improvement. I still feel very unhappy that someone else's blood is in my daughter's veins.'' ``Nobody can love my child as much as I do,'' he had told reporters Friday. ``We'll do everything possible and sell all our belongings if necessary, with the full support of the rest of my family, to save Stephanie's life. But we cannot agree to a blood transfusion,'' he said. Cyprus President George Vassiliou visited Stephanie and said afterward the government respects religious beliefs, but he said in this case intervention was necesary ``for the safety of the child.'' Stephanie's parents snatched her from London's Great Ormond Street Hospital on Monday to prevent her from being given a transfusion. They returned to Cyprus, defying a British court order that the transfusion should go ahead. The family went into hiding after a Cypriot court ordered a transfusion. Police issued arrest warrants for the parents and launched a search to find them in a bid to save the girl's life. The warrants were withdrawn after Stephanie's parents took her to the Evangelistria Clinic on Thursday. But later that day, the couple again took Stephanie into hiding until police tracked them down Friday and placed Stephanie under state care. Day-long efforts by doctors at the clinic Friday to persuade the parents to permit a transfusion proved futile.

DOC.HEAD: Battle in Batter Ends For Another Year
DOC.TEXT: Victory tasted sweet Saturday for Okmulgee Pecan Festival participants fighting for the world record for the largest pecan cookie. ``I think we've got it,'' baker Max Keck said. A crowd gathered 20-deep around the special oven Keck built on Main Street to sample the cookie that he said was 32 feet in diameter. The mayor had the first slice Saturday morning of Okmulgee's latest entry in a pastry war with rival world pecan capital Moultrie, Ga.
