The two towns have vied with each other since 1987 to win biggest-pecan-pie honors in the Guinness Book of World Records. Okmulgee made it last year, with a 40-foot pie. Moultrie declined to up the pie ante last year, choosing instead to bake a giant pecan cookie in October. Keck said Saturday the 7,500-pound Okmulgee cookie won out, by one foot and at least 4,500 pounds. He said the Moultrie cookie was 3,000 pounds. Keck built an oven with a tray mounted on wheels to make the cookie. ``They may try to beat it,'' he said. ``We'll just beat it again, next year.''

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Government Proposes Moratorium on Independence Act
With AM-Soviet-Miners, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf `The delegates...' with two grafs to UPDATE with details, quotes from meeting of pro-independence movements. No Pickup
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania on Saturday proposed that its parliament compromise with the Kremlin and impose a moratorium on its declaration of independence, officials said. The proposal from the republic's Council of Ministers appeared to coincide with a compromise offered Tuesday by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and the official news agency Tass said it ``could mark the beginning of the solution of all the so-called `Lithuanian problems.''' Also Saturday, Soviet authorities began pumping natural gas to a fertilizer plant in Lithuania, partly easing the 2-month-old blockade of fuel they imposed to pressure the Baltic republic into renouncing its March 11 declaration of independence. The Lithuanian government suggested the declaration remain valid but its implementation be frozen while negotiations were under way with Moscow, said Algis Cekuolis, a consultant for the Baltic republic. However, Cekuolis said it was unclear whether the compromise would have enough support to be passed by the republic's legislature, which will probably consider it Monday. ``It will be received in parliament by very strong opposition,'' he predicted. The Lithuanian government, under Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene, is considered far more disposed to compromise with the Kremlin than the parliament, which is led by President Vytautas Landsbergis and dominated by members of the pro-independence Sajudis popular front. Gorbachev proposed compromises Tuesday in a meeting with the leaders of the three secessionist Baltic states. He told the national Supreme Soviet legislature earlier that day that ``if Lithuania will suspend the implementation of this act of independence, we may start to talk. That means suspend its implementation at least for the duration of the talks.'' Saturday's proposal by the Lithuanian Council of Ministers suggested exactly that, government spokesmen said. ``Our act of independence would remain valid,'' said council spokesman Gentaras Jatkonis. ``But we are postponing the realization of it.'' Similar proposals have gone back and forth between the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius and Moscow in telegrams and informal talks ``like a ping-pong game'' for weeks but ``this is the first time it's on an official level,'' Cekuolis said. A spokesman for the Lithuanian parliament, Aidas Palubinskas, said he was told on Saturday by a pipeline dispatcher that natural gas was again flowing from the Soviet Union to the Azotas fertilizer plant in the city of Jonova. ``The plant will be getting 3.5 million cubic meters daily,'' Palubinskas was told by dispatcher Alexander Mishikov. Restoration of the gas supply fulfilled a promise made to Mrs. Prunskiene on Wednesday by Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov that 15 percent of the republic's daily natural gas supply would be restored. Politburo member Yuri D. Maslyukov told a news conference in Moscow on Friday that the restoration of fuel to the Lithuanian plant was a goodwill gesture from the Kremlin and a ``reiteration of the Soviet government's interest in speeding negotiations.'' More than 26,000 people have lost their jobs because of the Kremlin's blockade of all oil, most natural gas and some raw materials. Palubinskas said that restoration of gas supplies to the Azotas plant would mean 1,600 employees could return to work by the end of this week. At the beachfront resort of Jurmala in Latvia, leaders of the popular fronts of Latvia and Estonia and the Sajudis movement of Lithuania opened a conference to discuss the future of their movements under democratically elected governments. The delegates, 50 from each of the pro-independence movements, condemned the economic sanctions against Lithuania and discussed ways of increasing cooperation among the Baltic states and with other Soviet republics, Tass reported. ``Nobody has a right to demand either abrogation or halting the acts of independence,'' Tass quoted delegates as saying. ``A retreat will harm the democratic movement.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Apologize for Drug Raid on Racing Commissioner's House
DOC.TEXT: Police looking for a marijuana-growing operation mistakenly raided the home of the state's Horse Racing Commission chairman, whose wife says officers threw her to the ground and frightened her 90-year-old mother. An apology was made to Warren Chinn and his family, and an investigation is under way, said police Chief Patrick Fitzsimons. Chinn's wife, Honoria Chinn, 50, said Friday she was at home with her mother about 12:45 a.m. Tuesday when her front door was broken open and at least five plainclothes officers rushed inside. Mrs. Chinn said one of the men grabbed the telephone she was holding, handcuffed her, threw her facedown on the floor, put a gun to her head and demanded, ``Where's the man, where is he?'' The officers gave no warning before battering down the door and offered no identification, she said. ``I'm still in shock,'' Mrs. Chinn said. ``I can't sleep. I get nightmares every time I close my eyes.'' The Chinns said police officers apparently used a chemical spray to subdue their two dogs, which were outside. After emptying drawers in two bedrooms and checking the rest of the house, the officers left, Mrs. Chinn said. ``They didn't say a word,'' said Mrs. Chinn, whose niece, Maxine Chan, is a Police Department specialist on relations with the city's Asian community. Police were acting on information from a person arrested for possession of marijuana, said department spokesman Mark Amundson. It was ``completely the wrong location,'' said Fitzsimons. ``It was a mistake of great magnitude as far as we are concerned,'' the chief said. Chinn, who owns two Seattle-area restaurants and was at one of the restaurants when the raid occurred, said his wife was in her nightclothes and talking to a restaurant employee when the officers broke down the door with a battering ram. ``She thought somebody was robbing the house,'' he said. ``She didn't know they were police because they were all in plainclothes.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Supreme Court Denies Stay, Execution Slated for Monday
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Supreme Court on Saturday denied condemned killer John Edward Swindler's last-ditch bid to avoid becoming Arkansas' first prisoner executed in 26 years. The Supreme Court denied the stay request in a 7-2 ruling issued shortly before noon, with Justices William Brennan and Thurgood Marshall dissenting, said high court spokeswoman Toni House. Swindler, 46, is scheduled to be electrocuted at 9 p.m. Monday for the 1976 murder of a Fort Smith police officer. He would become the first person put to death in the state since 1964. Attorney Gerald Coleman said he told Swindler of the high court's decision by telephone and that he ``took it like a man.'' ``He didn't break up, but he was disappointed,'' Coleman said. ``He thanked me for calling him and doing what I could.'' The lawyer said Swindler had reached the end of the line in his appeals process. ``There's nothing left to do. I know of no other options,'' he said. Attorneys for Swindler appealed to the Supreme Court on Friday, after the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in St. Louis turned down his request for a stay Thursday, the same day Gov. Bill Clinton rejected an application for executive clemency. The lawyer said Swindler's mood Saturday was somber. ``He hopes that this execution will make the people of Arkansas think about capital punishment in general, to think twice about executing anybody else on death row.'' Clinton was not immediately available for comment Saturday, spokesman Mike Gauldin said. James Lee of the state attorney general's office, said prosecutors were ready to fight any further attempts to block Swindler's execution. ``There are nearly 72 hours between now and Monday night and anything can happen,'' Lee said on Saturday. Amnesty International, which opposes capital punishment, scheduled a 25-minute silent protest vigil Sunday night at the state Capitol. Swindler was moved to a death cell adjacent to the death chamber at the Cummins Maximum Security Unit on Friday. He waived his option to choose his last meal and told officials they could destroy his personal belongings. Earlier in the week, Swindler waived his choice between electrocution or death by lethal injection. Swindler was convicted in 1978 of the Sept. 24, 1976, death of Fort Smith Patrolman Randy Basnett, who was shot twice in the chest as he tried to arrest Swindler, who was wanted for murder in South Carolina. Before the Arkansas killing, Swindler killed Gregg Becknell, 19, and Dorothy Rhodes, 18, after forcing them from their car on a junior college campus in Columbia, S.C. He told police he sodomized and beat the man and shot him, then beat and shot the woman. After exhausting his state appeals, Swindler filed a petition in federal court and in 1988 U.S. District Judge Henry Woods ruled that he had received a fair trial. A year later, the decision was upheld by the three-judge panel in St. Louis. The last Arkansas execution came in 1964, when Charles Franklin Fields was electrocuted.

DOC.HEAD: University: Lambs Carrying Leukemia Virus Handled By Unwitting Humans
DOC.TEXT: University of Pennsylvania veterinary students and staff handling sheep may have been exposed to a leukemia virus and 100 pre-schoolers were among visitors allowed to pet the research animals. School officials asked 20 possibly exposed students and staff members to undergo blood tests and offered to make the tests available to the children and other visitors in a meeting with the parents Friday night. There is little chance anyone became infected by touching the lambs inoculated with the virus HTLV-1, known to cause adult T-cell leukemia, medical experts said. ``If I were a parent of one the children, I would not be worried,'' said William Blattner, chief of the epidemiology section of the National Cancer Institute. ``You can't spread this virus by petting a sheep.'' The inoculated sheep were supposed to have been kept separate from a flock of about 150 other sheep at the New Bolton Center, said Aron B. Fisher, a professor of physiology and the school's oversight committee chairman. Researcher Jorge F. Ferrer allegedly violated school regulations by failing to quarantine the sheep inoculated between April 13 and April 24, officials said. The exposure was discovered in early June. Ferrer was suspended pending an investigation expected to take about a week. Efforts by The Associated Press to reach Ferrer for comment by telephone weren't immediately successful. The inoculated lambs are believed to have been among sheep that were castrated and had their tails bobbed by eight veterinary students and 12 staff members sometime before May 16, officials said. About 100 students from the private Kennett Square Cooperative Pre-School were allowed to pet the lambs when they visited the center on May 16 and May 22, school officials said. Thirty adult visitors also could have come in contact with the sheep. The HTLV-1 virus linked to the sometimes fatal blood cancer is communicated through blood, mother's milk and sexual intercourse, Penn scientists said. ``It's a very minimal risk,'' said Barry Cooperman, university vice provost for research. Permission for the viral experiment by Ferrer, a physician and professor of microbiology at Penn's School of Veterinary Medicine, hinged on the sheep remaining isolated, Fisher said. Edwin J. Andrews, dean of the veterinary school, said the university discovered that the flock included inoculated sheep on May 24 after another researcher asked if the animals had been used in other experiments. Officials established that humans had come in contact with the sheep early this month. Andrews said the likelihood of true infection was extremely slim, especially among those who merely petted the lambs. ``The virus is very fragile and can only be transmitted in a human setting when it's in live cells,'' Andrews said.

DOC.HEAD: Menendez Pychologist Testifies Behind Closed Doors
DOC.TEXT: A psychologist who treated two brothers charged with killing their wealthy parents testified in closed hearings that were held to decide whether recordings of their therapy sessions should remain confidential. Beverly Hills psychologist Jerome Oziel was questioned in private Thursday and Friday in the hearings in the case against Lyle and Erik Menendez. Testimony from Judalon Rose Smyth, a former patient of Oziel who contacted police after learning of allegedly incriminating statements the Menendez brothers made to him, was postponed Friday until June 27. News media including The Associated Press, the Los Angeles Times and ABC-TV earlier this month lost an attempt to be present at the hearings. Superior Court Judge James Albracht ordered the courtroom cleared on grounds the discussions would center on whether the exchanges were privileged doctor-patient communications and therefore inadmissible as evidence. Lyle, 22, and Erik Menendez, 19, are accused of murdering their parents. Jose Menendez, 45, and his wife, Kitty, 44, died Aug. 20 in the family's Beverly Hills mansion after being repeatedly shot with shotgun blasts. The brothers claim they found the bodies when they returned home from a night out. Prosecutors allege the siblings were motivated to kill their parents to claim the wealth of their father, an executive of Live Entertainment Inc., a video distribution company. The brothers' arrest in March occurred after Oziel turned tape recordings over to authorities. Law enforcement authorities have said the tapes contain confessions by both brothers as well as threats made against Oziel and others. Smyth, 37, has sued Oziel, 43, alleging physical and sexual assault and fraud. Oziel has denied the charges and said he and Smyth were never intimate. Smyth's attorney, Fred Rucker, said he also filed a complaint against Oziel with the state Board of Medical Quality Assurance.

DOC.HEAD: European Nations Target East Bloc Pollution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with communique signed; pickup graf 8 pvs `East Germany...'
DOC.TEXT: Environment ministers from across Europe agreed Saturday to work at cleaning up heavy pollution in East bloc nations. ``The problems that have been described were horrendous and far beyond our forecasts,'' Environment Commissioner Carlo Ripa di Meana of the European Community said. He spoke after ministers from seven Eastern European nations reported on pollution in their countries at a one-day meeting in Dublin with ministers of the European Community. The ministers from 19 nations planned an attack on industrial contamination of the air, water and land that has built up over decades. They signed a communique setting out ideas to tackle nuclear and toxic waste, acid rain and water pollution in the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe. It stressed that protection of the environment was one of the most urgent political priorities. The agreement commits Poland, the Soviet Union, Hungary, Yugoslavia, East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria and the European Community members to look at ways of effective pollution monitoring and curbing harmful practices that poison the environment. The nations also called for the establishment of a new European Environment Agency, open to countries outside the European Community, to help ease the way for the cleanup. The ministers heard a catalogue of pollution misery in Eastern Europe. Environment Minister Josef Vavrousek of Czechoslovakia, complaining of pollution in his nation, said life expectancy in his nation was 67 years, five years lower than the average for Western Europe. Vavrousek said that until the late 1950s, his country's life expectancy rate was increasing to about 70 years. Since then, the rate had fallen in some areas of worst pollution. He said that in some heavily polluted areas like northern Bohemia, the life expectancy is 10 years below the Western European average. The ministers said one of the leading causes of pollution in Eastern Europe was the massive emissions of sulphur dioxide from coal-burning power stations. East Germany has announced plans to reduce its acid rain levels by switching from lignite to hard coal at power stations, and to use more oil and gas. That country's environment minister, Karl Steinberg, said the oldest and dirtiest power stations would be closed and clean coal technology would be introduced. His country is aiming to cut its energy consumption by up to 2.5 percent over the next decade and reduce carbon dioxide emissions by at least 20 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Liberian Government, Rebels Agree to Cease-Fire
DOC.TEXT: The government of Liberia and rebel forces on Saturday called for a cease-fire in their 5{-month-old civil war that has left more than 1,000 people dead. Government forces and rebels from the National Patriotic Front had not clashed for the last 10 days, but Saturday's agreement was the first time the two sides agreed to a cease-fire. The truce came Saturday after five days of peace talks in the U.S. Embassy in Freetown in this neighboring country. In a statement issued after the meeting, the two sides agreed to resume talks Monday. ``Meanwhile, it is the expectation of both parties that each side will exercise self-restraint in the use of military force,'' the two sides said in a statement. The sides also agreed to permit international relief aid to civilians in areas under their control. Their statement also said government soldiers and rebel fighters would be permitted to inspect shipments to the opposing side. Earlier Saturday, the Liberian government had proposed a 30-day cease-fire. The rebels have repeatedly demanded that President Samuel K. Doe resign and leave Liberia before a formal truce can be signed. They accuse him of corruption and human rights abuses. Doe has steadfastly refused to resign. The Liberian Council of Churches, which is mediating the peace talks, had been pushing for a cease-fire. The victims have been mostly civilians. The government regained control of the American-managed Bridgestone-Firestone rubber plantation outside the Liberian capital, Monrovia, and the nearby Robertsfield international airport before fighting died down. Though the airport remains closed, its recapture by government troops was the first major setback for the rebels since they invaded from neighboring Ivory Coast on Dec. 24. Four U.S. Navy ships carrying 2,100 Marines are anchored off Liberia's Atlantic coast in case an emergency evacuation of U.S. citizens is needed. Nearly 150,000 refugees have fled Liberia, and thousands of foreign nationals have been evacuated. The U.S. Embassy said a chartered air flight would evacuate more citizens Sunday. The war, which began as a rebel insurgency, has escalated into tribal warfare. Human rights organizations accuse soldiers of killing people from the Gio and Mano ethnic groups, who have backed the rebels. Rebels have retaliated by killing Krahns and Mandingos, accused of supporting Doe, who is a Krahn. About 5 percent of Liberia's 2 million people are the descendants of freed American slaves who founded this West African nation in 1847. They oppose Doe, who seized power in a 1980 coup that ousted Americo-Liberians from power.

DOC.HEAD: Arrests Hit 174 in Nationwide Roundup of Drug-Dealing Gang Suspects
DOC.TEXT: Arrests totaled 174 by Saturday in a nationwide dragnet for members of violent, drug-dealing street gangs, authorities said. Federal agents and local police in 11 states began executing warrants Thursday in a crackdown aimed at the Crips and Bloods, which have grown from Los Angeles street gangs into multistate drug-dealing operations. Despite the scope of the roundup and volume of arrests, Operation Streetsweep was going safely, according to Jack Killorian, spokesman for the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms in Washington, D.C. ``We've had no injuries, no shooting incidents,'' he said. Arrests and seizures of drugs and weapons were expected to continue through the weekend. More than 200 arrests were anticipated. Arrests were made in California, Louisiana, Arizona, New Mexico, Texas, Missouri, Oklahoma, Oregon, Washington and two other states that weren't identified because warrants were still being served. Air Force C-5A transport planes were used in the operation to shuttle ATF agents and vehicles from Dover Air Force Base, Del., across the country. Andrew Vita, the ATF chief in Los Angeles, said Friday that the gangs have ``staked out a large portion of the cocaine trafficking in this country'' and have been identified in 32 states and 69 cities outside California. The operation against them had been planned for months, and Killorian said Saturday that it was so successful that authorities will do it again. ``We'll be back,'' he said, declining to name a specific date. ``The element of surprise is an important part of achieving safety to everyone, as was shown.''

DOC.HEAD: Greece Protests Over Yugoslav Border Blockade
DOC.TEXT: Greece protested to Yugoslavia and the European Community on Saturday after Yugoslav shopkeepers blocked the border between the two countries for the second time in a month. ``Not only is the border blocked illegally, but Greek-Yugoslav relations worsen dangerously,'' the Foreign Ministry said in a statement. Several hundred shopkeepers and craftsmen from the southern Yugoslav republic of Macedonia blocked the border with cars and trucks early Friday. Thousands of vehicles were backed up at the three border posts by early afternoon when a local radio station called for an end to the blockade, said Prokopios Mantzouranis, Greece's consul in the Macedonian capital of Skopje. Macedonia is one of the six republics that comprise Yugoslavia. Demonstrators were demanding the abolition of Greek visas for Yugoslavs and recognition for ethnic Macedonians in Greece. The demonstration was similar to a one-day border traffic blockade on May 19. Greece does not recognize Macedonians as an ethnic minority. The Foreign Ministry said Saturday the Yugoslav ambassador in Athens was summoned ``and the necessary representations were made.'' The Greek ambassador in Belgrade conveyed a similar protest to the Yugoslav Foreign Ministry on Friday. Greece also protested to the European Commission that Yugoslavia was isolating Greece from the rest of the community. Yugoslavia forms the principal land link between Greece and other European Community members.

DOC.HEAD: Three Paintings Vandalized At Nelson-Atkins Museum
DOC.TEXT: Three paintings at the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art were found with deep scratches blamed on a disgruntled employee. Scratches were found in the paint of two 16th-century German works and in an 1880 painting by French Impressionist Edouard Manet, said museum spokeswoman Lisa Austin. The scratches were about as deep as a pen point, she said. Three other paintings were found with faint pencil marks on them, but that marring was not thought to have been deliberate, or even recently done. The German works damaged Friday were ``Portrait of a Bearded Man'' painted by Lucas Cranach the Younger in 1538, and ``Betrothal Portrait of a Lady'' a 1558 work by Barthel Bruyn the Younger. Both are part of the museum's permanent collection. A scratch was found shortly after the gallery closed Thursday in Manet's ``Still Life with Brioche,'' on loan from the Carnegie Museum of Art in Pittsburgh. Museum conservator Forrest Bailey said he believed a disgruntled employee was responsible. ``There were no patrons in the museum and no visitors,'' he said. ``Only staff were present.'' ``These things take but a few seconds to do,'' Bailey said. ``It's a sick, unhappy, disturbed person.'' The three scratched works were removed from display. The German works, on exhibit in rooms separate from the Manet, suffered the worst damage. ``We believe it was the same person who attacked the Manet,'' Bailey said. ``At least I believe it was. It was a quick, sudden movement, like done in anger.'' No arrests were made in the case and no damage estimate was available. The value of the paintings would not be released for security reasons, Ms. Austin said.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Demonstrate For Evicted Families Camping in Streets
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of protesters rallied Saturday in support of dozens of families living in outdoor camps since being evicted from their apartments. The demonstration was the latest in a growing uproar over a housing shortage in Paris and a war on squatters declared by the city in March. The 78-year-old Abbe Pierre, France's premier champion of the needy, led the march from the Place de la Republique to Chatelet in the heart of Paris. Since May 2, 48 families have been living in tents at the Place de la Reunion in eastern Paris after being evicted from the apartments where they had been squatters. Nine other families evicted from buildings that are to be renovated were camping at the foot of the famous Montmartre basilica, Sacre Coeur, and at least six families were camping in front of a local administrative building in eastern Paris. They all said they will remain in their tent camps until the city provides them with alternative housing. ``Paris and all large cities will likely be very beautiful tomorrow, housing only people with means,'' Abbe Pierre told the crowd at the rally. ``But they will be cursed by hundreds of ghettos surrounding them, nests of despair, hate, crime, broken families.'' Police estimated the protesters at about 3,000. Organizers said there were tens of thousands present. The city declared its offensive on squatters on March 15, when the traditional winter moratorium on evictions ended. City officials said squatting had reached unacceptable proportions and sent riot police in to start clearing buildings. Evictions have temporarily stopped with the growing protest movement. Critics say the city is trying to drive the poor out of town, as property values steadily rise amid a wave of real estate speculation recently condemned by President Francois Mitterrand, a Socialist. Premier Michel Rocard last week appointed a mediator between the protesters and the city to try to resolve the dispute.

DOC.HEAD: Gay Rights Demonstrators Protest Outside Ordination Ceremony
DOC.TEXT: About 1,000 gay rights demonstrators staged a noisy but generally peaceful protest outside Holy Cross Cathedral Saturday as 11 priests were ordained inside. Church spokesman John Walsh said the ceremonies, conducted by Cardinal Bernard Law, proceeded without interruption. Boston police Detective George Noonan said one person was arrested, a lone counterdemonstrator. The charges against him were not immediately available. A coalition of gay-rights groups organized the demonstration to oppose ``Cardinal Law's interference in public policy as well as his opposition to AIDS education,'' a statement said. James M. Claiborne, a deputy police superintendent on the scene, said the crowd peaked at 1,000 people during the three-hour protest. Chanting slogans and carrying signs _ including some reading ``Outlaw Cardinal Law'' and ``Curb Your Dogma'' _ the demonstrators marched in a circle outside the cathedral behind police barriers. Protesters blew horns every 10 minutes to mark the rate at which AIDS patients die. Several demonstrators crossed the barriers to approach the church. Police put them back behind the barriers, Noonan said. At one point, a priest leaving the cathedral was pelted with condoms. Demonstrators said they were trying to stop Law's ``religious tyranny.'' ``I was at Boston City Hospital last week where a teen-ager died of AIDS contracted through sex,'' said Steven Tierney, co-chairman of the Massachusetts Gay and Lesbian Political Caucus. ``I think the church has to take some responsibility for that. They won't let us teach kids about safe sex.'' Walsh said those inside the cathedral heard only a ``rumble'' from the demonstrations outside. ``Is the church going to change its moral teaching with regard to sexuality? No,'' he said. ``We've been at this for 2,000 years. And we will be here as long as it takes.''

DOC.HEAD: Researcher Warns Washington on Entry Restrictions for AIDS Carriers
DOC.TEXT: The French researcher who discovered the AIDS virus demanded Saturday that the United States repeal its ban on granting entry to people testing positive for the virus. The ban has prompted dozens of international organizations and agencies to call for a boycott of an international AIDS meeting in San Francisco this week. France and Switzerland have said they will not send official delegations to the meeting. The French researcher, Luc Montagnier, said he would attend the Sixth International Conference on AIDS, but he said it would be the last conference on American soil if the United States failed to repeal the ban. ``The American restrictions are completely unacceptable, and it is being said out loud that we are going only to save this conference'' Montagnier said in a recording for Canal Sante, a cable television channel for health professionals. ``But it is clear that the next American conference ... which is to take place in Boston, will not take place if the American law is not changed,'' he said. The Boston conference on Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome is scheduled for 1992. Montagnier led the French research team at the Pasteur Institute which discovered the AIDS virus. Under a law passed in 1987 by the U.S. Congress, infection with the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, which causes AIDS, was added to the list of contagious diseases for which foreigners can be barred from entering the country. AIDS is a deadly disease that attacks the body's immune system, leaving victims susceptible to a wide variety of infections and cancers. A person can carry the AIDS virus without having the disease and its symptoms, though infection in almost all cases leads to the disease.

DOC.HEAD: AP Launches New Photo System
DOC.TEXT: A revolutionary system for transmitting photos was showcased for publishers over the weekend, and executives of The Associated Press called it the most ambitious technical undertaking in the wire service's history. John Reid, vice president and director of communications and technology for the wire service, said the AP's new PhotoStream was just in the talking stage three years ago and now the technology is ``right around the corner.'' ``We're on target, the system is in production and exceeds our expectations,'' Reid told newspaper executives attending the 62nd annual technical exposition of the American Newspaper Publishers Association. The AP will begin scheduling the PhotoStream system to its 950 photo members by the end of June, Reid said. The new system will be installed at all photo members within two years, said Dave Tomlin, deputy director of membership. ``This is the most ambitious technical undertaking in the history of AP,'' Tomlin said. The system will deliver a black and white print to photo members in as little as 1 minute, compared to the present delivery time of 9 minutes. Color photos will be transmitted in less than 3 minutes, compared to the current delivery time of 30 minutes. Reid said the photo technology was changing rapidly and predicted, ``Within two years, we'll look back on the days we sent one photo per minute and we'll look at that as a long time.'' Hal Buell, assistant to the president for AP's PhotoStream and electronic darkrooms, told the executives, ``All of us are entering a new world of picture handling.'' Vincent Alabiso, executive NewsPhoto editor, promised that PhotoStream would ``solve almost every deadline problem associated with wire photos.'' He said that a 30-minute color project ``just became 90 percent quicker'' _ an attraction to editors facing deadlines. Tomlin said that PhotoStream ``offers the opportunity to solve almost all of the photo problems raised by editors.'' Robert Caspe, president of Leaf Systems Inc., reviewed his company's new electronic darkroom system which is being offered to AP members. He said the system would completely automate picture handling by editors and would increase quality while reducing cost.

DOC.HEAD: Two Suspected IRA members Arrested in Belgium, Netherlands
DOC.TEXT: Authorities on Saturday arrested two suspected IRA members after a local farmer heard them taking target practice in woods near the Dutch border. Police said they were looking for a third reputed member of the Irish Republican Army who escaped. Authorities identified one suspect as Donna Maguire. She faces West German terrorism charges dating back to September 1989, Dutch authorities said. Ms. Maguire, 23, was carrying a false U.S. passport when she was arrested in woods along the Dutch border, 43 miles north of Brussels. She and two men were in the area practicing shooting, Dutch authorities said. Officials said the shots were heard by a farmer who alerted the police. The woman was arrested, but the two men fled. Police said they found a Dutch-registered car containing a machine gun, explosives and two handguns in the woods where the three were shooting. About two hours later, across the border, Dutch police arrested an English-speaking man who was ``obviously on the run,'' said Stephan Worm, a Dutch National Police spokesman. He said the man was believed to be one of the group of three. Worm said the man refused to give his name or make any statement. He was being held for extradition to Belgium. Police on both sides of the border were looking for the other man. A police spokesman in the north Belgian city of Turnhout said, ``We are almost certain that we are dealing with three IRA people.'' Worm said Ms. Maguire is wanted in West Germany for murder, attempted murder and setting off explosives in connection with a terrorist attack in September 1989. He gave no other details. The charges may relate to the shooting death on Sept. 7, 1989, of Heidi Hazell, 26, the German-born wife of a British soldier. She was shot in her car in Dortmund. The IRA said later it thought she worked for British security forces. Since 1979, the IRA has mounted attacks in Belgium, the Netherlands and West Germany in the group's campaign to end British rule in Northern Ireland. The outlawed organization, in a new offensive aimed mainly at British targets outside Northern Ireland, has killed seven people in the past few weeks and mounted several attacks in England. Last weekend, an IRA bomb injured 17 students at a birthday party in a bar of a north London barracks. In other recent attacks, IRA gunmen shot dead a teen-age off-duty soldier at Lichfield station in central England and killed a British army major in West Germany. On May 27, at least two IRA gunmen shot and killed two Australian tourists as they got into their British-registered car in Roermond, the Netherlands. In a statement later, the IRA said it believed the two were British servicemen stationed in West Germany and apologized for the ``tragic mistake.''

DOC.HEAD: Niger Government to Permit Pluralism
DOC.TEXT: Niger's ruling council announced Saturday it would permit ``political pluralism'' but gave no indication if opposition parties would be authorized. Several one-party governments in Africa have reacted to recent demands for multiparty democracy by saying they would liberalize management of the ruling party to permit different opinions. This has been referred to as ``political pluralism.'' On May 1, President Ali Saibou, pressed by unions to permit opposition parties, said this West African nation was not ready for multiparty democracy. But in recent weeks, strikes by most of the country's workforce has forced the government to reconsider the demands. Saturday's communique from the ruling Superior National Orientation Council also reported that 63 Tuareg nomads were killed in clashes with security forces on May 7. The government initially said 30 Tuaregs and seven other people, including police and civilians, were killed in the clash. On Friday, the French newspaper Le Monde carried a front-page story saying hundreds of Tuaregs, white-skinned desert nomads who enslaved black Africans in past centuries, had been killed in the May incident. The story quoted Niger Information Minister Khamed Abdoulaye, himself a Tuareg, as saying that 29 people in his family were killed in the clashes. On Saturday, Abdoulaye said Le Monde had distorted his comments.

DOC.HEAD: Search Turns up More Flood Victims; 15 Known Dead, Dozens Still Missing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with death toll now 15, partial IDs of earlier victims, details of search. Pickup 7th graf, `Utility crews...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PG2, NY16; LaserColor XBLR2
DOC.TEXT: Searchers recovered the bodies of four people Saturday, bringing to 15 the confirmed death toll from a flash flood that raged through eastern Ohio, authorities said. About three dozen people remained missing. A 5-year-old Glencoe girl, Tiffany Webb, was found dead in McMahon Creek early Saturday, said Chuck Vogt, Belmont County Coroner's investigator. The girl and her 6-year-old brother, Donald Andrew Webb, were killed when Thursday night's flood swept their mobile home from its concrete mooring. Later in the day, Vogt reported two additional victims, Danny Humphrey, 8, hometown unknown, and Mary Grimes, age and hometown unknown. A fourth victim, who was not identified, was discovered in the Ohio River late in the afternoon, Vogt said about 8 p.m. Capt. Jim Boling of the Ohio Air National Guard said the number of people missing was revised Saturday evening to 34. Previous reports from Belmont County authorities had given the number as 51. Ohio Emergency Management Agency spokesman Ned Martin said some of those listed as missing had informed relatives or authorities they were safe. Boling said others found dead may never have been listed as missing. In all, some 700 rescue workers _ including 341 members of the Ohio National Guard _ are assisting flood victims. ``We have 26 dog teams from Maryland, Kentucky, West Virginia and Athens County, Ohio,'' Boling said. ``They have nearly completed an initial sweep of the affected area.'' Boling said 12 boats would search the Ohio River until dusk. ``We also have teams of volunteers walking the banks of the (Ohio) river.'' Utility crews and local volunteers used chain saws, axes and shovels to clear the debris of more than 100 homes destroyed or damaged by a careening wall of water that washed over the banks of three creeks. Gov. Richard Celeste, who toured the area for the second time Saturday, repeated how shocked he was at the destruction. ``The damage ... was extraordinary. It was something that was beyond what I've seen from tornadoes and floods. One can only imagine what it was like,'' Celeste said at a news conference. ``The shock of the wall of water as it roared through a very confined area literally flattened everything.'' Celeste said state and federal authorities planned to set up an emergency assistance center at Shadyside High School. Trucks hauled stacks of flattened cars out of a gully south of the town. State Highway Patrol troopers and National Guardsmen used the dogs to sniff through the rubble and along the banks of the Wegee and Pipe creeks in Belmont County looking for survivors or victims. Searchers were stunned by the devastation, said Salvation Army Capt. Ginny Muir. ``The mood is like disbelief,'' she said. ``As far as helping, nobody's getting tired or discouraged.'' Authorities allowed a few reporters at a time into the most heavily damaged area but they would not let onlookers downstream, where the dogs were searching. The search extended five miles south of Shadyside along the Wegee and Pipe creeks, which empty into the Ohio River. Workers were also sifting through debris that collected at the Hannibal locks and dam, about 25 miles south of town. A cloudburst that dropped 5.5 inches of rain in 3{ hours Thursday night surged through the low-lying community in the Appalachian foothills, washing away houses and destroying roads. The Federal Emergency Management Agency on Friday declared Belmont, Jefferson and Franklin counties disaster areas, making federal aid available to residents. Vogt said most of the victims were from Shadyside and Mead Township, where the two creeks run south of the village, or Glencoe, near McMahon Creek. A temporary morgue for flood victims was set up at the Bauknecht Funeral Home In Shadyside, about 10 miles south of Wheeling, W.Va. The National Weather Service issued a flood watch Thursday night, indicating that flooding along small streams and low-lying areas was possible. But Al Wheeler, deputy meteorologist in charge of the service's Cleveland office, said the service did not issue a flood warning, which alerts residents to take shelter. Wheeler said weather service offices in Cleveland, Akron and Columbus in Ohio and in Pittsburgh had information showing the storm had diminished over eastern Ohio when it had actually intensified. Seventeen Ohio counties have been declared disaster areas because of flooding or tornadoes since May 29.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Clings to Hope that 12-Year-Old Daughter is Alive
With AM-Flash Floods, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The mother of a 12-year-old girl swept away by a flash flood was clinging to hope that her daughter was alive but perhaps unable to get home, a family friend said Saturday. Janice Trigg's daughter, Kerri, was among nearly three dozen still missing Saturday night, two days after the floods hit eastern Ohio. ``She keeps saying Kerri Jo may have amnesia, or she can't move to get help. That's a mother's hope,'' said the friend, Betty Kreiter, 67. Searchers for the missing used trained dogs to sniff through the rubble and along the banks of the Wegee and Pipe creeks, which empty into the Ohio River, in an effort that stretched five miles south of this town. Workers also sifted through debris that collected at the Hannibal locks and dam on the Ohio River, about 25 miles south. Relatives of the missing were staying with friends and family, said the Rev. Robert Gracey, who was counseling flood victims at a school turned into a relief center. Kerri had been playing at a friend's house when the one-story home suddenly was washed away in the flood Thursday night. The friend, 9-year-old Amber Colvin, was swept down Wegee Creek and into the Ohio River, but survived a seven-mile ordeal by clinging to logs.Amber was released from a hospital Saturday after treatment for minor injuries. She said she last saw Kerri when the two, alone in the house, jumped into a bathtub for safety in the storm. The tub was washed into the creek. Throughout the town, there were stories of fear, luck and close calls. Deanna Hulderman, 48, said she and her husband, Clancey, were pulled under by Wegee Creek flood water at a bar but were reunited about a half-hour later. Mrs. Hulderman said she, her husband and about seven others were in the 3Ks bar when a wall collapsed and water rushed through. ``I saw my husband go under and get washed away. He was yelling how much he loved me, and then I went under,'' Mrs. Hulderman said. ``I began praying `God, don't let me die like this,' and the next thing I knew I was standing on my feet, and the water went down.'' Mrs. Hulderman said firefighters rescued her husband at the mouth of the creek near the Ohio River. Capt. James Boling of the Ohio National Guard said local authorities told him some of the bar patrons remained unaccounted for. Kathy Schramm, 37, said she, her husband and their two children fled their two-story house before water washed through. When they returned, the basement and first floor were flooded, and the surrounding area ``looked like a big lake.'' ``I looked up at a house on the hill, and it looked like it was on stilts on the water,'' Mrs. Schramm said.
