DOC.HEAD: Social Security Plan Tangles Debate Over Child-Care Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBs 2nd graf to indicate two bills go to conference committee
DOC.TEXT: Slow-moving congressional efforts to fashion a child-care assistance bill are becoming entangled in an election-year fight to include a $3 billion Social Security break for senior citizens. The child-care assistance plan passed the Senate a year ago and the House in March and both bills are languishing in House-Senate conference committee. The Social Security plan could make it even more difficult to fashion a compromise. Some GOP lawmakers plan to offer a resolution this week in the House that would instruct the conferees to go along with an important _ if largely unrelated _ provision that the Senate added to its child care bill. That provision would raise the annual limit on outside earnings that Social Security recipients over the age of 65 can have while still receiving their full government checks. Supporters say the change would provide a needed break for the working elderly. But opponents call it a $3 billion giveaway to senior citizens that would in effect be charged to the cost of children's programs. They say it has no business in the much-debated child-care bills. ``We're going to be dispensing money through the earnings test that could be used by middle class and working people for child care,'' said Rep. Tom Downey, D-N.Y., a sponsor of the child care bill and opponent of the Social Security provision. ``It comes right out of the pockets of working people and into the pockets of the elderly,'' Downey said. Advocates of increasing the Social Security earnings ceiling say the limit effectively increases the tax on recipients over the age of 65. They claim a majority of House members as cosponsors on a separate bill to lift the earnings limit all together. Thus far, however, that bill has remained firmly bottled up in the House Ways and Means Committee, where Chairman Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., opposes any such change. ``Because of the earnings test, seniors are being forced out of the work force and into the rocking chair,'' said Rep. J. Dennis Hastert, R-Ill. Rep. Hank Brown, a Republican Senate candidate in Colorado, was expected to offer a non binding motion this week to instruct the House conferees to go along with that Senate provision. The motion most likely would be approved, Downey said. The Senate, which has no rule barring unrelated amendments on bills, added the provision on a 100-0 vote last year after it was offered by Finance Chairman Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas. It would raise the amount of earnings for people aged 65 to 69 that are exempt from any reduction to $10,560, a $1,200 increase. Social Security payments for recipients earning more than that would be reduced by $1 for every $4 earned up to $15,560 in earnings, instead of the current $1 for every $3 earned. Most of the conference committee deliberations have been devoted to other sections of the complicated and conflicting child care bills. The House version has been estimated to cost $27 billion over five years, while the more modest Senate version has been estimated at $10 billion over four years. Jurisdictional disputes among members of Congress have plagued the bill. The House version, passed March 29, provides tax credits that could be used by working families to pay for child care. It would also provide money to epand Head Start pre-school services and establish a new program encouraging school-based before and after school child care. The Senate version, passed June 12, 1989, would provide tax credits and create a separate grant program for child care. Opponents say its central grant program would require annual appropriations and thus is vulnerable to political whim, while the House version locks in key portions by making them automatically renewing entitlement programs. Rostenkowski has resisted the notion of increasing the earnings limits for Social Security recipients and is concerned about the cost, estimated by his committee staff at $3 billion. The potential generational conflict comes at a time when the Ways and Means Committee has just issued a lengthy study of the impact of federal entitlement programs that suggests children as a group have suffered economically over the last decade while the aged have fared better. The report said the poverty rate for the aged fell from 15.7 percent in 1980 to 12 percent in 1988, while the poverty rate for children rose from 18.3 percent in 1980 to 19.7 percent in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Central American Economic Summit Seeks Common Ground for Development
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf, ``He wants...' with two grafs to UPDATE with U.S. economic proposal. Pickup 14th graf pvs, `The summit's...'
DOC.TEXT: Central American leaders on Saturday opened a summit meeting they hope will usher in an era of peaceful prosperity after years of war and economic crisis. ``The problems of poverty, injustice and political and social differences have been confronted by disappearing opponents, by conflict, by death and by assassination,'' Guatemalan President Vinicio Cerezo said at the opening of the gathering. ``We don't want to repeat this history. Now we have to begin taking other paths,'' he said. Cerezo said peace and democracy cannot survive without prosperity, a key theme of the two-day economic summit. The presidents hope to duplicate the success of their regional peace plan with a concerted development effort, including attracting substantial foreign support. The peace plan helped bring about free elections and an end to the war in Nicaragua and peace talks between leftist rebels and the governments of El Salvador and Guatemala. ``Central America has to show the world that it ready to confront underdevelopment and create options for prosperity for its people the same way it resolved the problem of war in the 1980s,'' said Honduran President Rafael Callejas. Callejas, a 46-year-old economist who took office in January, says Central America needs $2.25 billion over the next three years to begin rebuilding. ``The international community and the Western world should channel these resources to Central America,'' he said at a news conference in the Honduran capital of Tegucigalpa this week. Callejas and Cerezo are meeting with Presidents Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of Nicaragua and Rafael Calderon of Costa Rica. Panamanian President Guillermo Endara is attending as an observer. The Central American leaders, concerned about competing demands from Eastern Europe, are encouraged by Secretary of State James Baker III's decision to come to Antigua. Baker was to arrive late Sunday and will meet with the five Central American presidents and Endara on Monday. He is expected to propose a plan for coordinating aid, trade and investment from various nations and organizations. The United States is expected to manage the program with Japan and the European Community as co-chairs. ``In a world of redefined hegemonies, the United States is again making its claim: This (Central America) is our turf, and there is no doubt about it,'' one regional development expert said of the proposal. He spoke on condition of anonymity. The summit's opening was delayed almost an hour _ until halftime in the World Cup soccer match between Costa Rica and Brazil. Diplomats, international bankers, development experts, bureaucrats and reporters huddled around televisions in this colonial city 27 miles from the capital. This is the first summit to focus on the devastated economies of the region. Enrique Iglesias, president of the Inter-American Development Bank in Washington, said that despite competing national interests, there are ample possibilities for economic cooperation in the Central America. ``Energy, roads, communications _ these are issues which deserve a regional approach,'' he said in an interview from the bank's Washington headquarters. Political issues were expected to be raised as well. Although negotiations are under way in El Salvador and Guatemala, peace is still not at hand. Nicaragua is still in the delicate process of transition from a decade of revolutionary Sandinista rule to Mrs. Chamorro's promise of a renewed free enterprise system.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 100 Dead In Southern China Floods
DOC.TEXT: More than 100 people have died in floods caused by torrential rains last week in China's southern province of Hunan, an official daily said Sunday. The flooding knocked down about 16,000 homes, killed 2,905 farm animals and inundated more than 741,000 acres of farmland, the People's Daily reported. It said 39 cities in Hunan province recorded more than 4 inches of rain in storms between Monday and Friday. The official Xinhua News Agency reported that at one point, 10,000 people were trapped in buildings. Southern and central China perennially suffer heavy loss of life and damage from summer flooding. Last summer, nearly 3,000 people were killed, half in the populous southwest province of Sichuan.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Helicopter Pilot's Condition Critical
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 3-4 bgng `There had...' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with pilot still in critical condition, new quotes from hospital spokeswoman, wife by his side. ADDS 1 graf at end with quote from Arizona man who arranged for bone marrow transplant.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto SE2
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet pilot who was a hero of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster was in critical condition Saturday with a lung infection, said officials at the hospital where he recently underwent a bone marrow transplant for leukemia. Anatoly Grishchenko, 53, who had been in stable condition after the April 27 transplant, developed a fever and breathing difficulties late Thursday, and doctors at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center placed him on a respirator early Friday, center spokeswoman Susan Edmonds said. Grishchenko was sedated and on a respirator, and his doctors ``really don't feel there will be a recovery in the next 24 hours,'' Edmonds said Saturday. While doctors still hoped for improvement, there had been none in the previous 24 hours and that ``is usually a sign that things are not going to go well,'' she said. If Grishchenko survives the night, doctors will assess his case Sunday, when they likely will decide whether to continue use of the respirator, she said. Grishchenko's wife, Galina, was at her husband's side, Edmonds said. Grishchenko's leukemia was detected late last year. He made four flights in five days through hot radioactive gases to dump sand and wet concrete on the Chernobyl nuclear plant. The plant, about 80 miles north of Kiev in the Soviet republic of the Ukraine, exploded and burned April 26, 1986. At least 31 people died in the disaster. He underwent the transplant in hopes that healthy marrow could restore normal blood-cell production. The problem is a hard-to-treat lung infection he had before coming to the Hutchinson Center, Edmonds said. Doctors had tried to eliminate it with antibiotics, but the infection continued in his right lung. After waiting until the transplant appeared successful, doctors on Tuesday performed exploratory lung surgery to identify and remove the source of the infection. The surgery appeared to go well, but Grishchenko's condition began deteriorating late Thursday, Edmonds said. It was not known if his worsening condition was related to the surgery, she said, adding that he will continue to receive antibiotics. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev praised Grishchenko in a recent letter as a national hero and a ``brave man who didn't spare his life in the line of duty.'' The letter was delivered while Gorbachev was touring parts of Minnesota and California earlier this month after the summit meeting in Washington, D.C. Grishchenko arrived in Seattle from the Soviet Union on April 11. ``A lot of people are praying for him,'' said Cap Parlier of Mesa, Ariz., who arranged the bone marrow transplant. The light-helicopter testing and evaluation director for McDonnell Douglas Corp., is a friend of Grishchenko and has closely followed his treatment.

DOC.HEAD: Stolen Ancient Manuscripts Recovered in Italy
DOC.TEXT: Police on Saturday found a trove of stolen medieval documents hidden in cars and houses. Two men were reported arrested. Police became suspicious after seeing two men exchange boxes near a main square. Patrols in the area had been stepped up to keep order during the World Cup soccer tournament. Later searches of cars and houses yielded the manuscripts, rolls of parchment and sheet music dating from the 12th to 16th centuries. They were stolen from a library in the northern Italian city of Fabriano in mid-March. Police arrested Evandro Uzzani, 49, and Raul Andreasi, 40, both of Turin, the Italian news agency ANSA reported.

DOC.HEAD: Severe Thunderstorms, Tornadoes Tear Through Midwestern States
DOC.TEXT: Severe thunderstorms raked parts of the Midwest Saturday, causing widespread flooding and at least two deaths in Iowa and Illinois. Tornadoes destroyed five houses in South Dakota and ripped through a Nebraska town. Hundreds of Iowans were forced to evacuate their homes when up to 6 inches of rain fell over parts of the state, and roads and bridges were washed out. An 11-year-old girl was killed when she was swept into a culvert in the Davenport suburb of LeClaire on the Mississippi River, Scott County authorities said. Iowa Gov. Terry Branstad declared seven eastern and central counties disaster areas and sent the National Guard to help sandbag low-lying areas as rivers and creeks overflowed. The Weather Service said more thunderstorms and heavy rain were likely overnight as a front of moist, unstable air moved through the upper Midwest. In South Dakota, a tornado ripped a nine-mile path through Beresford, 35 miles south of Sioux Falls, damaging 30 to 50 homes, said Beresford Fire Chief T.A. Mullinex. He said about five homes were destroyed but no deaths or injuries were reported. In Nebraska, a tornado hit the northeastern town of Madison Saturday night, causing widespread damage just hours after areas had been evacuated because of flooding, officials said. Part of the roof of the IBP Inc. meat packing plant was torn off by the storm, said a woman who answered the plant's phone. She wouldn't give her name. ``There are trees down everywhere, roofs off of houses all over town, and gas lines ruptured,'' said Madison police Officer Mike Bowersox. ``It moved right through the middle of town.'' He said there were no immediate reports of deaths or injuries in the community of 2,000 about 100 miles northwest of Omaha. Another tornado touched down further north near O'Neill earlier Saturday, damaging two farms, in Nebraska's fifth straight day of severe storms. Heavy rains also lashed western Illinois Saturday. A train engineer was killed and three people were injured when a Burlington Northern freight engine derailed at a washed-out bridge near Morrison, Ill., authorities said. ``The train collapsed the weakened bridge and the two engines with approximately 28 cars began a chain reaction collision,'' said a Whiteside County sheriff's dispatcher. ``Workers were trapped in the engine because they came to rest in about 15 feet of water and mud from the swollen ditch.'' The engineer's identity was not released. The injured were treated at a hospital and released. In Iowa, scattered flooding was reported throughout the state. Branstad declared Polk, Warren, Dallas and Jasper counties in central Iowa and Johnson, Scott and Muscatine counties in eastern Iowa disaster areas. Six inches of rain overnight brought the Raccoon River out of its banks. The river was expected to crest at 22 feet on Sunday, 11 feet above flood stage. The crest was expected to reach Van Meter in central Iowa Sunday, nine feet above flood stage and slightly higher than the record set in 1958. The river was expected to crest at Des Moines near its 1947 record. All roads between Des Moines and west Des Moines were blocked except Interstate 235 and police were going door to door in low-lying areas offering evacuation help. A thunderstorm packing winds of at least 80 mph struck the Ottumwa area in southeast Iowa shortly after 2 p.m., damaging trees and at least two homes and downing power lines. A new outdoor storm warning system failed when the weather service asked officials to activate it after a tornado was sighted. Ottumwa Police Sgt. Jim Clark said the failure apparently was caused by an electrical power surge from intense lightning. Travel was considered extremely dangerous all over eastern Iowa. In Cedar County, motorists along Interstate 80 between Durant and Stockton were trapped inside and on top of floating cars, a State Patrol spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: Fire In Winnebago Leaves One Dead, 13 Hospitalized
DOC.TEXT: Adults en route from Mississippi to a bingo game on an Indian reservation jumped from a burning, moving motor home Saturday. One died and at least 13 were hospitalized. Eyewitnesses said about 14 passengers were aboard the Winnebago when it caught fire about 4 p.m. on Interstate 65 near Creola, about 21 miles north of Mobile and 40 miles from the Poarch Creek Indian Reservation. ``There was a flash fire inside the vehicle and they abandoned it while it was going down the road,'' said Jim Teague, Creola assistant police chief. ``Black smoke came out of the vehicle and then flames and then people started jumping out.'' Teague said the people jumped out as the Winnebago traveled three-fourths of a mile, and suffered abrasions and ``major trauma'' from the pavement as well as burns from the fire. He said police didn't know how fast the vehicle was going or what caused the fire. Officers were interviewing the passengers at the hospitals. The witnesses said the Winnebago left the highway, went across a field, through a fence and over a service road before hitting a tree and coming to a halt, still burning. Teague said the witnesses were passengers on a full-sized bus just behind the Winnebago, also headed to the bingo game. The Mobile County coroner's office said one person died from injuries in the incident but declined to release other details. Six of the injured were taken to the University of South Alabama Medical Center, two by helicopter. Nursing supervisor Doris Willmon said their conditions ranged from stable to critical. Seven others were taken to the Spring Hill Memorial Hospital, one of whom, a burn victim, was later moved to the medical center. A Spring Hill nursing supervisor said the remaining six were listed as stable. Teague said the Winnebago was one of four vehicles that left Biloxi, Miss., to go to the Bingo Palace near Atmore, about 60 miles northeast of Mobile. He said the other vehicles were all full-sized buses carrying 47 people each. Police could not immediately determine who owned the Winnebago.

DOC.HEAD: Tyson, Foreman Win With Quick KOs
DOC.TEXT: Mike Tyson made a triumphant return to the ring Saturday night, knocking out former Olympic heavyweight champion Henry Tillman with a single, smashing right hand in the first round. Tyson then helped the stricken Tillman to his feet. It was Tyson's first fight since he lost the heavyweight championship on a shocking 10th-round knockout to James ``Buster'' Douglas on Feb. 11 at Tokyo. Tyson made sure there was going to be no surprise on this 87-degree night before a near-capacity crowd of about 15,000 at an outdoor arena at Caesar's Palace. A 20-1 favorite, Tyson came swarming out of his corner at the opening bell and kept the pressure on Tyson until the end, which came at 2 minutes, 47 seconds. Tyson, who will be 24 on June 30, scored his 34th knockout in boosting his record to 38-1. He earned $2 million. In another bout on the same card, 41-year-old former heavyweight champion George Foreman, continuing his improbable try for a world title, stopped Adilson Rodrigues with a thundering three-punch combination in the second round of their scheduled 10-round fight Saturday night. Foreman caught Rodrigues with a left jab, then followed it with a right hand and a left hook that put the Brazilian down. Rodrigues struggled to get up but was counted out by referee Carlos Padilla at 2:39. Foreman, winning for the 22nd straight time since returning to the ring three years ago, wasted little time in earning his $1 million payday.

Bush last month, over the objections of many members of Congress, extended for an additional year most favored nation trade status to China. It gives the Asian nation preferential treatment in trade with the United States, including the lowest-possible tariffs.
WX-Cabrera

DOC.HEAD: Thai Drug Minister Says US Must Talk With Supply Country
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials will have to talk with representatives of the country that supplies drugs through Thailand to reduce the flow, Thai officials told administration representatives Friday. The Thai officials did not publicly name the country they were referring to, but Burma is known to be the biggest supplier of drugs shipped through Thailand. The United States has poor relations with Burma's military government, which it has sharply criticized for the country's record on human rights. At the National Press Club, Thai Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan referred a question on drugs to his minister in charge of narcotics, Korn Dabbaransi. ``The supply itself does not originate in Thailand,'' Korn said. ``So if you want to talk to the supply side we'll have to include a third country. ... If we ... discuss between us and the United States only, it will never work and the United States will have to realize that. You will also have to do your own homework ... with the country in question before we can ever hope to reach any fruitful ultimate target.'' The State Department has criticized corrupt Thai officials for letting drugs flow through their country. ``Thailand is significant as the primary route for Southeast Asian heroin bound for the international market,'' it said in its most recent report on narcotics control in March. ``Heroin is refined in Thailand, but in much smaller quantities than that produced in refineries on the Burmese, and to a somewhat lesser degree, Lao sides of the border.'' According to the State Department's figures, Thailand will produce this year about 50 tons of opium , the raw material for heroin, while Burma is expected to produce 2,780 tons. In a speech to the club, Chatichai said narcotics trafficking transcends national boundaries. ``We must direct our joint effort at both the supply and demand side of the problem,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Caseworker Found Guilty of Child Abuse
DOC.TEXT: A social worker was convicted of child abuse Friday for helping a couple regain custody of a 2-year-old boy who died when his father repeatedly dunked him in a toilet bowl during potty training. Margaret Barber, 62, was convicted of felony child abuse and misdemeanor failure to report suspected abuse in the death of Bradley McGee in July 1989. Ms. Barber was the first Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services caseworker to be convicted of a felony for handling of official duties. Three other state workers were charged with the misdemeanor count in the case. Two were acquitted, and the charge was dropped against the third. ``This case is not about what Ms. Barber did. It is about what she did not do,'' Assistant State Attorney John Aguero said in closing arguments Friday. He said Ms. Barber ignored negative professional appraisals of the parents and warning signs in the home. Defense attorney John Liguori called the prosecutor's argument unfair hindsight. ``The state now asks you to Monday morning quarterback the decision of Ms. Barber,'' he told the six-member jury. The child spent most of his life in foster care after he was abandoned as an infant at a shopping mall. Ms. Barber recommended he be returned to his parents despite a psychological profile describing them as ``infantile'' and ``explosive.'' Bradley's mother, Sheryl Coe, 21, pleaded guilty to second-degree murder and is serving a 30-year sentence. Stepfather Thomas Coe, 22, faces a murder trial next month. The boy was dunked headfirst in the toilet to punish him for soiling his diaper. Ms. Barber also was convicted of failing to report an allegation that the boy's mother forced him to eat human waste after another potty training setback. Ms. Barber faces a maximum five-year prison term at sentencing scheduled for July 20. Attorneys have said she is unlikely to receive more than one year. Ms. Barber declined to comment after the verdict. She had testified that Bradley's case was one of about 60 she was assigned at the time. ``I'm not perfect,'' she said. ``There may have been some things I missed.''

DOC.HEAD: Bob Hope Keeps Them Laughing at Palm Springs High Graduation
DOC.TEXT: Bob Hope handed out one-liners and a plug for the environment while picking up an honorary degree from Palm Springs High School. ``Palm Springs High is some school,'' the comedian quipped in his commencement address Thursday. ``The dress code here is swimsuit and thongs. And that's for the teachers. ``I know how you all must feel,'' Hope, 87, told 500 graduates and 3,500 others. ``I remember how proud I was when the principal handed me my diploma. I dropped it. It was printed on a stone tablet.'' Hope told the students that it is up to them to correct the errors of his generation and clean up the environment. ``The specific challenge of your generation is to work creatively with the consequences our generation has passed on to yours,'' Hope said. ``Good luck and God bless you in your efforts.''

DOC.HEAD: Creator's Death Won't Slow Use of Muppets by Disney
DOC.TEXT: The family of the late Muppet master Jim Henson expects to expand the use of his characters in Walt Disney Co. theme parks and films. ``I'm sure this is just a beginning,'' Henson's widow Jane said Friday at the opening of a new live-character Muppets musical show at the Disney-MGM Studios theme park. ``We all want so much for the characters to live and live and live,'' she added. ``And this is the right place to do it.'' Henson and the company were negotiating an agreement to broaden use of the Muppets by Disney when he died, Disney chairman Michael Eisner said at a news conference Friday. Henson's oldest son, Brian, said his father ``really felt that this is the ideal place for his work to end up. ... We just hope that our association flourishes.'' ``None of us have any reason to believe we won't proceed as planned,'' Eisner told reporters. Henson died May 16 after a bout with pneumonia. He was 53.

DOC.HEAD: Mitterrand Says European Community Favors English Over French
DOC.TEXT: President Francois Mitterrand, in a letter released Friday, said the European Community has improperly allowed English to become its dominant administrative language at the expense of French. France was ready to help EC bureaucrats ``acquire the linguistic competence needed to perform their mission,'' Mitterrand wrote in a letter to Jacques Delors, the Frenchman who is president of the European Commission. Several Conservative members of Britain's Parliament criticized Mitterrand's letter. ``The man's dotty,'' Sir Nicholas Fairbairn said. ``French is the language of privacy and English is the language of communication.'' ``It might not be a bad idea if President Mitterrand took some English lessons, preferably from Mrs. Thatcher,'' said another member of Parliament, Neil Hamilton. Mitterrand said using French increasingly as an official EC language was a top priority of his government. ``Today, a tendency exists in certain sectors of the commission to convene meetings of experts who are asked to work only in English,'' he wrote. Mitterrand said many EC documents, including contract offers and work documents, were issued only in English despite a treaty calling for multilingualism. ``Such practices are not acceptable, and France will continue to oppose them,'' he wrote. ``France is ready to put at the commission's disposition the means of enabling its employees to acquire the linguistic competence needed to perform their mission.''

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Get Their Turn At White House
DOC.TEXT: Environmentalists told senior advisers to President Bush on Friday that the timber industry has grossly exaggerated the economic impact of proposals to save the Northwest's northern spotted owl from extinction. The White House officials who heard the environmentalists' story Friday on Thursday heard from the timber industry. The Fish and Wildlife Service is expected to declare the northern spotted owl a threatened species next week, a move that likely will require vast tracts of land to be set aside for habitat protection and result in severe reductions in timber harvests. Larry Tuttle, director of The Wilderness Society of Oregon, said the environmentalists were ``very encouraged'' by the tone of the White House meeting on Friday. ``It gave us a chance to debunk some of the numbers that the timber industry has been using to support their case. Clearly they are using worst case numbers and in some cases, worse than that,'' he said. A panel of government scientists led by Forest Service biologist Jack Ward Thomas said in April that 8.4 million acres of forests must be set aside to ensure the owl will survive across its range of Oregon, Washington and California. Forest Service Chief F. Dale Robertson said his agency intends to institute most of the Thomas plan. The agency earlier projected if the plan was adopted in its entirety, harvest levels would be cut nearly in half in the region, resulting in the direct loss of more than 28,000 jobs by the end of the decade. Tuttle said, however, that the job-loss figures include unemployment due to causes other than the spotted owl. He said 7,000 jobs are likely to be lost as a result of continued automation, 7,000 are likely to be lost as a result of changes in 10-year forest management plans already under way and another 7,000 are likely to be lost because private lands have been overcut to the point less timber will be available.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Upholds `Polar Cap' Seizures, But Warns Government
DOC.TEXT: The government can proceed with the nation's largest-ever money laundering case, a judge ruled Friday, despite claims by holders of frozen bank accounts they were unaware their dollars were drug-tainted. U.S. District Judge Lenore Nesbitt refused defense requests to dismiss the forfeiture case that rose out of Operation Polar Cap, a nationwide crackdown on profits allegedly growing from trafficking by Colombia's Medellin drug cartel. She said prosecutors have established minimal probable cause to believe about $11 million in 88 Florida bank accounts is connected to drug profits earned by drug smugglers. But account holders have a right to be concerned about the government's complaint, she said in her 21-page ruling. ``Although designed to deprive those associated with the drug trade of their illicit gains and tools of the trade, forfeiture is nevertheless a draconian remedy,'' she wrote. ``The government has alleged only skeletal facts in the complaint that would support any legal theory of forfeiture.'' The accounts were among 658 seized in 23 states in April in an unprecedented crackdown against money laundering. U.S. Attorney General Richard Thornburgh said agents had for the first time traced money made in drug sales on the nation's streets directly to drug traffickers in Colombia. The government later released most of the accounts after conceding they belonged to wealthy individuals and corporations that traded pesos for dollars on Colombia's unofficial currency exchange market. The cash was then wired to U.S. banks. Lawyers for the account holders asked Nesbitt last week to dismiss the case, saying their clients are legitimate businessmen who had no idea the dollars they bought were dumped on the black market by the cartel. But the judge said the account holders must prove their innocent ownership in court. She promised a speedy trial and scheduled a status hearing for July 6. ``My client and I will continue to fight this gross miscarriage of justice,'' said Fred Schwartz, an attorney representing Colombian businessman Marc Levy. Schwartz said Levy is a legitimate businessman who has nothing to do with drugs and was only buying dollars to pay for his children's education in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Twins See Double on Grades, Grants
DOC.TEXT: They graduated from high school just fractions of a grade point apart, as valedictorian and salutatorian. In college, they shared summa cum laude honors. Now, twins Amy and Anne Frary are getting ready to start graduate work _ on identical grants, of course. This fall, the twins begin pre-doctoral studies in plant-breeding at Cornell University on National Science Foundation fellowships worth $38,700 each. ``People always say to me is one a little better than the other and the answer is `no,' '' said their teacher and advisor, Diana Stein, an associate professor of biological sciences at Mount Holyoke College. The twins are mirror-image. Amy is left-handed and wears glasses, Anne is right-handed and needs no correction on her vision. Like many twins, they finish each other's sentences and don't understand why people find them unusual. ``At college we just were biology majors,'' Amy Frary said. ``We knew we wanted to do something with plants. We just picked it out of the blue.'' Four years ago, the twins graduated from Hampshire Regional High School with grade point averages better than 97 percent. Amy edged out Anne for valedictorian by a fraction of a point, but the twins said there was no acrimony. ``We're not like that,'' Anne Frary said. For the science grant, Stein wrote one recommendation, pointing out that there were two Frarys applying. ``I happened to learn inadvertently ... that NSF sent their two folders to different panel groups so they were in fact evaluated separately,'' she said. ``They stand on their own merits.'' At Mount Holyoke, the twins graduated with a 3.90 grade average, which made them both summa cum laude. Stein said she has advised the twins to get separate mentors at graduate school, so they can begin to diverge. ``The next stage in their life they have to go out and find jobs and the job market is such that the chances are that's when they'll split.'' Although they look very similar, the twins are not impossible to tell apart. ``It was easy for me because I have a set of identical twin girls also who are now 28,'' Stein said. Amy Frary said name mix-ups are the only thing that annoys her about being a twin. ``It annoys me that people who we went to grade school with all 12 years still can't tell us apart,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Speakers Call for Continued Sanctions Against South Africa
DOC.TEXT: U.N. delegates, marking the 14th anniversary of South Africa's worst riots, declared that sanctions against its white government should remain in place until apartheid is abolished. The government of F.W. de Klerk has been asking foreign governments to lift economic sanctions, saying its recent reforms show that South Africa is changing. Some of the U.N. delegates, in their ``Soweto Day'' speeches, cautiously welcomed the reforms but said the international community should keep up the pressure by maintaining sanctions. The meeting by the Special Committee Against Apartheid was held one week before black African leader Nelson Mandela addresses the United Nations. In its recent reforms, the South Africa government freed Mandela from prison, lifted the state of emergency in three of four provinces, legalized anti-apartheid groups, and moved to end some segregation laws. The white government has also opened talks on giving the country's black majority a political role, though it has not promised to yield to majority rule. ``Soweto Day'' marked the 14th anniversary of bloodshed in Soweto at a protest by black school children complaining about the use of the Afrikaans language in schools and opposing the apartheid system. At least one student was killed in an initial clash with authorities, and the riots that followed left up to 700 people dead in the following months. Security Council President Pierre-Louis Blanc, the French ambassador, said Friday's ceremony came at a time when major changes were occurring in South Africa. But he added that ``the abhorrent system'' of racial discrimination remains in place. He called for the total elimination of apartheid and majority rule before the lifting of economic sanctions against South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: West Germany Wants to Cut Carbon Dioxide by 25 Percent
DOC.TEXT: West Germany intends to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide 25 percent within 15 years to combat global warming known as the greenhouse effect, a government official said Friday. Scientists say the odorless, colorless gas could cause higher temperatures by collecting on the outer edges of the Earth's atmosphere and trapping heat within. That process could produce changes in the world's climate. Frankfurter Allgemeine newspaper said that highly industrialized West Germany _ with about 61 million people inhabiting an area roughly the size of Oregon _ now releases 716 million tons of carbon dioxide a year into the atmosphere. Reducing the emissions by 25 percent by the year 2005 would mean a cut of nearly 180 million tons annually, it said. A Cabinet committee group was set up Wednesday to work out details for the project, said Uwe Fritche. He is a member of the Enquete Commission, a federal panel of experts that evaluates policy options on climate change. Fritche said officials are also studying ways of drastically cutting carbon dioxide emissions in East Germany as quickly as possible after the two countries are united. East Germany, which heavily depends on brown coal as an energy source, has the highest per capita emission rate in the world with 22.4 tons per year per person, the newspaper report said. West Germany's is about half that level. Carbon dioxide is released during the burning of fossil fuels. ``It's already clear that energy efficiency will be the main means to achieve the goal of cutting emissions 25 percent,'' Fritche told The Associated Press in a telephone interview. He said the government is considering taxing emissions to encourage cutbacks in the industrial and private use of carbon-dioxide producing fuels, including heating oil. In Britain, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has committed her country to a 30 percent reduction in its carbon dioxide emissions by the year 2005.

DOC.HEAD: McDonnell Douglas Lays Off Douglas Descendants
DOC.TEXT: The last remaining members of the Douglas family have been laid off from their jobs at the Douglas aircraft unit of McDonnell Douglas Corp., along with 7,000 other employees, officials said Friday. ``It is tough to be tossed out when your name is on the door,'' said James S. Douglas Jr., ``It is the McDonnell corporation now, as far as I am concerned. I am very sad that it is over.'' Douglas, 29, worked for the company for five years. He was laid off in late May. His father, 59-year-old James S. Douglas Sr., son of aviation pioneer and company founder Donald W. Douglas, worked there as an engineer and supervisor for 30 years. ``He is very hurt,'' the younger Douglas said of James Sr., who was laid off at the beginning of the month. Another son of the founder was asked to step down from McDonnell Douglas' board last year when he turned 70. A third son retired from the company's astronautics unit in Huntington Beach several years ago. Douglas Aircraft Co. spokesman Don Hanson confirmed Friday that no members of the Douglas family remain with the company. Donald Douglas founded Douglas aircraft in Santa Monica in 1920. It was an industry leader until Boeing gained dominance in 1960. Seven years later, it was bought by McDonnell. The company is now controlled by the McDonnell family of St. Louis, which has tried recently to contain losses at the largely independently run Douglas subsidiary. Douglas Aircraft has lost $306 million during the past 15 months. Its biggest aircraft programs are behind schedule, and it is still suffering from a management reorganization last year. To trim costs, the company started cutting 7,000 jobs, mostly white collar, at its Long Beach and Torrance plants. Douglas currently employs 40,500 people in Southern California. James Douglas Jr. said he did not think the loss of his job was due to a struggle for family power. ``I don't think there was anything on that level at all. We were just peons,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Famed Cole Landscape Gets First Exhibit in 159 Years
DOC.TEXT: The prized Thomas Cole landscape ``The Garden of Eden'' went on museum display Friday for the first time ever and 159 years after it was whisked out of sight by a secretive owner. The landscape depicting paradise with Adam and Eve greeting the morning sun went on exhibit at the Amon Carter Museum, which bought it recently. Curators, who refused to name the seller or the sale price, said the painting is a masterpiece of color and style that spent most of the last 159 years locked in a bank vault. ``It's never been on public view, never been photographed. It was last seen in 1831,'' assistant museum director Ervin Lippman said Thursday. ``That's the extraordinary thing about the rediscovery of it.'' Cole is thought to have painted the lush, tropical depiction of paradise in 1827. It features mountains, towering trees, foliage and wildlife lit in bright, jewel-like colors. Art historians knew of the painting from preliminary drawings, descriptions, and an engraving of it used as the frontispiece of an 1831 edition of the Bible. ``It's an enormously important picture,'' said Cole scholar Ellwood C. Parry III, of the University of Arizona, Tucson. Later, Cole painted a sequential, companion landscape, ``Expulsion from the Garden of Eden,'' which resides at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston.

DOC.HEAD: Familiar Plastic Bull Stolen From Rooftop
DOC.TEXT: It's no bull. Ravioli makers are seeing red now that their 8-foot plastic mascot Rudolpho has been stolen. ``Anyone seen riding or leading a plastic bull should be identified,'' a police dispatcher told squad cars in the field on Thursday. Police issued the alert for Rudolpho, the molded Fiberglas bull who had graced the roof of the two-story Homestead Ravioli Co. until sometime Wednesday. The big bovine beast was a familiar site to highway commuters who passed the building in the city's South of Market Street district. Ravioli workers often dressed up Rudolpho for the holidays. ``It's not Coit Tower, but it was certainly a landmark for some people,'' said Andrew Kubersky, president of Homestead Ravioli. Coit tower is an important San Francisco landmark. ``I miss him,'' Kubersky said. The company inherited the bull when it moved to the building 11 years ago. Rudolpho was placed on the roof by the meat packing firm that earlier had occupied the building. Kubersky said ``bull'' is actually a misnomer for the gender-neutral ``Rudolpho.'' ``We call him a bull, but he's missing some parts,'' Kubersky said.

DOC.HEAD: Satellite Photos Will be Used to Detect Overwatering
DOC.TEXT: Drought-plagued Southern California's major water wholesaler will use satellite photographs to detect overwatering of large tracts of land, officials said Friday. The project, which begins July 3, will not mean day-to-day monitoring of overwatering, said Tim Skrove, a spokesman for the Metropolitan Water District of Southern California, which serves 15 million people in six counties. Authorities will use the photographs to assess irrigation levels over an extended period of time, Skrove said. ``This isn't an instance where we're going to be spying on people,'' Skrove said. ``We're going to be spying on water use, primarily in broad categories such as parks, golf courses, cemeteries or even residential neighborhoods, but certainly not individual homes.'' Where overwatering is detected, water district officials expect to contact local water districts, subdivision developers or operators of parks, golf courses or cemeteries to encourage conservation measures such as landscaping that requires less water, Skrove said. There won't be any new photographs, only pictures taken since October 1988 by Landsat satellites, which orbit 450 miles above Earth's surface, said Tracy Walklet, vice president of Terra-Mar Resource Information Services Inc. The Mountain View, Calif., computer software and systems company will buy, enhance and analyze the photos under an $80,000 contract approved Tuesday by the water district's board of directors. ``To the best of our knowledge, this is the first time this technology is going to be applied to urban area for gauging water conservation potential,'' Skrove said. Terra-Mar will use the photos to determine the amount of irrigated land and the intensity of watering in the district's 5,200-square-mile service area, which includes parts of Los Angeles, Ventura, Orange, San Diego, Riverside and San Bernardino counties. Based on the amount of reflected light, vegetation will appear in different shades of red, with the most lush, heavily watered vegetation appearing bright red. ``What we want to do is categorize the types of vegetation we have in Southern California and how much water is being used for them,'' Skrove said. ``Then in the future we will be able to tailor conservation efforts.''

DOC.HEAD: NAACP Seeks Federal Investigation Of `Slave Day' At Schools
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmits a0747 to fix cycle designator.
DOC.TEXT: The NAACP has asked the federal Justice Department to investigate an annual fund-raising event in some public schools that students have nicknamed ``slave day'' because classmates ``buy'' one another as servants. Students at Upper Lake Elementary School in rural Lake County also call the day ``seventh-graders rule,'' because the younger students are allowed to turn the tables on eighth-graders and order them about for a day. But the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People call it a form of slavery that violates the Constitution and civil rights laws. ``Slavery was heinous. It wasn't a fun game,'' Dewitt Bussey, a consultant to the NAACP's Racial Intolerance Task Force, told reporters Thursday. In written statements to federal and state officials, the NAACP said the Lake County school held its 13th annual ``slave day'' last month, another is planned this October at Union Lake High School, and similar events have been held at other schools around the state. The events ``only serve to condone the concepts of white supremacy,'' the organization said in a letter to acting U.S. Attorney William McGivern. The NAACP asked that the district be ordered to halt the custom and start new programs in human rights and ethnic diversity for students and staff. Thordie Ashley, another NAACP consultant, said blacks were not treated differently from other students during the ``slave day'' event. Otis Williams, principal of the elementary school, did not return reporters' telephone calls Thursday. He has been quoted as saying the school would discontinue the practice. The NAACP also said school board members had promised to abolish the tradition. In its arguments against the practice, the organization cited statements by Ron Raetz, an Upper Lake High School teacher and elementary school board member, that he had ``bought'' a high school senior as part of the event at his school each year. One year, Raetz told a local newspaper, he ``bought a Mexican kid, dressed him up in a big sombrero, a serape, and hung a green card around his neck. It was all in good clean fun.'' State school Superintendent Bill Honig, who received a similar complaint from the NAACP last week, said his department was investigating the practice.

DOC.HEAD: Nelson Clings to Tiny Lead in Nebraska Recount
DOC.TEXT: Bill Nelson had a 25-vote lead Friday in the recount for Nebraska's Democratic gubernatorial primary, complete but unofficial tallies showed. The recount was required under state law because of the close margin of the May 15 primary, which showed Nelson with a 41-vote lead over Bill Hoppner in the seven-man race. The winner will challenge Gov. Kay Orr, the nation's first woman Republican elected governor, in November. Mrs. Orr, who has received high disapproval ratings in recent polls, is seeking a second four-year term. Even with the recount, the results could be in doubt. Nelson declined to declare victory, saying he wanted to see the numbers the state Board of Canvassers certifies. The unofficial tallies statewide showed Nelson with 44,655 votes and Hoppner with 44,630. In most of the state's 93 counties, the recount produced changes of 10 or fewer votes. ``It means it's not a landslide,'' said Nelson, an Omaha lawyer. ``It was about what we expected. ... Listen, as long as it's one vote that's all that counts.'' ``There's plenty of time to declare me a winner later if I am,'' Nelson said. All figures are unofficial until the state Board of Canvassers meets to certify the recount totals. Secretary of State Allen Beermann said the board is scheduled to meet at 3:30 p.m. Wednesday. Hoppner, an attorney-businessman and former aide to U.S. Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb., scheduled a news conference for 2 p.m. Saturday at his campaign headquarters to announce his reaction, said Larry Grisalano, a campaign spokesman.

DOC.HEAD: Journalists Name Computer Maker in Injury Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: Eight journalists filed a $270 million lawsuit against a computer maker on Friday, contending they suffered disabling injuries from using the company's word processors in newsrooms. The suit, filed in U.S. District Court in Manhattan, charged that Atex Publishing Systems, a subsidiary of the Eastman Kodak Co., was negligent in marketing the computers and had failed to warn users of the dangers or to develop substitute systems. It also alleged that the company ``ignored, suppressed or disregarded'' medical studies about ``the causal relationship between the repetitive use of computer systems and cumulative trauma disorders.'' The journalists, each seeking $20 million in punitive damages and $10 million in compensatory damages, included two from Newsday, two from American Banker and individual staffers at The Associated Press, New York Newsday, The Village Voice and Discount Store News. Three spouses also asked $10 million each for loss of companionship, bringing the total number of plaintiffs to 11. None of the employers were named as defendants. Ruth Marcus, an attorney for the plaintiffs, said New York state law provides that workers cannot sue employers for work-related injuries but must pursue such claims through workmen's compensation. Eastman Kodak spokesman John Labella said the company had no comment, ``as our attorneys have not yet seen the suit.'' It was the second lawsuit filed in New York this month against the company, which manufactures computer systems designed for use in newsrooms. Three reporters and an editor at New York Newsday demanded $40 million in a negligence suit filed June 4 in Manhattan Supreme Court, the newspaper reported Friday. Marcus said there were ``very few'' such lawsuits to date, ``but on the other hand it has become a very serious and pervasive problem.'' The suit alleged the eight journalists ``developed and suffered severe, permanent and disabling cumulative trauma disorders, as well as psychological injuries,'' from repeated use of the Atex video display terminals. It said cumulative trauma disorders included ``repetitive strain injuries, musculoskeletal and nerve disorders, upper extremity pain syndrome, carpal tunnel syndrome, tendinitis and other injuries to the upper extremities.'' The eight journalists named as plaintiffs are: Susan Harrigan of New York Newsday, Laurie Garrett and Sandra Peddie of Newsday, Martha Gioumousis of Discount Store News, Kathy Silberger of The Village Voice, Wendy Grover and David Neustadt of American Banker and Anne Buckley of The Associated Press. The other plaintiffs are Harrigan's husband, Peter Benjaminson; Peddie's husband, Brian Quinn, and Neustadt's wife Maisie McAdoo.

DOC.HEAD: Engineer Arrested For Exporting Star Wars Secrets
DOC.TEXT: A defense technology exporter was arrested Friday for allegedly shipping ``Star Wars'' technology and data to South Africa via West Germany without a license, the U.S. Attorney's office said. Ronald Hoffman, 51, of Los Angeles, appeared before U.S. Magistrate Robert M. Stone and was ordered jailed in lieu of $500,000 bail. A preliminary hearing was scheduled July 5. According to a statement from U.S. Attorney Robert L. Brosio's office, U.S. Customs officials began investigating Hoffman five months ago in an undercover scheme called Operation Exodus. Authorities say Hoffman, the owner of Los Angeles-based Plume Technology, sent binders filled with sensitive data and computer-related software to West Germany on Thursday. Shipment of the materials required prior approval by the State Department, Brosio's office said.

Cement blocks were all that remained of homes, fallen branches stood where trees used to be and muddy streams meandered through the outskirts of this Ohio River town after a furious flash flood. Residents donned shorts and hip-waders Friday to begin putting their lives back together after 5{ inches of rain fell in 3{ hours late Thursday, churning floodwaters that left at least 11 people dead and 51 others missing early today. The shock had not worn off, said police officer Bruce Fink, whose bristly face bore signs of more than 20 hours on duty, including work at a temporary morgue set up at a funeral home. ``We have counselors back there now, but we've lost whole families. It's just been devastating,'' he said Friday night.

The streets of Bucharest were calm for the first time in four days today after coal miners went home at the behest of President-elect Ion Iliescu, who thanked them ``with all my heart'' for helping put down unrest. The state Rompres news agency quoted railway official Ion Tica as saying the last train of miners left Bucharest late Friday night for western Romania. ``Absolutely all the miners left Bucharest Friday night, headed back to their jobs,'' Rompres said. ``The process of normalization is continuing. The central areas of the city are quiet. Subways, street cars, buses and trolley buses are running normally.'' No miners were visible this morning. But on Friday evening, one miner said small contingents from each mine would remain in the capital in case of renewed trouble. He spoke on condition of anonymity.

President Bush said he must ensure the ``integrity of the civil service'' as he vetoed a bill relaxing 51-year-old curbs on the off-duty political activity of government workers. Two days after the Senate upheld his 11th veto, an authorization bill for Amtrak, Bush cast the 12th veto of his presidency. No Bush veto has yet been overturned. ``The Hatch Act has upheld the integrity of the civil service by assuring that federal employees are hired and promoted based upon their qualifications and not their political loyalties,'' he said Friday in a veto message to Congress. Robert Tobias, president of the National Treasury Employees Union, representing federal employees in 16 agencies and departments, called the veto ``wrongheaded'' and urged the Senate to override it.

The blaze aboard the leaking Mega Borg has been extinguished and firefighters doused the sizzling supertanker today to avoid a flare-up. The fire was put out Friday, but Coast Guard and state officials warned that the Norwegian ship crippled in an explosion June 8 still posed a threat. ``There are no flames. However it's still real hot and if we walk away from it right now, it may reflash. It's not yet dead,'' Coast Guard Chief Petty Officer Todd Nelson said. The accident left 4.3 million gallons of light African crude in the Gulf of Mexico _ the fifth worst spill in U.S. history. Tar balls from a 10-mile long slick were expected Sunday on the Bolivar Peninsula, about 40 miles east of Galveston.

Big-city mayors are leading an effort to pressure the federal government to increase spending on drug, poverty, housing and other urban problems. The mayors opened their annual summer meeting Friday by denouncing the 1980s as ``a decade of neglect of America's cities'' and attacking Congress and the White House for spending billions on foreign aid, the savings and loan bailout and other programs while cutting aid to cities. ``We have to do something,'' San Diego Mayor Maureen O'Connor said in urging fellow mayors to be more militant in their lobbying of Congress and the Bush administration. ``Our pleas have been falling on deaf ears.'' The host mayor for U.S. Conference of Mayors session, Chicago's Richard M. Daley, chastised administration officials _ drug czar William Bennett for one _ who have accused the mayors of whining in asking for more federal help.

DOC.HEAD: Tonight on PBS, `Ring' Cycle The Way Wagner Wanted It
DOC.TEXT: Richard Wagner never was content just to write operas _ he longed to control every detail of how and where they were performed. In 1850, immersed in a project called ``Siegfried's Tod,'' he vowed that this time he would do it HIS way. ``I am toying with the boldest of plans,'' the composer wrote to a friend from Zurich, Switzerland, where he was living. ``I would have a theater erected here on the spot, made of planks ... and give three performances _ free of course _ in the space of a week, after which the theater would then be demolished.'' Twenty-six years later, ``Siegfried's Tod'' had blossomed into four operas, a 17-hour epic titled ``Der Ring des Nibelungen.'' And Wagner had designed and built his own wooden theater, an acoustical gem with a covered orchestra pit in the town of Bayreuth, Germany. There the world premiere unfolded on Aug. 13, 14, 16 and 17, 1876. Wagner had dreamed of presenting the four operas on successive days, but he realized that would put impossible burdens on the singers. Since then, most productions have added one more day off, so a typical ``Ring'' cycle takes six days from start to finish. Now, thanks to television, American audiences can savor Wagner's marathon masterpiece the way he conceived it. Beginning tonight, the Public Broadcasing Service will present the Metropolitan Opera's production on four consecutive nights. It's a $5 million undertaking that should please purists and win new admirers for Wagner's tale of greed, love and redemption set in a fantastical world populated by mermaids, dwarfs, giants and gods. The Met's ``Ring'' has been hailed by some critics for its faithful approach to Wagner's original intentions and lambasted by others as stodgy and lacking a modern point of view. Some productions nowadays put Wotan, Bruennhilde & Co. into time tunnels, nuclear holocausts or 19th-century factories. The Met sticks to Wagner's original settings, which are bizarre enough without updating. Modern stage technology helps. In the first Bayreuth production, the three Rhinemaidens climbed into an oversize bathing machine for the opening scene of ``Das Rheingold'' at the bottom of the Rhine River. At the Met, water is suggested by lighting and a scrim stretched across the stage. The finale, in which a castle collapses, the river overflows and the home of the gods goes up in flames, looks awesome thanks to the trickery of producer Otto Schenk, set designer Guenther Schneider-Siemssen and lighting director Gil Wechsler. Thanks to tactful editing, the TV version, directed by Brian Large, actually offers some advantages over the live performances. First and foremost are the subtitles, which help the listener through those long monologues for which Wagner is notorious. Host F. Murray Abraham introduces each episode and provides useful plot summaries. In addition, crucial stage effects that tended to go awry in the theater work perfectly on TV. The anvil that Siegfried breaks in two with his magic sword sometimes crumpled too soon in the opera house, but on TV it splits right on cue. And singers who sounded vocally stressed in live performance come off better, because the videotape editors were able to combine the best moments of several performances from the last two seasons. This is especially true of tenor Siegfried Jerusalem, who looks great, acts superbly, but sings erratically in the grueling role of Siegfried. Hildegard Behrens' grace and emotional involvement make her Bruennhilde memorable, though her voice is not in the league of heroic sopranos like Kirsten Flagstad and Birgit Nilsson. One thing TV audiences definitely won't see is the accident in which Miss Behrens was hit on the head by a beam that collapsed too soon at the end of a ``Goetterdaemmerung'' this spring. She was not seriously hurt but missed several later performances. Other standouts include basses James Morris, a handsome, rich-voiced Wotan, and Matti Salminen, a thundering, malevolent Hagen; baritone Ekkehard Wlaschiha and tenor Heinz Zednik as the deliciously repellent dwarf brothers Alberich and Mime; and mezzo Christa Ludwig, past her vocal prime but still compelling as both Fricka and Waltraute. As the incestuous brother-and-sister Siegmund and Sieglinde, who enter the story Tuesday in ``Die Walkuere,'' tenor Gary Lakes and soprano Jessye Norman sound beautiful. But they are far too amply proportioned to look or act the parts of impetuous young lovers, especially in closeup. A couple of minor vocal notes: On Wednesday, in Act Two of ``Siegfried,'' we get to hear, but not see, the lovely Dawn Upshaw chirping away as the Forest Bird. On Thursday, in the prologue to ``Goetterdaemmerung,'' pay attention to the Third Norn. She's a young soprano named Andrea Gruber who's destined for bigger and better things.

Elsewhere in television ... SHAW SHIFTS: Cable News Network anchor Bernard Shaw, who has been co-anchoring ``The International Hour'' at 3 p.m. EDT, shifts to prime time tonight as the new co-anchor of the 8 p.m. ``Prime News.'' Shaw, the best-known of CNN's anchormen, will continue anchoring the one-hour ``World Today'' with former Texas judge Cartherine Crier. That program starts at 6 p.m. EDT. Shaw is being succeeded on ``The International Hour'' by Sharyl Attkisson, a former reporter and weekend anchor from WTVT-TV in Tampa, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Activists Call For Riots And Promise Demonstrations At AIDS Meeting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to include reservations on call for riots, police comment; PICKS UP 8th graf pvs, ``As Kramer ...''
DOC.TEXT: A prominent AIDS activist is calling for riots at this week's Sixth International AIDS Conference, and while most demonstrators won't go that far, many have promised to disrupt the meeting with protests inside and outside the convention hall. The call for riots came from Larry Kramer, one of the founders of the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power, or ACT UP. It is the most militant AIDS organization. And Kramer may be its most militant member. In articles published in gay newspapers around the country, Kramer wrote, ``Every human being who wants to end the AIDS epidemic must be in San Francisco ... screaming, yelling, furiously angry, protesting at this stupid conference. WE MUST RIOT!'' ACT UP is a grass-roots group without leaders or a hierarchy. It was founded in New York in 1987, and now has perhaps 2,000 members there. Twenty-five chapters have sprung up across the country, some with several hundred members. Of the conference organizers, Kramer said, ``My feeling is these are the same idiots putting on this conference who have bumbled the epidemic for 10 years and made mistake after mistake. ``If you really want my gut feeling,'' he said in an interview last week, ``I think the war against AIDS has been lost.'' San Francisco police say they expect demonstrations at the convention, but no violence. ``Outside of Mr. Kramer, we don't know of anybody talking riot or violence,'' said Sgt. Jerome Senkir. ``We're hoping for a peaceful conference. I think at this point that's going to happen.'' As Kramer pointed out in his articles, the AIDS meeting, which begins Wednesday in San Francisco, provides an unparalleled opportunity for activists to deliver their message. Some 12,000 scientists and 1,800 members of the news media are registered to attend. The conference was established as an annual forum for presentation of the latest scientific reports on AIDS, but increasingly is becoming the target of protests. Last year in Montreal, the opening of the conference was delayed for an hour when 200 activists seized he podium to demand better access to AIDS drugs and an end to discrimination. Peaceful demonstrations continued later outside the convention center. Larger and more disruptive demonstrations are expected this year. Some protesters will remain outside the meeting, boycotting the conference to protest a policy that allows the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service to bar foreigners infected with the AIDS virus. The New York chapter of ACT UP will not boycott the meeting. At least 50 of its members have registered, and they promise to carry their protests inside. Protests are liable to occur ``at the most visible events, or at anything where a Bush administration official or a member of the executive committee is at the podium,'' said Peter Staley of ACT UP New York. The ``executive committee'' is a group of scientists that sets policy for the AIDS Clinical Trials Group, the government's program for testing new AIDS drugs. It is run by the National Institutes of Health. ``There will be two major messages we'll be trying to deliver there,'' said Staley. ``First off is the rage our community is feeling now with the INS.'' Secondly, he said, ``We want to deliver the message to the scientific community that they have failed thus far in reducing AIDS to a chronic manageable disease _ from the death sentence that it is now.'' ACT UP has become adept at organizing angry demonstrations. Its most recent protest occurred at the National Institutes of Health. A thousand activists gathered there in May to demand increases in federal AIDS research; eighty-two were arrested. Even before the demonstration, the National Institutes of Health was so upset by ACT UP's criticisms that it took the unusual step of sending science reporters a detailed, 30-page response. ``Like it or not, we've got a debate going about the government's AIDS research effort,'' said Staley. During the May demonstration, ``there was debate in the corridors of the NIH,'' he said. ``Arguments broke out as to whether we were right or wrong.'' At the same time, ACT UP has worked quietly behind the scenes to help change government policy. Its members now are consulted by the NIH and the Food and Drug Administration. ``We seem to have access to anyone we want,'' said Charles Franchino, a member of the ACT UP's treatment and data committee. ``When we meet with government people, there's the specter of 3,000 people standing behind us. And that's what's gotten us in the door.'' Kramer's call for riots has divided activists. It was criticized by gay and lesbian groups in San Francisco. ``San Francisco is not an angry town like New York is,'' Kramer said. One group there, he noted, plans a quiet candlelight protest, but militants elsewhere have put the city on notice. ``I do know that the city is terrified that there really are going to be riots, and I suspect it will be very much a police state for those days,'' he said. ``After Montreal, there was a lot of hope. This year there is a lot of despair, because that hope has simply not appeared.'' Drugs continued to be tested slowly in a rigid system, Kramer said. And for many people with AIDS, it already is too late. ``We're talking about another savings and loan scandal,'' he said. ``We're all going to wake up and it's going to cost $500 billion.'' New York state has just reported that its annual expenses for AIDS care topped $1 billion for the first time last year. In 10 years, researchers have projected that one in 24 people in New York City will have AIDS. A new AIDS infection occurs in the United States every minute. ``The figures are grotesque and no one's paying attention to them,'' Kramer said. In a letter to activists who opposed his call to riot, Kramer wrote, ``You are free not to riot and you are free to criticize my call to riot ... ``And we are all free to die.''

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Seeks to Recover Rawlings' Works, Letters
DOC.TEXT: ``Cross Creek belongs to the wind and the rain, to the sun and the seasons, to the cosmic secrecy of seed, and beyond, to all time.'' _ Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings.

Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings, with her endearing portraits of rural Florida life and people, belongs to her adopted state. Now, efforts are being made, including a federal lawsuit, to return all the manuscripts of the late Pulitzer Prize-winning author to the University of Florida library, as instructed in her will. Rawlings' widower, 89-year-old Norton Baskin, recently filed suit against the Seajay Society, a non-profit literary group in Columbia, S.C. The group has one of Rawlings' unpublished novels, some short stories and 81 letters that he wants returned. Rawlings is well known for her depictions of ``Florida Crackers''; her 1939 Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, ``The Yearling,'' the tale of a boy and his deer in the Florida wilderness; and ``Cross Creek,'' stories of the Alachua County community where she lived from 1928 until her death in 1953. She wrote in the character-speaking vernacular that Mark Twain had utilized so well. When she told her housekeeper, Martha, about winning the Pulitzer, the woman replied, ``Well, ain't that nice? Bet nobody else at Cross Creek got one.'' Her home at Cross Creek is a state museum, preserved as it was when Rawlings did her writing there. Rawlings was born in Washington, D.C., in 1896 and educated in Wisconsin. She worked as a journalist in New York state, but gave it up in 1928 to live and write on the 72-acre citrus orchard she bought in Cross Creek. It was the same year Ernest Hemingway arrived in Key West. Her first husband, Charles Rawlings, was also a journalist. They divorced, and she met Baskin, a hotel owner, several years later. They married in 1941, and had a second home in St. Augustine where she died of a brain hemmorrage. Rawlings' life and work were portrayed by Mary Steenburgen in the critically acclaimed movie ``Cross Creek,'' in which Baskin played a minor role. The state regents granted the university permission to either join Baskin's suit or file suit on its own to recover the manuscripts. A decision will be made in the next few weeks, according to Barbara Wingo, associate legal counsel for the university, on how the university plans to proceed. ``We will use what we consider the best way to get the manuscripts back and have them published,'' she said. The unpublished manuscripts Baskin is seeking to recover include numerous short works from the 1920s and a 1928 novel, ``Blood of My Blood.'' The items were stored for 26 years at the Massachusetts home of Julia Scribner Bigham, Rawlings' longtime friend and executor of her literary works. Under provisions of Rawlings' will, the university has the right to any published and unpublished manuscripts and literary property, Wingo said. Bigham's heirs found the works in 1987 and the Seajay Society obtained the works for $12,500. Steve Matthews, a member of the Seajay Society, said the works were given to Bigham by Rawlings and were not part of the Rawlings' estate. A lawsuit is being contemplated, Wingo said, because extensive negotiations with the society have failed to produce any results. ``They are not going to give them up,'' she said. The society is dedicated to enhancing awareness of, and appreciation for, ``unduly neglected aspects of Southern writers and Southern culture,'' Matthews said. Some of the Rawlings' works held by the society are from as early as 1914 and were probably written for a creative writing class. Others were written at the start of her literary career in Van Hornesville in upstate New York. Baskin said his wife's writings are important to understanding her progress as a writer. They should be returned to the University of Florida, he said. ```Blood of My Blood' ... it's a very personal thing. It's Marjorie's life,'' Baskin said. Rawlings submitted the manuscript to the Atlantic Monthly Press in a competition. It is a story about the tense relationship between the author and her mother. The Seajay Society wanted to publish ``Blood of My Blood'' through the University of Florida press, but was denied permission by Baskin, Matthews said. The University of Florida library is eager to get the manuscripts, said Sam Gowan, associate director for collection management. Retrieving the Rawlings' manuscripts, he said, is important to both the library and to scholars of the author. That would allow researchers to find most of her works under one roof. ``I think what is really most important is that the library feels it is the depository of record,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: First Photographer at Chernobyl Opens U.S. Exhibit
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The ferris wheel at an amusement park turns riderless in the wind. And the eyes of children stare unknowingly at a cameraman whose free hand holds a Geiger counter registering off the scale. Visitors to the photo exhibit of Igor Kostin, the first Soviet photographer on the scene of the April 26, 1986 explosion at the Chernobyl power plant, are greeted by the images of burn victims, rescue workers and the contaminated rubble. It is a testament to the world's worst nuclear accident. There are the melancholic strains of Mozart, Bach and Beethoven, and the darkness of a black tunnel representing the fallen cooling tower at the plant, which was among Kostin's first sights when he arrived there 11 hours after the explosion and fire. ``This is definitely not art,'' said Kostin, a 53-year-old industrial designer turned photographer. ``It can't be a piece of art because it was such a terrible thing. It's a historical tragedy for our people and a warning for other people that this could happen anywhere.'' Kostin was in Baltimore to kick off the U.S. tour of his exhibit, ``Chernobyl: Not to Be Forgotten.'' About 100 black and white and color photos are arranged in chronological order, beginning with the destroyed building of Reactor 4, the arrival of rescue workers and nuclear power officials and the cleanup operation, and ending with more recent photos of the Chernobyl trial, protests in Kiev, residents who either have refused to leave the 18-mile danger zone or are awaiting government relocation, and deformed animals and contaminated crops in the area. But next to the devastating scenes of hospital patients, abandoned homes and the silent amusement park in the nearby village of Pripyat are Kostin's testimony that life continues _ photos of a woman giving birth to the first post-Chernobyl baby, a new housing settlement built for evacuees and a man standing defiantly outside his contaminated home with a sign that reads, ``Attention countrymen and soldiers: Do not destroy this house. We live here.'' The exhibit ends with a brief photocopied statement from Kostin: ``When I think back, it seems as if it were yesterday. I can hear the noise of the helicopter and I can see the people who had to leave their homes taking with them only a cat or a kitchen pot as they fled from the danger. Then I think, Did it all really happen?'' ``When people look at the photographs, each person sees something different, but I want them to see what I saw there four years ago and since,'' he said. ``The reaction of all people has been the same _ the sorrow is the same and they have the same tears.'' Kostin, who lives in Kiev, about 60 miles from the plant, continues to return to the danger zone despite the health risk. ``I went there the first time because I just had to see with my own eyes, and I took my camera so other people could see,'' said Kostin, a photographer with the Soviet news agency Novosti. ``I go back now because it is a magnet drawing me. Someone has to continue to go back into the affected area, to show the world that there are still people living there, to show that it never should have happened and that it must never happen again. I've already been exposed. That's my job now.'' According to official Soviet figures, 31 people were killed in the explosion and fire at the Ukrainian plant, although a Soviet newspaper has speculated the death toll could be as high as 250. The Soviet government has said it plans to continue to relocate villagers from the contaminated area, but there is little money for housing. Kostin said the government has been cooperative in allowing him to show the photographs and to travel with the exhibit. ``Five years ago I couldn't even think about this,'' he said. ``I'm happy to live at a time when I can show what I've done and can tell what I have to tell.'' But when it comes to telling his story, Kostin said he prefers to let the photographs stand alone. ``If I have anything more to say, it would be this: I would like to give a gift to the American people and to the people of the world _ an armful of uncontaminated flowers from a clean field in the Ukraine. I wish I could say it didn't happen.'' The exhibit, which already has toured four cities in Italy and Austria, will be in Baltimore through mid-June. Susu Erca, of Imago, the Italian firm sponsoring the exhibit, said negotiations are continuing with Boston and Portland, Ore., but the next stop on the tour has not been confirmed. Depending on its reception in the United States, the exhibit is expected to be on tour for a year, Erca said. Proceeds from the exhibit, which has a $1 entry fee, will help establish the Igor Kostin Fund for Children of Chernobyl, Erca said. The fund will go toward medical supplies for hospitals within the danger zone.
