DOC.HEAD: Rap With a Sense of Humor From a College Grad
DOC.TEXT: When Marvin Young was dutifully doing his economics homework two years ago at the University of Southern California, he thought that after graduation he would settle down to the 9-to-5 desk job grind. But somewhere along the line he became Young M.C. Today the rapper not only has an economics degree, he also has a top-selling album and single, a pair of music awards and a promotion deal with Pepsi. ``I didn't intend to get into the music business the way that I did. It was just luck _ it was kind of fate _ that it happened,'' he said. ``I intended to go to college and get my degree, then get a regular job and use that money to put out my records and then see what happened from there.'' In the past year, Young M.C. has won an American Music Award for best new rap artist, and a Grammy Award for best rap performance with the song ``Bust a Move.'' His album, ``Stone Cold Rhymin','' has gone double platinum _ selling over 2 million copies. He also wrote the hit songs ``Wild Thing'' and ``Funky Cold Medina'' for fellow rapper Tone Loc. And he recently made a deal with Pepsi to promote ``cool cans,'' stylized versions of the soft drink's traditional can, over the summer. Not bad for someone who is just 22. However, Young M.C. hasn't settled down in the music business just yet. He wants to use his bachelor's degree in economics to go even further. ``Going out now and being Young M.C., and all the records and the awards and whatever the case may be, it's good now for the way I'm thinking, but in the future it also is a building block for me to be a competent executive in the business,'' he said. Dressed in a black running suit before his recent Worcester appearance with pop-duo Milli Vanilli, Young M.C. said his music is purposely lighter than some other rap songs that have drawn criticism for controversial lyrics. ``Bust a Move'' is a case in point. The song follows the humorous path of boy meets girl _ almost. ``It's like, OK, a guy sees a girl and wants to talk to that girl _ don't be shy, go up to her _ `Bust a Move.' It's just that simple, instead of getting deep and graphic and all of that. To me it's unnecessary.'' Other rappers, most notaby groups such as N.W.A., Public Enemy and 2 Live Crew, have come under fire for music that is fueled by racial, social and sexual issues. ``It's not the subject matter. It's not the fact that people will get on a record and say, `the government is unjust,' or `black people are being mistreated,' because if you say it like that it's not that offensive,'' Young said. ``But when you swear, or when you degrade other races, or degrade women, or get violent and talk about killing people, that's what is found offensive.'' Young M.C. said he keeps controversy out of his lyrics because of his fans, and he wants to establish an audience before he starts voicing his opinions. ``The thing about it, to me, is that you go at your own pace,'' he said. ``You don't beat people over the head with the things you want to say. And you also don't say it in a way to challenge or offend anybody.'' Young M.C. was born in London but grew up in Queens, N.Y. By the time he reached high school, he was already writing the songs that would eventually make up about half of ``Stone Cold Rhymin'.'' Then, two years ago, a single and somewhat unconventional audition led Matt Dike and Mike Ross to sign Young M.C. to their ``Delicious Vinyl'' record label. ``I just rapped for them over the phone _ and they signed me. It all happened really fast,'' he said. Since that fateful phone call, Young M.C. has become known as something of a prodigy in the music business. He wrote ``Wild Thing'' for Tone Loc in 35 minutes, and ``Funky Cold Medina'' in under an hour. ``Bust a Move'' took a mere hour-and-a-half, and it remained on Billboard magazine's hot 100 singles chart for more than 40 weeks. And all of the writing took place while he was still at USC. ``See, that's what happens when you're in college and you're hungry and you're sick of professors and classes,'' he joked. Despite his Cinderella-like launch in the business, Young M.C. is not about to turn into a pumpkin and fade into obscurity. He says the same about his medium _ rap is here to stay, regardless of the critics who believe it is a passing musical fad. ``There is no way it's going to die out. It's a young people's music. It's just like how folk music was in the '60s,'' he said. ``You can get a lot more thoughts across with more words. And there's a lot more words to a rap song than there is to a singing song.'' Now the pressure is on to make more hit records. But the fame hasn't gone to his head. If anything, it's made him hungrier. ``When people talk to me and say `you've made it' or something like that, I don't feel like I've made it. Two or three albums down the line if I still have the same appeal I have now, then that's what I'm talking about,'' he said. ``You have a lot of artists come out and they have great albums for one year, then two or three years down the line you don't know where they are.'' In the meantime, Young M.C. is looking with amazement at his sudden success. He never thought he'd achieve all this when he was sitting at his dorm-room desk pondering figures and formulas. ``I was an economics major and now I'm rapping for a living'' he said with a laugh. ``It doesn't seem to follow.''

DOC.HEAD: GOP Candidates Standing Firm Against Taxes Even as Bush Wavers
DOC.TEXT: Republican Bob Smith has won three House races stressing his opposition to higher taxes. The New Hampshire congressman isn't about to drop a winning strategy just because George Bush is wavering. If the president changes course, ``I'll disagree with him point-blank,'' says Smith. He's counting on the ``no new taxes'' theme to sweep him into the Senate this year. Rep. Bill Schuette wears a ``keep-the-pledge'' button as he campaigns for the GOP Senate nomination in Michigan. Presidential backpedaling on taxes doesn't bother him _ as long as the debate keeps generating publicity for his own views. ``It is in the newspapers all across the state _ taxes are being discussed in Washington, where does Bill Schuette stand, foursquare against raising taxes,'' Schuette said. ``Frankly, it helps me.'' Sound and fury over flag-burning have overwhelmed the nation's political debate in the past week. But the average citizen is more likely to be affected by a quiet series of budget talks in Washington that are likely to produce higher taxes _ Bush's famous campaign promise notwithstanding. Even as Bush edges away from his ``read my lips'' campaign rhetoric, Republican candidates who have staked their careers on the ``no new taxes'' pledge are embracing it as tightly as ever. Publicly, they won't concede anything _ even that Bush has softened his position. They say he's merely done what was necessary to open a dialogue with Congress on the budget. Last week a business lobbyist at a lunch with Rep. Hank Brown, another GOP Senate candidate, said higher taxes on gas, tobacco and liquor appear to be ``a done deal'' among the budget negotiators. ``Am I wrong?'' the lobbyist asked hopefully. ``You surely don't believe the president of the United States is going to break his word?'' Brown replied lightly. But Bush entered into discussions with Congress by saying there were no preconditions on the talks, and most analysts expect tax increases to be part of any agreement. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater confirmed the impression last week when he accidentally referred to the sessions as tax negotiations, later correcting the word ``tax'' to ``budget.'' ``The best thing Republicans can hope for right now is for the administration to support some non-tax taxes like user fees, sin taxes, possibly even an increase in the (income) tax rate on the very wealthiest,'' said analyst Stuart Rothenberg, editor of The Political Report. Brown, running for an open Colorado seat, agrees the dilemma may be ``finessed'' that way. But he and other no-tax candidates don't see much difference between general tax hikes and the narrower measures that seem to be on the table. Any tax increase is anathema to them. Their resistance is understandable, given the enormous success Republicans have had with campaigns against ``tax-and-spend'' Democrats. The issue continues to look strong. In a Gallup poll last month, for example, 36 percent of those questioned said they'd be less likely to vote for a senator or congressman who had supported a tax increase. The figure was 42 percent among Republicans. California voters' approval this month of a doubled gas tax at first was interpreted as a sign that the tax revolt is over. But now analysts say it signals only that middle-class voters are willing to pay more for something they want _ in this case, better roads. Bush's sudden veer away from his hard-line anti-tax rhetoric caught Republican candidates unawares, and none were more exposed than the eight House members giving up their seats to run for the Senate. But the shift at the top has not cost them a potent issue, as they had feared. Many, like Schuette, are discovering that it carries unexpected dividends. Rep. Lynn Martin, R-Ill., challenging Democratic Sen. Paul Simon, said her surprise at Bush's move ``was later overcome by my delight. It certainly allowed me to make my position clear, which is always nice. It gave me advantages that at the first blush I didn't think were going to be there.'' Bush's shift ``constantly comes up'' on the campaign trail, says Rep. Larry Craig, R-Idaho. ``I simply say that I have never voted for a tax increase in the 10 years I have served in the U.S. House. I will not vote for a tax increase now. I am disappointed that my president ... is willing at least to begin some consideration of possible tax increases.'' In the event Bush agrees to a budget package that raises taxes, there will be no shortage of candidates to remind him of his broken promise. If people vote for higher taxes, says Smith, ``so be it. But they didn't vote for it in 1988. That was the theme of the campaign.''

DOC.HEAD: Dispute in Obscure Belgian Stock Market Has Profound Implications
DOC.TEXT: Trading in Belgium's bourse never has been high-profile, but a dispute over control of market-moving information here has grabbed attention of brokers and regulators far beyond the borders. The stock exchange is battling a group of Belgian and international news outlets over who has the right to release news first. The news group has accused the exchange of seeking to monopolize the news, violating the European Community's fair competition rules and press freedom. The group includes Reuters Ltd., the largest financial information reporting service. The exchange has said it wants to level the playing field for market participants by becoming a clearinghouse for market-sensitive corporate news under a stock market reform bill now under government review. Presently, companies release news to the exchange and the press at the same time. Under the reform, only the exchange would get the news, then release it to investors and traders through a datbase to which the media could subscribe. Although some say this is strictly a domestic fight, others fear it could have more profound implications for trading elsewhere, especially in view of other events that suggest the world is moving to 24-hour global trading. The 12-nation European Community is scrutinizing the Belgian dispute with special concern because it plans a community-wide trading system after 1992. The system presumably would have uniform rules for disclosure of information that could affect stock prices. The debate over the issue already has led the Belgian government to review the stock market reform plan. ``We are taking this very seriously,'' said Bernard Snoy, an aide to Finance Minister Philippe Maystadt. Reuters and several Belgian media groups have complained to the government the stock market is misinterpreting the bill. They argue that if the bourse gets to handle corporate news before the media, this will violate EC laws on clarity in corporate matters and fair competition. They say the stock market cannot get company news to the public quickly. They also say it can't be done without risking insider trading abuses, in which stock market insiders can act on corporate news before others can. ``This could institutionalize insider trading,'' said Herman Smedts, manager of electronic information at the Financieel Ekonomische Tijd, a financial daily. But bourse officials say their method avoids insider trading by giving the bourse a chance to suspend dealings in a company stock before the information is released. Also, they say, by releasing news after trading has closed they can assure all investors will see reports in the media the next day and can act on it simultaneously when trading reopens. ``We are mainly concerned that information gets to all people at the same time,'' said Jean Peterbroeck, head of the Brussels stock market commission, a panel intended to make sure the exchange functions in an orderly manner. There is also money at stake. The bourse, a non-profit outfit, has created BDB, its own database service. The media groups say that by channeling information to BDB, the exchange gets a monopoly on news and gets to finance the computer trading system the Brussels bourse bought in 1988. ``It's partially true we are out to make money,'' said BDB General Manager Jean-Pierre Monmart. ``But we never had the idea of monopolizing (market news). Organizing, yes. Monopolizing, no.'' The media groups, fearful of losing customers, point to the New York Stock Exchange as an example of how the stock market could set its news policy. The NYSE requires companies to release their news to the exchange and to Reuters and the Dow Jones Co. _ the world's two key financial news groups _simultaneously. The Paris and Frankfurt exchanges have similar rules. For their part, the Brussels bourse points to the London International Stock Exchange, which gets a first crack at corporate news. Brussels also says the media have ulterior motives. Reuters, which already receives instant data on stock prices, volumes and some price bids, wants access to even more exchange information. ``They could only want that to mount their own trading system'' to supplant conventional exchanges, said one bourse official, who asked not to be named. Reuters says it only wants the same type of information other markets provide. It and the other media groups proposed creating a cooperative, owned by information vendors, to replace BDB. The two alternatives _ one requiring simultaneous disclosure, the other giving a stock exchange precedence _ are likely to be debated as exchanges across the EC work to establish a Community-wide stock trading system. Sources said the EC federation of stock exchanges has agreed in principle that their Price Information Program for Europe (PIPE) would resemble the London stock exchange. Media groups have said they will challenge that.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, June 18

DOC.HEAD: Khrushchev, Rusk Sons Chronicle Fathers' Careers
DOC.TEXT: Dean Rusk and Nikita Khrushchev, two leaders of the Cold War, now have something else in common: sons who are offering assessments of their fathers' roles in both war and peace. Richard Rusk, in what he calls ``my attempt to know my aging father,'' interviewed the former secretary of state for long hours with a tape recorder rolling. Sergei Khrushchev, describing himself at one point as ``a witness to my father's meditations,'' chronicled the last seven years in the life of the Soviet leader who was driven from power in 1964. ``As I Saw It,'' by Dean Rusk as told to Richard Rusk, will be published June 25 by W.W. Norton & Company. ``Khrushchev on Khrushchev: An Inside Account of the Man and His Era,'' by Sergei Khrushchev is scheduled for June 28 publication by Little, Brown and Company. Nikita Khrushchev was a coal miner's son who rose through the ranks of the Soviet bureaucracy, holding power for 11 years as Communist Party chief and six years as premier before being deposed. He died in 1971. Rusk, 81, lives in Athens, Ga. He was secretary of state from 1961 to 1969 and was, as his son says, ``an architect of a war that killed 58,000 Americans and nearly a million Vietnamese.'' He was with President Kennedy at the summit in Vienna in June 1961, when, in his words, Khrushchev ``set out to intimidate this new, young president of the United States.'' Sergei Khrushchev's view is different: ``The main thing I recall happening at Vienna was that the two men got acquainted. Father returned to Moscow after the summit with a very high opinion of Kennedy.'' Rusk encountered Khrushchev again after going to Moscow in July 1963, to initial a limited atomic test ban treaty. At the Soviet premier's villa on the Black Sea, they batted a badminton bird back and forth with no net and no lines on the floor. After his downfall, Khrushchev was all but forgotten in the Soviet Union _ pictured, his son recalls, as ``a dimwitted hooligan cast upon the throne by fate.'' Only recently has the rehabilitation of his image begun. Rusk, although he held office longer than any secretary of state since Cordell Hull and retired to an honored professorial chair in his native Georgia, had his detractors, too. Historian Arthur M. Schlesinger, a Kennedy White House aide, found him ``the perfect number-two man'' _ ``a baffling leader'' who had ``authority but not command.'' As Richard Rusk sees it, Schlesinger was suggesting ``that Rusk wasn't smart enough for the job.'' Staying on in the Johnson administration after Kennedy's death, the State Department veteran became increasingly a target for opponents of the Vietnamese war. The young Richard Rusk, a student at Cornell, found himself ``caught between love for my father and the growing horror of Vietnam,'' unwilling to volunteer and unwilling to embarrass his father by joining the antiwar movement. In a tape-recorded session two decades later, he pressed Rusk on the point and found him ``unprepared ... for admitting that thousands of American lives, and hundreds of thousands of Vietnamese, might have been lost in vain.'' For the elder Rusk, there were no doubts: ``Because of this nation's commitments, I had a duty to perform: to try to prevent North Vietnam from overrunning South Vietnam by force. That was my job. And I tried to do it.'' The taciturn Rusk and the voluble Khrushchev both at first resisted the idea of writing their memoirs. ``All we wanted to do was to get him involved in some kind of project,'' writes Sergei Khrushchev. ``Father didn't respond to our first suggestions. Sometimes he laughed them off.'' When he did agree to tape record his memoirs, Soviet authorities of the time resisted publication, but the material was published widely abroad. As Sergei Khrushchev's own book neared publication, he was seeking to have a Russian edition of his father's memoirs published ``so as to restore his good name.'' Rusk vowed when he took office in 1961 that he would never write his memoirs, saying he would leave it to the historians. In a preface to Richard Rusk's book, however, he tells how his son ``came home to Georgia after many years in Alaska, years spent, I now realize, attempting to understand and make peace with the events of his youth and of my public service.'' ``He could not do this, could not reforge the broken chain, without me,'' Dean Rusk writes. Reforging the chain, Richard Rusk interviewed family, critics and friends as well as his father. ``At every stage of Dean Rusk's life _ youth, public servant, retired statesman _ were signs of mortality,'' he writes. ``But mainly I found affirmation of the goodness in my dad.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tuesday AMs, June 19, and Thereafter

DOC.HEAD: Some Good News About Junk Bonds
DOC.TEXT: As if to prove that things can't go down forever, most of the news coming from the junk bond market lately has been upbeat. The $200 billion market that paid a steep price for the debt excesses of the 1980s has staged a significant rally in recent months. By some measures, junk bonds have outperformed investment-grade corporate bonds and Treasury bonds. The market really took off last week on news that Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. would inject $1.7 billion into RJR Nabisco. The news eased fears about RJR's ability to continue to meet debt payments when the interest rate on $6 billion of bonds, a bellwether for the market, are reset beginning next year. ``Fundamentally, things have stopped getting worse,'' says Howard Marks, who manages about $1 billion in high yield funds at Trust Company of the West in Los Angeles. To be sure, the market has a long way to go to regain anything like its former vigor. It remains virtually shut to new issues _ volume has dwindled to just $382 million so far this year from more than $12 billion in the same period last year. The drying up of new issues has clipped some wings on Wall Street. Merrill Lynch last week reassigned the two co-heads of its merchant banking department, Raymond Minella and Jeffrey Berenson. They led the firm's expansion into junk bonds, but their department has little to underwrite these days and is stuck with hundreds of millions of dollars in illiquid securities and supposedly temporary bridge loans that can't be refinanced. Defaults, also expected to hit another record this year, were underscored this past week when developer Donald Trump missed a payment due to holders of junk bonds used to finance his Trump Castle casino in Atlantic City, N.J. Those bonds slumped in value afterward. Nonetheless, much of the bad news about defaults already has been discounted. For example, prices on more than $800 million of junk bonds issued by Southland Corp. rose sharply late last week even as the company, which operates the 7-Eleven chain, missed an interest payment. Bondholders hadn't expected Southland to make the payment, says Kingman Penniman, an analyst with McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei. But they were cheered by the company's enhanced offer to exchange the bonds for cash and stock, he said. What's more, the bonds were trading at less than a quarter of their face value. At that level they have value even if Southland liquidates, he says. Bankers say new players such as equity investors and revived demand from long-time junk buyers have given the market fresh strength. In one sign of that strength, the market two weeks ago readily absorbed the sale of $50 million in junk bonds from the Resolution Trust Co., the federal agency liquidating the holdings of failed savings and loans. ``Basically, the market is looking for paper,'' said John Crotty, head of new issues and sales at First Boston Corp. Crotty says the junk market generates nearly $25 billion in interest payments a year, and investors are reinvesting much of that money. Those flows have helped junk bonds recover from the depths reached late last year and early this year. Indeed, First Boston's index of 400 junk issues showed a total return of 5.46 percent from March through May. Ten-year U.S. Treasury bonds returned just 1.32 percent in that period, according to the firm's index. Some institutions are hoping the market gets a further boost from a new auction system set to start next month for junk bonds and lightly traded equities. New York Securities Auction Corp. plans to conduct weekly auctions of securities, primarily junk bonds, over Bloomberg Financial System's electronic screen service. Joel Greenblatt, the Wall Street investor who is starting the service, says the lack of ready price information on junk bonds deters investors. He hopes to counter that by getting institutions to display their offerings on a screen and allowing others to bid for the bonds. ``One of the hallmarks of an efficient market is open information on buyers and sellers,'' says Marks of Trust Company of the West, which has enrolled as a member in the auction system. He said the system ``may increase efficiency and it may increase liquidity.''

DOC.HEAD: Where Have All The Men Gone?
DOC.TEXT: It hasn't become a police matter, and so far there seems to have been little impact on family and social affairs, but there has been a mysterious disappearance of middle-age men from the work force. Statistically speaking, they've left little trace, which amounts to a truly astounding occurrence, since we're not talking about a few guys vanishing here and there. A few disappearances are to be expected, considering the stress factor these days, but this vanishing act involves 30,000 a month. It's been going on since last October, and that means the total now is well over 200,000. Those are significant numbers. Nothing like it has been seen before, and making it more mysterious is the absence of clues. These men haven't been laid off, for example, because they haven't shown up in jobless insurance claims. They've just gone from the rolls, leaving statisticians with the puzzle of figuring out where they went. If the disappearance occurred in just one or two months, it might be dismissed as a statistical aberration. But not this. Economists at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, a securities firm, have been among those seeking an explanation but, while they have an interesting and plausible theory, they haven't yet been able to prove it. Among their findings is that labor force participation by men aged 45 years to 54 years peaked last October, with 91.8 percent of them working, and that the percentage had fallen steadily to reacy 90.1 percent in May. Those unaccustomed to percentages such as these might find such a decline of no special concern, even insignificant. It is anything but, the economists say. It is extremely significant, unprecedented in the entire economic expansion that began eight years ago. They checked the age group one tier below, in the 35 years to 44 years category. The phenomenon couldn't be seen among these younger men. In fact, job participation in that group was decidedly stable rather than unstable. Then they checked the age tier just above, where men aged 55 years to 64 years are counted. While they did find participation by this group had declined quite a bit since the 1950s, that decline leveled off in 1986. In short, since last October, when the middle-age men began disappearing, there was no comparable phenomenon to be found among their older or younger brethren. When so many of similar profile disappear, if only statistically, it suggests something sinister. This becomes especially so when they leave no clues. Had filed for unemployment insurance, for instance, you might assume they had been laid off, and then you might limit your probing to why. But they didn't file for insurance, or at least the statistics suggest they did not. Initial claims for such insurance have moved in a narrow range since last fall _ no sharp runup, no big bulges at all. Sinister indeed! Two hundred thousand men in the prime of life vanish from the labor force without a whimper. No complaints from their wives and children. No obvious explanation in the statistics. No inquiries. No, but there is a possible explanation, and it is anything but sinister. They retired! That is the tentative conclusion of the economists, who explain: ``Having chosen early retirement or settlement packages, many of these men may be ineligible to file for unemployment insurance. Thus, their job disappears without any claim having been filed.'' The puzzling statistics could indicate, they say, that early retirement programs now are being directed at middle managers rather than senior level managers. Lost from the job statistics perhaps, but not from life. They may not labor, but they do live. In fact, if they really did settle for a bundle of money to get lost they're probably living the good life.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Monday, June 18.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Dodged Trouble In Year's First Half
DOC.TEXT: Approaching the midway point of 1990, Wall Street analysts see many blessings to count in the performance of the stock and bond markets so far this year. Stocks have reached record highs in recent weeks, and bond prices have also rallied as interest rates declined. Worries about inflation have ebbed as well. But a slowdown in the pace of economic growth doesn't appear, in the eyes of many forecasters, to have brought business to the brink of any severe, economy-wide recession. Along with whatever enthusiasm those developments may have engendered, many market commentaries and predictions these days express a generous measure of relief. Since New Year's, most observers agree, the markets have tiptoed with remarkable agility through a minefield of potentially serious hazards. Already fading into memory from the early weeks of the year are a severe break in Japanese stock prices _ some of the losses from which have recently been recouped _ and the failure of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the titan of the junk-bond market. More recently, investors have had to grapple with worries about credit problems facing a diverse list of borrowers and lenders ranging from developer Donald Trump to the money-market mutual funds. Even the much-discussed threat of a ``credit crunch'' appears to have been staved off, for the time being at least. Whatever happens during the summer and beyond, many analysts say, the Federal Reserve has kept some ammunition in reserve to use against any signs of developing economic trouble. So far, they note, the Fed has held off on any moves to a more stimulative credit policy as growth has weakened. ``The economy is slowing, but a recession can probably be avoided,'' said Jack Lavery at Merrill Lynch. ``We believe the data to be reported during the weeks ahead will show economic activity to be weak enough and inflation tame enough to spark another Fed easing within the next month.'' Hopes of that sort helped inspire a solid advance in the stock market during the past week. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 73.51 points to 2,935.89, surpassing on Friday its previous closing peak of 2,935.19 reached on June 4. The New York Stock Exchange composite index gained 1.81 to 197.86; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 6.68 to 467.55, and the American Stock Exchange market value index was up 2.84 at 364.03. Volume on the Big Board averaged 155.29 million shares a day, against 168.46 million the week before. As much as they may like the chances for lower interest rates during the second half of the year, many analysts are leery of committing themselves too much in that direction. They haven't forgotten the surprise that hit optimistic forecasters over the early months of 1990, when interest rates jumped along with borrowing costs in the financial centers of Japan and West Germany. Suresh Bhirud, an analyst at Oppenheimer & Co., argues, ``interest rates are most likely to remain in a narrow range at this point.'' With a slowdown in the economy, he says, ``the budget deficit is likely to increase. Therefore, although interest rates may not rise substantially, we doubt they will come down much until there is a meaningful reduction in the deficit. Also, he says, ``real interest rates are still high in Germany and Japan, which will keep pressure on U.S. rates for some time.''

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Banning Smoking on Buses
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound Lines Inc., taking a cue from the airline industry, announced Friday it would ban smoking on its buses beginning Monday. ``Signs are going up right now,'' company spokesman George Gravley said. The ban takes effect at 12:01 a.m. Monday on regularly scheduled buses. Charter service is not affected, the company said. Greyhound's marketing vice president, Ralph Borland, said the ban was a response to recent passenger surveys that indicated riders preferred non-smoking service. He said Greyhound research indicated 22 percent of its passengers smoke, compared to 29 percent of the general public. The company carried 22.5 million passengers last year and has been carrying about 75 percent of that passenger load since a strike by drivers began March 2. Gravley acknowledged that some passengers would be unhappy about the ban. Most buses stop about every two hours for meals or intermediate rest stops and ``we hope that will provide the relief that the smokers need,'' he said. Eight states already ban smoking on buses: California, Idaho, New Jersey, New York, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Utah and Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Kodak and IBM to Develop Integrated Publishing System
DOC.TEXT: Eastman Kodak Co. and IBM Corp. said Friday they will jointly develop publishing computer systems that integrate editorial, advertising and business operations. IBM spokesman Jim Keller said the companies will work together to develop a system that allows a newspaper or magazine to link the different aspects of its operations. The systems will be targeted at large and mid-sized publications, Keller said. The companies did not disclose financial details of the joint venture, which involves Kodak's Electronic Pre-Press Systems Inc. subsidiary and IBM's Media Industry marketing group. EPPS makes units for Atex Publishing Systems. The systems will use IBM hardware and Atex software, but will be designed to be compatible with the existing computer systems used by publishers, said Kodak spokesman John LaBella. He said publishers are increasingly looking for systems that integrate different aspects of their businesses. The companies have had a working relationship for several years, and will introduce a system that integrates pre-press operations at the American Newspaper Publishers Association technical exposition and conference beginning Saturday, LaBella said.

DOC.HEAD: Big Board Takes Steps to Avoid Long-Term Obsolescence
DOC.TEXT: Manhattan's South Street Seaport was a frenetic commercial center in the 19th century but fell victim to technological leaps in moving goods that made its wharves and merchants obsolete. The message has not been lost on another business landmark nearby, the cavernous New York Stock Exchange. This past week the Big Board took steps ultimately designed to avoid the same fate as the seaport, now a trendy singles spot of bars and restaurants where oceangoing clippers are just quaint relics from the pre-Civil War days. NYSE Chairman John Phelan confirmed plans to ease into computerized after-hours trading, which could lead to full 24-hour trading by the year 2000. The NYSE also released a study of stock volatility, aimed at showing that the nation's biggest securities market is sensitive to the anxieties of all investors. Although details of the after-hours trading plan must still be worked out, the aim is to recover business lost to competing exchanges and companies that are trading NYSE stocks on their own when the NYSE is closed. ``There is some volume going overseas, and we'd like to capture some of that volume back,'' Phelan said. The Big Board remains by far the preeminent U.S. place to buy and sell stocks. But in recent years a growing number of investors who want to do business in the off-hours are going to London or Tokyo, a reflection of what appears to be an inexorable march toward a nonstop global marketplace. Other investors have found it more efficient to execute trades via technologically advanced NYSE rivals in the United States. The over-the-counter NASDAQ system, for example, uses computers to match buyers and sellers and is expanding into off-hours trading this September, when it will open at 3:30 a.m. Eastern time. By contrast, the NYSE has clung to an old-fashioned group of market-making ``specialists.'' Although they use computers to make the flow of trading more efficient, the specialist system still hinges on human-to-human contact on the Big Board floor, which opens weekdays at 9:30 a.m. and closes at 4 p.m. The NYSE's traditional reluctance to expand hours has played a partial role in its eroding share of business. It handled only 69.2 percent of all trades in listed stocks last year, a record low. Exchange earnings fell to $6.29 million last year, a 40 percent drop from the $10.45 million earned a year earlier. ``The NYSE is taking a look at after-hours trading basically because of competitive pressures,'' said Joseph Hardiman, chairman of the National Association of Securities Dealers, which runs the NASDAQ system. ``They're trying to be responsive by telling issuers they will be able to provide something.'' The NYSE's other signal of responsiveness to customers came earlier in the week when its Market Volatility and Investor Confidence Panel disclosed findings of a study into causes of stock-price volatility. The most important recommendation was the use of trading halts during times of market stress. But many securities professionals remain opposed to such an idea, arguing it could worsen panicky selling by investors trying to get out of a market before it closed. Some suggested trading halts also could have the ironic side effect of driving business to less restrictive markets abroad. In other business and economic news this past week: _More signals emerged suggesting a slowing economy. Retail and wholesale prices rose modestly in May, easing pressure on inflation, the government reported. It also said the trade deficit shrank dramatically in April, reflecting lower demand for imported oil and autos. _A takeover specialist ensnared in the Ivan Boesky insider trading scandal received a 2-month prison term, one of the mildest punishments meted out in a four-year-old crackdown on securities fraud. Martin A. Siegel, who allegedly took suitcases of cash from Boesky in return for insider tips, could have received 10 years in prison but he cooperated with prosecutors to implicate others. _Standard & Poors Corp., a leading debt-rating agency, lowered its opinion of creditworthiness of Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp., reflecting growing weakness in the automotive industry. The rating downgrade means Ford and Chrysler will find it more costly to borrow money. _Casino developer Donald Trump missed a payment on junk bonds used to finance one of his Atlantic City resorts, the most visible signal yet of the trouble dogging his real estate empire. But another prominent personality with the initials D.T. basked in more positive publicity, luring hordes of moviegoers as the Hollywood blockbuster Dick Tracy opened around the country.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for weekend editions June 16-17.

DOC.HEAD: Honda Dealers to Handle Jeeps
DOC.TEXT: Honda Motor Co. Ltd. will sell Chrysler Corp. Jeeps through some of its dealers in Japan beginning this fall, the companies said Friday. In a joint announcement, Honda and Chrysler said 1991-model Jeep Wranglers and Cherokee sport-utility vehicles will be sold in about 750 of Honda's Primo dealerships. The companies said they expect about 2,000 Jeeps would be sold in the next model year. That would more than double Chrysler's sales in Japan, and marks the first time a U.S. company has used Honda's Japanese dealers to sell vehicles. Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca for years has complained about being shut out of the Japanese market either because of governmental regulations or dealer resistance. Last year, Chrysler sold about 1,500 Jeeps and cars through Chrysler Japan Sales Ltd., a joint venture between the U.S. company and J. Osawa & Co. of Japan. Japanese dealers rarely handle more than one car make at a dealership. ``There is an incredible amount of dealer loyalty to their companies (in Japan),'' auto analyst Mary Anne Sudol of Fitch Investors Services Inc. said Friday. She called the Honda-Chrysler deal ``a nice little breakthrough for Chrysler.'' Under the agreement, about half of Honda's Primo dealer network, a collection of 1,755 businesses that market family oriented cars, will distribute Cherokee and Wrangler vehicles. Honda said in a statement released in Japan that the Cherokee would sell for about $33,300 and the Wrangler for about $23,800. Base prices for 1990 versions of the vehicles are $15,545 for the Cherokee and $11,599 for the Wrangler. Honda sells its own sporty cars through its Verno dealerships and luxury cars through its Clio dealerships. In all, Honda has about 2,500 dealerships in Japan. General Motors Corp., the No. 1 automaker in the U.S., sells vehicles in Japan through Suzuki Motor Co. dealers. Ford Motor Co., the nation's second largest automaker, uses a 290-dealership Autorama network to sell Ford and Mazda vehicles under Ford nameplates in Japan. Ford expects to sell about 100,000 cars and light trucks through Autorama, including a mini sport-utility vehicle, this year.

DOC.HEAD: Standard & Poor's Drop Philly's Bond Ratings
DOC.TEXT: Financially strapped Philadelphia received another blow Friday when Standard & Poor's Corp. lowered its ratings on $1.3 billion in city bonds, citing ``chronic deficit operations.'' City Financial Director Betsy Reveal, who called the news ``disappointing but not unexpected,'' said the decision could cost the city $30 million in future years in extra interest. The city's general obligation bonds were downgraded two rating notches, from BBB+ to BBB-. The company also said $23.6 million in bonds issued by the Philadelphia Redevelopment Authority and Philadelphia Parking Authority were downgraded to BBB-. The rating is one level above what Standard & Poor's considers the minimum ``investment grade'' that offers a high level of security. The last time the city's bond rating dipped below investment grade was in 1976. ``It clearly will increase our costs for future borrowing,'' Reveal said. Standard & Poor's pointed to this fiscal year's city deficit _ estimated to be $60 million when the year ends June 30 _ as a sign of ``chronic fiscal imbalance.'' The credit-rating company added that the city's $2.1 billion budget scheduled to go into affect July 1 ``does not bode well for restoration of fiscal stability.''
